content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												I just finished "To the Moon". Though I doubt I'm the expected or intended audience (57-year old male) I DID enjoy the game, but as to loving it? Not so sure.The writing wasn't realistic, being more on the level of teenage dialog. That, combined with some very mature themes (meaning concepts, not parentally objectionable items) created an odd blending. The mixing in of mini-games further contributed to a sense of (almost) absurdity, especially the (in my opinion) completely unnecessary zombie game. At about the halfway point I found myself intending to finish, but wishing it wouldn't take too much longer. Then things changed. Around the middle of Act 2 the story became deeper, more real, more emotional. I did NOT cry, but I will admit to tearing up at the absolute purity of the young love that EVEN old men dream of. And the music was VERY nice.My opinion isn't important, other than to me. Yes, I AM glad I played this game. Perhaps due to the nature of it, it needed the filling-out that I found slightly tedious and unnecessary, without which the game would have been still shorter. While I might not recommend this to other 57-year old men, I would CERTAINLY suggest it for almost anyone else. (I would have been nice to get the achievement, but apparently that doesn't happen on a Mac. The brief gametime is result of offline play.)

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I try to review games as I finish them, so I can look back on them later. Weeks, months, years down the road - they help me remember the way a game made me feel, or even the person I was when I was at that particular time.To the Moon, for some reason, I never reviewed.Was it because upon completion, I was crying? Reflecting? Contemplating the meaning of life? Experiencing the dreaded feels?Yeah, probably.In To The Moon you take control of two doctors/scientists who have been hired by a dying man to grant his last wish - to go the moon. Though it is an odd request, the doctors do not question it. But to get him there, they must piece together his blurred memories, of loss, of love, of his complicated relationship with the love of his life.It feels almost intrusive to walk through a stranger's most delicate memories, and they invite you to examine your own relationships with the ones you love, flawed and complex as they may be.Play when you're contemplative, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												I just.. I sat down and did this game start to end and simply couldn't put it down. It's incredibly powerful and sad. There have been a very small handful of stories that I'd say have made a really deep impression on me, something I end up remembering for the rest of my life, those tales and characters that are so touching and poignant that they sort of become part of me, making me want to dedicate and live my life for them and succeed where they could not, and become a better person that way.This is one of those stories. And I absolutely will not tell you the plot of the story. I could never do it justice. The game presents all these weird puzzling plot items and ideas at the start of the game, but then ties them together in Act 3. My gosh. It hit me so hard.The game flirts with existential philosophy, and that is referenced a couple times by the characters but is more an undertone of the game rather than the main focus and story. There is also a fair amount of banter and humour between the two playable characters, that had me laughing out loud on occasion.It has a very linear plotline and map and is written in the RPG Maker XP engine. Slightly clunky UI, the windowed mode is incredibly small and unable to be resized, so the game is meant to be played full screen. Nothing too egrerious however, I found a couple small annoyances like movement obstacles and not knowing where to go during the horse part, but they were easily ignored. The soundtrack is simple and haunting and even plays a minor role within the story.

[SPOILER FREE]I simply can not state how this game made me feel during it's last hours and especially in the end. This is one true masterpiece, a game to be forever remembered for it's unique storytelling, dialogue and characters. The game gets really emotional in a way I've never seen since Mass Effect 2 (Yes, it is THAT good), but it also features great sense of humor, really nice pixelart and an incredible - to say the least - soundtrack. The only flaw I see in this game is the lack of an options menu, since the game apparently doesn't run at the native resolution of your desktop.Overall, I believe that any story driven gamer should play this.Strongly recommended.9.3/10

												This game is beauty and art in their purest forms. I've read a lot of books, I've watched a lot of movies, and I've played a lot of games, but never have I come across something that has caused me so much emotional turmoil and heartwrenching bittersweet feelings than this simple visual novel. content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												9.5/10So... You're here to take me to the moon?OverviewTo The Moon doesn't offer much in the gameplay department. It doesn't present stunning visuals nor is it particularly exciting... But it doesn't pretend to offer any of those things. It's short, honest, beautiful and emotionally consuming. A solid piece of masterful storytelling.StoryThe story follows the whimsical Dr. Neil Watts and level-headed Dr. Eva Rosalene, high-ranking employees of the Sigmund Agency of Life corporation, a service that specializes in altering a terminal person's memory before time of death in order to make their dreams come true. Basically, they're selling deathbed happiness.To The Moon isn't a comedy, though it's hilarious. It isn't a tragedy though it's heart-rending. What it is is brilliant. The dialogue is as powerful and relatable as the thematic is harrowing. I don't want to go into too much detail about the story; I want you to experience the twisty narrative of it by yourselves.GameplayAt first glance, the game plays like you'd expect an RPG to play, minus any form of combat or statistical management. The gameplay mechanics are bare-bones: You walk around, talk with people and interact with objects to progress in a linear fashion. The walk-and-interact gameplay is briefly diversified every now and then with a series of flip-tile puzzles. These are never too difficult and are not detrimental to the experience in the least. Other unexpected gameplay elements are also introduced for brief segments, all of which are an appreciated change of pace.Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene enter the mind of John (their patient) and start off in a late memory. They need to understand the patient's history in order to progress farther back into his past and construct variables to influence the patient's future. The goal is simple: Work your way through John's memories and spark the changes that will alter his future forever.AudioThe original soundtrack may be the strongest aspect of the game. It's strongly in-tune with the emotions that the game attempts to pull out of you and often feels like it leads the resulting impressions. I can't lie, I had to hold back tears to Laura Shigihara's "Everything's Alright" when it ripped the limelight from the scene during which it's presented.TechnicalThough the game isn't a technical marvel in itself, the user interface is pretty bland and appears "cheap". The lack of options or settings is odd and the game does not support the Steam overlay. These are all very minor shortcomings and I could only bring myself to shave off a fraction of a point for these. The game otherwise runs well, saves automatically to prevent progress loss and it all just works.The TL;DRAn engaging fable of love, waning time and the human condition it encompasses. A tale of fabrication and untruth. This is a story you likely won't soon forget. It lingers with you. A tragic comedy.To The Moon is a success. A brilliant, sense-shattering success.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This game made me realize that being bigger and having beautiful graphics is not always better.  More than anything else, game developers should strive to give us games that are both memorable and satisfying.  A game that makes you feel and experience something extraordinary.     To the Moon is not gorgeous in terms of graphics.  What it lacks in graphics, it makes up for its interactive story telling.  It lets you take part in a tale that is both hearthwarming and incredibly tragic.     The story immerses you and engages you to fulfill a dying man's (Johnny) last wish to go the moon, by altering his memory and replacing them with alternates ones.     What really made the journey interactive is how you put together bits and pieces of his memory and various highlights of his life and love story with wife (River) in order to progress forward in the story.        You will also be carried away by the games soundtrack, specially its main theme also entitled - To The Moon.  It really enhances your game experience and sets the mood in every game sequence.  The game, however, is relatively short, but the game content is what all that matters to me.  The game's message about life and death and the joys and difficulties we might or have already experienced did struck a chord.  In the end all we have our just cherished memories of our loved ones. The moral of the game is' if we had the chance and the ability to change our past, Will you do it?  Maybe some for me.       I really recommend this to a mature audience or even someone who needs a break from the run and gun games we have in our games library.  Kudos to the game developers for giving us such a wonderful game.  Can't wait for the next installment.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
												I remember when this game came out in my junior year of high school. Great time. I was an awkward, nerdy little♥♥♥♥♥♥with more time than I'd care to admit and I guess I was looking for something that'd make me *feel* stuff. One night, a couple of buddies were over and we all decided we wanted to play something with a story. Something that'd eat up a couple of hours and keep us all focused.Enter: To The MoonAs one of my buddies narrated the dialogue, we were absolutely enthralled. We couldn't tear ourselves away. How did we get so wrapped up in what was essentially a move-and-click sprite game with cliche tropes and easy puzzles? By the end of that session, we'd finished the game and, for reasons you'll understand if you decide to play through, all of us sat in the dark and cried for a while while we talked about what we'd just experienced.I cared about the characters, I loved the soundtrack, and every moment of the game made me feel warm and fuzzy. I've sat down to show it to a few people over the years since then, and even though the magic and surprise is gone, I still can't help but smile like an idiot or get a little teary-eyed while I play this game.Ladies and gentlemen, regardless of your age, if you buy one story-driven walking simulator this year, don't let it be Dear Esther or one of the seventeen ripoffs of that game; let it be To The Moon.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												To The Moon is a story-driven point and click adventure game that also incorporates puzzle elements. The gameplay mechanics are simple and incredibly easy to pick up. You won't ever find yourself stumped or frustrated at this game, since the gameplay is used to pace the plot perfectly. Without revealing too many spoilers, at its heart To The Moon is a love story. It's also much more than that, it delves right into topics such as life and death, regrets and even fate. If you're a pessimist, this is a story that will restore your faith in humanity and make you believe in love again. It had just the right amount of humor thrown in, you just can't help but smile at how silly one of the characters can be at times. It plucked on your heartstrings plenty as well, and I'm comfortable enough with my manliness to admit that there were a few moments when I was on the verge of tears, both out of sadness and out of happiness.The pixel art is beautiful and charming. A lot of care and thought was placed into the art style and I never imagined that 8 bit graphics could be so expressive. The only minor flaw I found with the game, and it's incredibly minor, is that the game runs in a set resolution and there is no option to run the game windowed. It's probably for the best, since running the game windowed can easily break the immersion. It isn't a terribly long game, it took me just under 4 hours to complete. You will want to set aside a healthy chunk of time to dedicate to this game though. I highly recommend playing this through all in one sitting, though if you're anything like me, that won't even be an option. I was so immersed into this game, I don't even think I glanced at my second monitor the last 3 hours of play, let alone get up from my chair. The soundtrack is beautiful, filled with piano arrangements that accompany the story so well. Every aspect of this game has a simple elegance to it that adheres to you at such a fundamental level. This is a game that will stay on your mind long after you've finished playing it.To The Moon is damn near perfect. It's not often that I play a game where I struggle to point out flaws or things I wished the developers changed. It's not often that I am so entranced by a game, I am glued to my computer chair until the end credits scroll past my screen. Even now, as I'm writing this review, listening to the game's soundtrack, I still feel goosebumps. This game has affected me on a level deeper than any other game ever has. The story in this game easily stands as one of the most beautiful and touching tales I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing in ANY form of media. This game is absolutely amazing, and it's one that everybody should try, even non-gamers.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												'To the Moon' is intelligent, well written and extremely creative. Two scientists dive into a dying man's mind to alter his memories in order to fulfil his final wish. And yes, the game is just as awesome as it sounds. It has some really cool moments and even though the idea is pretty surreal, it is presented to you in a way that it just sucks you in and the game MAKES you believe it is all actually possible. Not only that, you will feel for these characters. Rarely have there been games that tug on my heart strings the way this game did. Some people seem to finish it in one sitting, take 2 or 3 hours to complete it but it took me 5.2 hours for 1 playthrough from beginning to end. I like to be thorough in my games, especially the story heavy ones that rely on exploration. You will want to take it all in with this game because it is just that good.It is a very basic point and click game, nothing overly complicated and it doesn't require too much work, there are some minor riddles to solve but in the end, it relies for the most part on its emotion heavy story. The game is story driven and the visuals and soundtrack are both there to intensify the experience. Some songs might come over as repetitive (something actually made fun of within the game itself) but you will hardly notice this because the music is just that good. The graphics are reminiscent of the Super Nintendo era and it works for this game. Finally 'To the Moon' is jam packed with useless nerdy trivia for gamers and people who watch all the good tv shows.'To the Moon' is dark, atmospheric and you won't leave the game unmarked.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I have to preface this recommendation by saying that To The Moon isn't really much of a game. It's an interactive story, and a phenomenal one at that. So if you're one of those people who refuse to play interactive story experiences for whatever reason, then you'll probably get nothing out of this.For the rest of you, I say strap yourselves in and give it a shot. To The Moon is an emotional journey through a dying man's memories in order to fulfill his last wish of going to the moon. To say more really spoils what makes it so great, but suffice to say I went into this with fairly low expectations (it is an RPG Maker title after all) and came away from it wondering why we haven't had more stories in gaming that were this compelling. I couldn't actually pull myself away from the screen until I'd completed it and left going "argh, the feels!"As a result, I can do nothing but recommend To The Moon. Just know what you're getting into.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												To The Moon has the most moving story I've ever experienced, not just in games, but anywhere.  The game only takes a couple hours to complete, but it is definitely worth it just to experience the story.  The music is beautiful as well and fits perfectly with the story.The gameplay, however, is at the level where some people may not even call it a game.  While it looks like a classic JRPG, the level of interaction offered is very low.  It mostly consists of walking around to discover what triggers the next cutscene.  At some points the level of interaction offered is almost insulting, with the game giving you control just for a couple seconds to do something easily accomplished during the cutscene.  It's almost as if it's trying to remind you that you're playing a game, not watching the story.  Later in the game, it turns into more of a hidden object game where you solve simple puzzles between chapters which is much more pleasing.To The Moon is a game that needs to be experienced.  It's too difficult to put it into words, especially without giving any spoilers.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												To The Moon is everything I want in a game,  Sure, it has little gameplay and is more interactive story than really a game, but this it handles perfectly. It is one of the rare games that made me laugh, cry and feel with the characters on screen, which not many games manage to do nowadays. The story within is very human, touching, and well handled in its build up till its very tear-inducing conclusion. It is a story about people, about love and loss, and every fine nuance in between. Honestly, I can't hardly recall any game --or media in general -- which moved me to this extent like it did. Yes, it is limited in its graphics, being an RPG-Maker game, though it does use it in a very charming and heartwarming way, accompanied by beautiful music extra composed for the game. To say more would mean to spoil it, so let me conclude in saying that playing To The Moon was a very unique and great experience, and I'm thankful for having made it.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												'한 편의 아름다운 소설과 감미로운 음악을 동시에 체감하며 즐길 수 있는 작품' 게임이란 넓은 범주에서 보면 인간이 즐길 수 있는 모든 것을 포함할 것이다. 투 더 문은 이런 넓은 범주에서의 게임에 속한다. 투 더 문을 하면서 느낀 게임의 '장르'적인 방식은 마치 '디어 에스더'와 비슷하다. 유저가 게임을 직접하면서 개입할 수 있는 것은 거의 없으며, 게임적인 요소도 거의 없는 점이 비슷하다. 유저가 할 수 있는 행동은 이동과 단서 모으기 및 퍼즐 맞추기 뿐. 하지만, 이러한 요소 중 단서 모으기 및 퍼즐 맞추기는 절묘하게 스토리적인 '시스템'에 부합해서 어색함이 없다. 다만 이런 게임적 요소도 챕터 1에서 끝나버린다. 이 게임을 하게되면 유저는 4시간 가량되는 플탐동안 감미로운 OST와 감동을 이끌어내는 스토리를 별다른 개입 없이 체험만 하게된다. 게임의 스토리 요소와 OST는 매우 높은 평가와 점수를 줄만하다. 하지만, 어찌보면 그냥 비주얼 노블 마냥 진행되는 게임의 방식에 질리는 유저도 분명 존재할 것이다. 게임인가 소설인가. 그것은 직접 유저들이 판단할 문제지만 어떻게든 이 게임을 구매한 유저들에게 만족감을 준다면 그건 그거대로 좋은 작품이라는 뜻이되지 않을까? 투 더 문 시리즈의 미래를 봤을 때, 앞으로도 후속작들이 이런 방식으로 나올 것이 거의 확실한 듯 해보인다. 여러 떡밥을 해결하기 위해 작가가 스토리를 어떻게 풀어갈지 후속작도 기대가 되는 작품이다.

												Don't let the store page screenshots fool you, this game is not an RPG despite being made with RPG Maker (The squirrel battle is an ingame joke), It's a linear 16bits-ish adventure game.Talk to people, look for some items, do a few puzzles, and follow the story. The sad, touching, tear-jerking story. Seriously, if you don't cry you're not human. It's hard to talk about why the game is so great without spoiling the story. The characters have a profound personality rarely seen in a videogame, and they share a deep pure love. The beautiful music just make the experience even more enjoyable.There's two control schemes, arrow keys or mouse (No WASD for you). Mouse control can be a bit clunky sometimes, with your characters not going at first click where they're supposed to go; playing with a keyboard is faster and more efficient but then you won't have a clue about what things you can interact with.You can choose from 10 different languages. The game lasts around 4 hours and doesn't really have replay value, but it's worthy.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2013
												OK, I had previously recommended this game, but I reread it and I thought, "thats all I could say about it?" This is one of my personal favorites. Everyone needs to play this. I don't care if you don't play games like this. Play it anyway. The first time I played it, I enjoyed it and found the story beautiful and sad at the same time. I played it again and, since I knew what was coming, just enjoyed the ride. If I had to give a one word review it would be this: beautiful. The creators made good use of RPG Maker. The look is retro but charming. As great and touching as the story is, the soundtrack is the star. It never misses a beat. It covers every emotion that runs through the story and pulls at your heart. Have Kleenex nearby because the music brings a level of reality that isn't found in a lot of games. To the Moon is more than a computer game. It is something special. Its pulls you in and touches your heart. It will stay with you.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												'Ladies and gentleman, welcome aboard the feels train. Todays destination will be: the Moon!'Okay let's be honest: the gameplay of 'To the Moon' is quite boring, it's repetitive and often more annoying than entertaining. It's not the typical 'Fighting & Fantasy'-RPG-Maker game but a strictly linear adventure whichsets its focus on the story about an old man and his dying wish. Sure, there are minigames and some 'better' levels, but after the fifth time collecting some memory links to go on to the next level I just thought 'C'mon just skip this, I don't want to do this agai-... great another memory link level'. But I still recommend this game - without any doubts - to everyone who enjoys a good story.You ask why? It'S true, for me 'To the Moon' is an 'average' game at best, but at the same time it's a fantastic 'movie' with an interesting story backed up by an amazing soundtrack, well-written dialogues, interesting characters and an atmosphere that makes up for many flaws. I really enjoyed the plot and the great dialogues between the characters and you can definitly see how much time the developers used to make every scene create the right emotional situation. And - at least in my case - they succeeded.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Note: I received a copy of To The Moon for my birthday!First off I would like to start by stating that you don't actually have to use your mouse (some people get annoyed), you can use your arrow keys and your space bar (interaction key) and just use your mouse as a guide. Also, this game's graphics isn't the best (pixel art) but I promise it actually grows on you and you will start to like it. Especially because there are some sick illustrations later on.Positives:+ Deep storyline (very well thought out, kudos to the Developer's efforts) - you don't actually know what to expect when you first start playing this game; it's much more than you think it is+ Relatively nice graphics (Pixel Art)+ Beautiful and fitting music (Situational)+ Extra minisodes (DLCS)+ Character development is simply wonderful, and very well done+ Good excuse to go grab some ice cream as soon as you get to 'Act 3' (I cried a little)+ Maps aren't too large, but large enough to explore thoroughly and enjoyably especially with the little dialogues or things you pick up+ Relatively easy puzzles, but not too easy - it also displays the lowest amount of moves needed to complete the puzzle which makes you visualise the outcomes and how to complete it with the least amount of moves. Tip: As soon as it tells you about the diagonal flipping, use it because almost every puzzle afterwards requires it (to achieve least amount of moves)+ Saving options are very well thought out - automatic saves for important actions and you can also use manual saving+ There are nice little extras in the game menu where it shows you the items you have and specific 'notes' or interesting things you have found out - this is updated quite frequently and worth your time to check outNegatives:- Although I loved the character development and thought it was very well done, I definitely would have liked it more if there was more background information about Johnny's mother. We only know a little about her but I feel like she plays a bigger role than that.- Puzzles that can get repetitive (it's not too bad)- Walking speed is quite slow and can get annoying waiting for them to hurry up- Some larger maps can get tedious - walking around and finding thingsOverall:The main focus of the actual game (storyline) is very beautiful, relatable and enjoyable. It made me cry after 'Act 3' at various scenes (those who have played know what I mean). The way the story is set out seems a bit odd at first, but as you continue on it makes a lot of sense and I feel is the perfect way to lay it out. The ending was simply beautiful and you don't really see it coming - in fact, you don't see many events (plot twists people) happening until it does. There is a little bit of humour, especially with the protagonists and it's a very deep, heartfelt story. Despite the negatives, I would like to say that the postitives definitely outweigh the negatives.I love stories like these because you don't have to make any serious choices, yet the choices the protagonists make, makes you think about your morals and what you would do in such a situation. I've spent some time considering the many options and the options the protagonists made plus the repurcussions and their situations, and I finally came to the conclusion of what was morally correct. I'm fully content with the ending. I think this game is a lot about the morality of how these people help the man, as well as others. The DLCs do explore the concept of morality and how some people think what they do is immoral.Score: 9/10It's not perfect but it's close enough. Definitely worth the full price (and if you like the music, get the soundtracks too) and you get free minisodes (DLCS).I could go on and on and on... But let me say this: Just play the game, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Its barely a game, its a piece of art. It starts slow, but it gets progressively better having a peak at the very end. Level of emotional involvement is just incredible that almost no AAA titles have and guarantee you great experience, just with a bit simple and lacking gameplay, but amazing story to put you through.Couple doctors arrive to grant dying man last wish - "To the Moon". How hard can it be to go through old man's memories and alternate his past, his dreams for young qualified doctors, to ensure his adjusted dream-life brings him to the moon before he dies? Apparently dying man doesn't know why he wants go to the moon at the first place, he just does. Doctors are going to discover that its not about him, its about people he loves and cares; its about his only dream he worked for his whole life; its about connection between all those things. Would one dream destroy another one and all he lived for? Would it make him miserable, make him find something new, both or something else? Is there time to make it work? This game is so alive and tense it almost made me cry. I witnessed beautiful dreams, lives, endings, losses, achievements and success altogether, leading man to his dream, To the Moon and everything beyond it.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Great, great game. I must say that I was rather surprised by how the developer managed to make a very good story fit within the short length that the game is. The story, in my opinion, is the biggest highlight of the game, followed by the sweet soundtrack. It manages to be both really clever and moving, and the textual dialogue within the game contains that quality to it that I absolutely love, which is the one that brings emotion and personality into the written words. The one that makes the characters sound more human, and that familiarity with them renders them very emotionally potent; a kind of emotional truth that we experience at a biochemical level quite the same as we would with strangers whom we get to know with time.I suppose that the only one I genuinely have with the game is the fact that it only runs on 640x480 in Windows. While the art is still very good, it's a shame that it's not possible to experience the game in bigger resolutions. The lack of an options menu for that is an issue, and it's bad that the Steam overlay doesn't work with the game as well. Albeit, as usual with other RPG Maker games, the game's properties and settings can be easily accessed by pressing F1. Those can be used to alter the game's controls, in case the player isn't satisfied with them. They're smooth and easy to learn, however.Any gamer that loves games that are story driven must have this in their library. To The Moon contains a heartwarming narrative, good characters, fine art, and a wondrous soundtrack. This is something to be paid attention to.  It's simple, yet powerful. It's short, but gripping. It's part of why it's as impressive as it is. Very recommended, thank you for this stunning journey, Freebird Games. 9.1/10.0

Posted: July 14, 2015
"I never told anyone... but I always thought they were lighthouses. Billions of lighthouses... stuck at the far end of the sky."I don't even know where to begin. The story begins when a John a very ill person nearing his end called for two doctors that can dive deep into the patients memories to artificially fulfill his last wish.The story telling is backwards. You start from the present dive deeper into the past until his childhood and things will slowly start to make sense along the way. I tend not to give off any kind of hints to my reviews, you should play this game and know the story yourself and why it's called "To the Moon".[+] Surprising depth in writing.[+] Outstanding story that has both emotional and funny moments.[+] A casual mini-game that doesn't ruin your momentum on a story-driven game.[+] Soundtrack that you will listen over and over again.[+] Likeable characters.[+] Humor were added perfectly to where they should be.[+] I get to play whack-a-mole and ride horses and totally forgot about what I should really be doing.[-] No window. A sprite game doesn't look pleasant on fullscreen.[-] Unfortunately I wasn't able to get a screenshot for the finale due to F12 being a hotkey for pause. (LOL)[-] Some grasses are not walkable. (LOL'd again) This made some areas of the game really hassle to explore.RatingFun-factor: ★★★★★ Atmosphere: ★★★★★Story: ★★★★★Soundrack: ★★★★★Average: ★★★★★

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Absolutely sensational storytelling. Very few games out there succeed in excellent story and character development that attracts and scars players. To The Moon is one of the few that does an outstanding job in not only nailing this, but also leaving a long-lasting impact.Without revealing too much to those that have yet to play - You assume control of two Doctors – Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene – whom work for an agency whose job is to reconstruct certain aspects of dying people's memories and fulfil their deepest wishes before their lights are out; in this case, taking Johnny to the Moon. The reason to which I will not explain in this review, otherwise there would be no point in going through all the emotions this game sets out to deliver. Though you can expect a story filled with excellent dialogue and character development with plenty of unpredictable momentsGameplay is fairly straight forward and pretty much the same as TWD or any point-and-click game for that matter. There are a few mini-games and puzzles to add that little challenge factor but nothing overly complicated or mind numbing. Everything is straight forward and easy to pick up.The soundtrack is composed to perfection and aids the storytelling in a very unique way. A great mixture of tracks which change depending on the scenario at hand.The only aspect that may throw some people off is the fact that there is almost zero replayability, with the average completion time appearing to be anywhere around the 4.5 hour mark. Unless of course certain aspects of the game did not sink in properly the first time and you attempt a second rerun, though this does not bother me at all as it aimed to convey a purpose right from the beginning and was delivered to great satisfaction. Overall a wonderful game I would very strongly recommend. Do not let the simple graphics fool you! Deep down tears will be shed playing this little blockbuster.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												At first glance, To the Moon may simply look like another of those retro-coated adventures or RPGs that go dime a dozen these days. Granted, it is technically a text-driven, point-n-click adventure with a few minigames here and there. Yet when experienced in its entirety, it becomes clear that it is much more than that.Fresh from credits rolling, I can say that it's one of the best stories I've ever been told through the medium of video games. It's a unique, humane piece, unlike any I've come to experience; so elaborately woven together, so well-written and touching with flawless pacing all-around that I could have easily enjoyed it as a book if the author, Kan Gao, had chosen to tell it so. Better yet, this superb script is accompanied by an exquisite audio-visual package that enriches the adventure greatly. The result of the amalgamation of these expertly crafted elements was an experience so rich that I couldn't help myself going through it in a single session, caring about every single one of its small cast of characters and wondering what would I uncover about them next all the way. Needless to say, I found myself being amazed from scene to scene, as the 'game' was delivering everything to be expected from a true work of art in spades.The fact that this kind of an experience is not coming from of a first-tier developer but born from the minds and crafted in the hands of a small group of individuals with a small budget is only a nod to their talent. I must admit that I wasn't expecting such a fine-tuned creation with this much of an impact when I first booted the game. But here I am, after a five-hour rollercoaster of emotions, feeling all the more human thanks to this excellent work of art disguised as a game.My advice, don't lose any more time reading about To the Moon. Get it, live through it and see if it doesn't take a place among your most precious gaming memories, 'cause it surely got itself one of the best for me.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												To the Moon is a beautiful game on many levels. The music, sounds, story, artwork, atmosphere, and delivery unlock a cornucopia of raw and powerful emotions that cling to the obvious passion the developers put into it. It's a pretty remarkable journey of closure, one that is amazingly told backwards.All giddiness aside, the gameplay and user interaction are definite weak spots, although quite easy to overlook. The story also showcases a striking resemblance to movie concepts from Total Recall (memory implants)--not a knock...just saying.Only a select few indie titles have come close to pulling off the grand gaming experience that To the Moon delivers. It is every little bit a must experience game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												To the Moon is an absolutely fantastic, narrative game that is a challenge to review without spoiling what makes the game so impressive.  It lacks a lot of what people expect when they play a game, and is rather short - a little over three hours in my experience, but it more than makes up for it with the incredible atmosphere and storytelling.  The developer is a legitimate, accomplished musician and the musical score of the game alone can guide both the story and your emotions with ease.This game is truly a work of art and I recommend to anyone who thinks that they might even remotely enjoy a masterpiece of storytelling that few other games can even compete with.  I am far more often than not bored of these types of game but this one pulled me in and I've replayed it several times over now to share the experience with others.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												To the Moon is a very short game about a company who fulfills one last wish of our loved ones before they pass on.  In a short amount of time not only do you learn about some deep and surprising facts of the character who is dying, but also about the people who are trying to guide him through his final moments and complete his dying wish.  This game also comes complete with two mini games!! :)  (*spoiler alert* One of the mini games also has a fun and quite honestly challenging mini game within it.)  My suggestion is to be sure to play the main game first, as the content within the mini games will not make as much sense. (ESPECIALLY the second one!)  I really hope that many others will discover this quaint and adorable game.  Most of it is text novel, with some point and click along the way.  It is also currently as I write this on sale for 75% off.  Although it is very much worth, in my opinion that is, the full price.  So what are you waiting for??....Go get yourself a copy today! :))  ~~*NOTE* I have intentionally left out many details of the game as possible, so as to not spoil the wonderful experience of the game for others.  (The game description and trailer of it explain more anyway. lol)

content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												This game. It seems to be one of those typical pretentious indie games at first glance, but by god, this is so much more. Let me get this out of the way first: To the Moon is the game that I cried the most at throughout my whole life.Now, it doesn't really consist of a lot more than text and accompanying music, but that's way more than enough for immersion into such an amazing story—the plot was absolutely new to me, with no clichés in its integral parts at all. The setting is very similar to, or I'd even dare say borrowed from the movie 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind', but it goes way deeper beyond that, to, as far as I know, previously uncharted territories of storytelling. Naturally, because of this, the story was for the most part unpredictable for me; this is what happens when none of your actions really matter and yet the life of someone is depending on them... maybe. I'm really not even sure what to make of this all, I still am in shock after having played through the game and I will need quite some time to completely process what I've seen.Above all this, the game has an unbelievably great soundtrack that meshes with the story so well that you'll cry even more just because of the musical score. There's even some really humorous moments in the game, that include but are not limited to: poking fun at those pretentious indie games I mentioned above, breaking the fourth wall, making hilarious puns, having absolutely unexpected moments, and so on. There's clearly tons of attention paid to every detail of the game, having a masterfully crafted experience.The negatives: not much, really. The author clearly doesn't have the best technical background, so you'll be stuck playing at a weird resolution no matter what, but it doesn't take a lot to get used to.I'm still real close to crying. ♥♥♥♥.

number of helpful: 30 of 54 people (56%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												There's a great story in here but it needs a professional writer to edit and redraft it. As it is, the dialogue is very clumsy, very painful, very awkward, very unnatural - the inappropriately shoehorned jokes range from unfunny to baffling. Half the story deals with people middle-aged to elderly but the characters all speak consistently like teenagers or young adults. I hate to be that kind of snob but - maybe the overwhelmingly positive rating comes from a mostly younger audience who don't notice the bad dialogue as much? Like how Stephanie Meyer's books are so successful?It's a shame, the core ideas - mostly Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind with chunks of Elfen Lied - are solid and at times I came tantalisingly close to feeling something.Art and animation and music were all polished, can't fault them. Found the controls to be clunky, seemed a bit haphazard as to whether I could click on a thing or not, and invisible walls everywhere. There's no real gameplay, there's objects or places in the map that when clicked on will help progress the story, same as a lot of walking simulators, which I don't mind if the story's worth it.This is a completely un-cynical game written with passion and some talent, about a quasi sci-fi future where a dying man's memories of his sometimes troubled marriage to his childhood sweetheart, who lived with asperger's, are relived in a bid to grant his deathbed wish of going to the moon. That's such an awesome setup, and how many video games are we going to get with that kind of thoughtful and creative elevator pitch? And I hate, hate, hate this game for wasting it on what's basically a particularly surreal and lengthy Big Bang Theory episode. Bazoonga! or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ that guy says.

content:

AUDIOHeart-feltVISUALStockDIFFICULTYSimpleVIBETheatricalCRAVINGCinematicON SALEOccasionallyPROS: Story is exceptional, and told creatively. OST is wonderful, worth a download if you can appreciate solo piano. The world is very interesting; it would be great to see more episodes following different people. The game is easy to control and understand. CONS: Doctor Watts is a major atmosphere-ruiner. I'm assuming his more obnoxious lines were shoehorned in when it appeared the game was a bit too dramatic, but his meme-rife "comedic" relief is very unwelcomed. Much of the graphics are RPGMXP stock.WORTH: The short total playtime and stock graphics may not make it worth its full asking price.OVERALL:  To The Moon is a touching endeavor and worth 2-3 hours of your time. Freebird Games can make a hell of a story that's proof that the video game medium can tell tear-jerkers.SCORE:8/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Two parts Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, one part Inception, some really charming visuals and an extremely memorable and beautiful soundtrack and you've got To The Moon. You take control of two scientists who are part of an organization specializing in altering the unfulfilled memories of dying patients in order to help ease their passing. They crash their car on the way to their latest patient, who wants to believe he went to the moon before he dies, and saying much more than that would begin to ruin the premise, but rest assured it is a GREAT premise. Some very good narrative reveals, great character dialogue (for the most part, details on that later), and a story that you'd have to have a heart of stone not to appreciate on some level. I can admit that I'm a bit of a curmudgeon when it comes to games trying to touch my heart, but with the story, visuals and music I couldn't help but give myself over to the experience during a few particularly beautiful sequences. As far as gameplay goes, there really isn't much to speak of outside of hunting for clues in the levels, solving the picture puzzle at the end of each memory and a few scarce, optional minigames. It's also worth noting that it's a very short game, able to be finished in around 4-5 hours. That being said, it's one of those games I plan on going back to play every couple years, and it's not a very expensive game, either.My only real complaints are that the game can be broken fairly easily (Moving through solid environments, walking through cars, I even encountered a glitch early on with the log jumping mechanic that nearly forced me to delete my save and start over) and the dialogue between the scientists can be extremely poorly timed and downright obnoxious and can occassionaly ruin otherwise very touching moments. I understand the need for comic relief in a game like this, but screaming "HULK SMASH!!" and "HADOUKEN!" during emotional moments isn't the way to do it. Even so, it's still a very enjoyable game that you should definitely play if you get the chance. I wouldn't suggest picking it up for more than a few bucks if you're not the type to replay a game periodically as it is, like I said, only about 4-5 hours long. It's in a bundle right now and it goes on sale very cheaply from time to time, though, so why not pick it up?

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												People give excellent games a 10/10 and maybe half of them deserve it, but To The Moon has a brilliant story that needs to be experienced by everyone and their grandmother.  There's really nothing quite like it, and the fact that it's able to convey such a brilliant story WITHOUT voice acting and using 16-bit graphics is genius in itself.  I would put this in the same calibur as a Half Life, Super Mario 64, Warcraft 3, type of level even though there really isn't any gameplay.  I would put it above Life Is Strange and Grim Fandango as well, which were my favorite interactive-story type of games before I played this.  Yes, it's THAT freaking good!11/10

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												To the Moon is an adventure game/bordering on visual novel which uses 16-bit era RPG-style graphics to communicate its story. In it, two doctors use a device which allows them to travel through a man's memories, altering them in such a way that in his coma state it allows him to dream that he has lived the life which would have resulted from those alterations.The story is the important factor of this game, so I'll refrain from saying any further due to spoilers. It's an excellent story although the writing can be a little mediocre in spots. I'd recommend finishing the game in one or two sittings to get the full experience, but that is not mandatory by any means.For those who enjoy narrative-driven games, this is a must purchase. However, it might be worthwhile to wait for a sale of some sort.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												If I had to describe To the Moon in one word, it probably would be "epic" or "awesome", probably I just would say "pure-epic-awesomeness", but I don't know if it's possible to describe the game fairly even with many words and I surely won't try it... Thankfully you can focus in a review on other aspects aswell:Story: I don't want to talk too much about the story, because I guess you better have to explore it for yourself and the game is based... well about 50% on the story. Just one hint: "I am round. Sometimes I'm light, sometimes I'm dark, sometimes I'm both. Many people want to walk on me but few ever will. What am I?" ;) Reach it or die trying and you probably finished one of the most awesome games about life, death, love and the inherent struggles mixed with some small puzzles. If I had to rate it, I would give the story 5/5 weaselpoints.^^ Graphic: It's an indiegame, and for an indiegame the graphic is wonderful, because the 16bit style! fits perfect (better then a poorly executed try of "modern" graphic) 5/5 weaselpoints.Sound: It's hard to say, how much the game is based on the story, or on the soundtrack... I decided to split it 50/50... I really enjoyed the story and even as a "grown-up" I caught myself wiping a tear away. But the soundtrack alone is just a masterpiece. Well fitting in the story, without harsh breaks, and still escorts me even without playing the game 5/5 weaselpoints.Length: I needed about 5h to complete my journey. Even I wish it would have last longer, it's fair for an 8€ indiegame full of awesomeness and emotions compared to some 50€ fullprice highend-graphic junk without a real story but with the same length. 5/5 weaselpoints.Difficulty: There are no seperate settings for the difficulty but it doesn't matter. The puzzles within the story I would rate as fair and doable for everyone.Summary: 5/5 I highly recommend this game. A real gem within the flood of indiegames! And even this all wouldn't be enough, the game includes 1 achievement and it's really simple to get!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Human wishes are the meaning of our life. They set our path, affect our decisions… They make us what we are. To The Moon tells us a story of an old dying man that wants his final wish to be fulfilled. Wish that he cared through his life. That made him who he is. As Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts you will travel back in old man’s memory to let him live through his wish. Even if only in dreams. The story you will see in this trip is full of emotional moments. Moments that can’t leave you indifferent. Main and credit melodies are unbelievable. And gameplay is easy but interesting. All who loves quest novels with heartful story should play this masterwork of Canadian designer/composer Kan "Reives" Gao.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I don't really know how to describe this game, other than to say it's an interactive story with some light gameplay in it. However, I don't mean that in a bad way, as it's a very good format to tell a story.The story follows two doctors working in a company that grants its clients (who are all people on their deathbeds) a last wish of sorts before they die: they rewrite their memories so they can accomplish whatever they dreamed of; in the case of the game, the client is a man who always dreamed of going to the Moon, hence the title of the game. The story is very good, and emotional; and I'd say the game it's worth it for the story alone. Still, I'd make a disservice to the devs, as they managed to craft a very good game not only storywise, but in aesthethics and overall tone. The traditional RPG style fits the game pretty well, and the soundtrack is very good as well.As far as gameplay goes, as I said, it has light gameplay; there won't be a lot of fighting or anything like that; only going around interacting with certain objects, and having dialogue with different NPCs. Even then, it's entertaining enough, and the gameplay works to enhance the story.After the main story, there's two extra DLC chapters (which can be downloaded for free), which show a bit more of the company the doctors work for; and it's set during Christmas, after the events of the main game. The tone remains somewhat similar to that of the main game, although there's a few interesting twists (particularly in the second chapter).Well, I don't think I can say much more about this game, other than I recommend it.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
 Rate  : 11/10 would board the Feel Train again!  Game Information :Modes : Single PlayerGenre : Indie, RPG, AdventureEngine : RPG MakerDeveloper : Freebird GamesPublisher : Freebird Games	Platforms : Windows, Mac & LinuxRelease Date : 1 Nov, 2011How Long to Beat : 4 hoursTo The Moon is an Indie RPG created by Freebird Games. The game follows Dr. Neil Watts and Dr. Eva Rosalene, employees of Sigmund Corporation, whose job it is to fulfill the final wishes of elderly people who are about to die.They do this by using a machine that allows them to go back through their patient's memories and influence them to fulfill their wishes, creating the memories of their wishes being fulfilled for the patient. In the game, the patient is an elderly man named Johnny, whose dream is to go to the moon. However, he does not know why he wants to go to the moon, so the doctors must find out why he wants to go in order to influence him to go. The doctors go through his memories, from being an elderly man to being a child, in a race against time to get him to the moon before he passes away. The game also delves into the lives of people in Johnny's life, such as his wife River, his friend Nicholas, Isabelle and others. Though this game has a rich story and a great soundtrack, it is still click to proceed type game. Its still worth playing and enjoying.  Free DLCs : ● Sigmund Minisode 1● Sigmund Minisode 2 Verdict : Why are you still reading my review, buy and play this amazing game now. content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												To the Moon is a beautiful story driven game, with gameplay taking a backseat. This game is all about story as the gameplay consists pretty much of moving on a 2D plain and solving puzzles. If you are not one for games with little actual gameplay, then I do not recommend this game, but if you enjoy stories, then I highly, highly recommend To the Moon. My only issue with the game were the controls. Using the mouse to move was often a pain, because it either wouldn't register or the character just wouldn't move there. If you can, I suggest using the keypad to move. During the "Puzzles" the game also registered me as double clicking quite a lot, which made me miss some of the ideal move numbers.The story is, in my opinion, absolutely brilliant and I will not hide the fact that I did cry towards the end. Its sad, but really sweet is all I can say without spoiling it.The music is also fantastic. I'm a sucker for piano pieces and the main theme and "Everything's Alright" are absolutely amazing...I gotta give the vocalist credit as she did a beautiful job. If you can, purchase the soundtrack. You won't regret it.Again, I highly, highly recommend this if you're looking for a good story, because it's fantasticly well done, with a brilliant concept. Just be ready to bawl your eyes out.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
Short version: 96%To the Moon is an RPGMaker interactive movie that is… is…Just… just play it. Just buy it and play it. There should be nothing else said about. Just… play it.Long version:Don’t let the appearance fool you: To the Moon may have been created with RPG Maker XP, but it is an interactive movie through and through. Player input is minimal and it is restricted to walking around, examining things, and two minigames.The main theme of the story is memories. Memories of a lifetime, to be exact: you play as two scientists, whose job is to create an artificial set of memories for a dying old man, so he can reach happiness in his final moments.The memory exploration is twofold: on one hand, we are witnesses to key moments of the man’s life going backwards in time, slowly learning what choices and events led to his final decision.But the journey is also quite symbolic, even allegoric. All memories are tied to small mementos, and as the journey progresses, we learn how much importance a seemingly insignificant object can hold for someone… Something I’m sure all of us are familiar in our own lives.There are two minor problem with the game. Two smudges on this perfect gem. One is the overabundance of slapstick; its purpose is to have small emotional pauses in this story, but sometimes it is misused. The other is the obstacle-passing minigame towards the end that just feels completely out of place and nonsensical.Still, even with these, To the Moon is still probably the best indie game available on Steam. So… just buy it and play it.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
To the Moon is a game that truly has a heart to it. The music is fantastic and syncs very well with every moment of the story. The graphic style reminds me of the Super Nintendo era of jRPGs, the likes of Final Fantasy and Secret of Mana.But the game plays very differently from a RPG. It's sort of an interactive story, with some adventure and puzzle elements to it. It's not very long, which is not a criticism, given that the flow of the history is very good and it respects your time (not many "fillers" or wasted time on silly things).The history feels very personal and immersive. It can be very touching at times, going through the whole set of emotions (happy, sad, depressive, euphoric, funny). There are a few easter-egg-references to other games and pop/nerd culture in general. Even though they’re, for the most part, hit-or-miss, i think it’s a nice touch nonetheless.Definitely gets my recommendation.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Background: dislike "Nintendo RPG" art, love point n clicks. Heard good things about the game.The Good:* Great sound and atmosphere for a game with such limited animation* Outstanding story with humour, sadness and joy* Fun but not difficult mini game puzzles* First rate dialogue with very natural characters and reactions* Superb use of memories in the latter parts* Characters have depth and there's surprising subtly included* Leaves you wanting more and lots of hints at unexplored concepts The Bad:* Bland but well crafted '8bit' art* Very clunky mouse movement and hit n miss hotspots* Clunky speech skipping that stopped working in chapter 3 for me* Short and little to no immediate replay value* Horse riding section is confusingly under explainedImpressions: Much like 'Gone Home' this is a story being unfolded as you move and click. It tugs the heartstrings and plays with your emotions but not in a cynical way that left me tearful and sorely impressed at how well delivered the story was. The high concept plot and natural dialogue raise the game well above it's underwhelming artwork and poor hotspot/movement detection and pathing.Recommended for: People with a heart and a soul for a well told story. Requires pixel hunting and plenty of reading.Conclusion: 8/10. Story of the year that will stay with you for a long time.

content:
Posted: February 13
												To The Moon was quite an experience of a game for me.In To The Moon, you play as scientists that are part of a corporation called the Sigmund Corp. They are developing a technology that can create artificial memories, and they offer this as a "wish fulfillment" service to people who are about to pass away, so that they may pass on more peacefully. However, these artificial memories conflict with the patient's real memories, the procedure is only legal to do on people without much time left to live.Sigmund Corp. employees Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts are requested to provide a fulfillment to the lifelong dream of the dying Johnny Wyles, Although he never could explain why, Johnny's lifelong dream was always to go to the moon.  The doctors use special headgear and devices that allows them to interact and put themselves into an interactive compilation of his memories, and traverse backwards through his life, from his elder years to his childhood.The more time goes on through the memories, the more Eva and Neil learn about Johnny and his life. They find mementos, and learn about him, what brought him to his career, and his marriage. I will not spoil anything else, as the game is an absolutely incredible experience to enjoy blind to the story and going into hearing and seeing it for the first time. However, I will say that To The Moon has so many emotionally impactful moments, some of hope, some of despair, some of fear and some of pain. You will see the memories through Johnny's mind, and start to develop knowledge about his life, as well as possibly think about your own.The game's story and emotional impact is amazing and incredible, and To The Moon still remains to be one of the most emotional and touching games that I've ever played. The soundtrack is also absolutely beautiful, and adds to the atmosphere in the game. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a story-rich game with plenty of emotion, and lots of real-life stuff to think about, too. It was an incredible experience of a game, and I cannot recommend it enough. ^.^

English Version: Given that I was not convinced about this game's quality, I wanted to try It, and I have to say that I understimated It because of its low price.Is a 2D adventure game with apparently very simple dynamics, but It has a lot to offer to the players. The protagonist, a man with the only wish of reaching the moon, seemingly inexplicable, is dying; so he asks over Doctoress Eva Rosalene and Neil Watts, who belong to the sigmund Agency of Life Generation, in the attempt of reaching his very last wish through artificially implanted memories. However, as the game progresses, the plot thickens and the introspection and the past of the poor elderly protagonist, Johnny Wyles, begins to excite the minds even colder.The graphics do not excell but they offer simple and different scenarios. The plot, at least to me, is very reminiscent of Inception (for those who saw it), even if we are talking about memories and not dreams. Johnny and his poor wife are deeply characterized, so much that the gamers are made aware about the wife's health condition, which is not so rare in today's reality. The soundtracks are very impressive, and in any case always suited to the circumstances in which they find themselves. The gameplay is very simple, but the depth of the story manages to entertain the gamer to everyone for the duration (albeit brief) of the game. Yes, the game, unfortunately, is short-lived, but nevertheless It's an experience recommended to all.Do not be fooled by the low price, as It previously happened to me: It's a MUST HAVE in your Steam LibraryItalian Version: Sono venuta in possesso di questo gioco grazie al consiglio di un amico, che già lo possedeva. Non convinta dell'eccellenza di tale titolo, ho voluto provarlo, e devo dire di averlo sottovalutato per via del prezzo basso. To the moon è un'avventura grafica in 2d che si presenta come un gioco dalle dinamiche molto semplici che tuttavia ha molto da offrire ai giocatori.  Il protagonista, un uomo con il solo scopo di raggiungere la luna, apparentemente inspiegabile, è in fin di vita; così convoca nella sua abitazione sopra una scogliera i dottor Eva Rosalene e Neil Watts, appartenenti alla Sigmund Agency Of Life Generation, intento a raggiungere il suo ultimo desiderio attraverso l'impianto di ricordi artificiali. Tuttavia, man mano che il gioco avanza, la trama si infittisce e l'introspezione ed il passato del povero anziano protagonista, Johnny Wyles, inizia ad emozionare anche le menti più fredde. La grafica, pur non eccellendo, offre scenari diversificati e semplici. La trama, almeno a me, ricorda molto Inception (per chi l'ha visto), anche se qui si parla di ricordi e non di sogni. La caratterizzazione di Jhonny e della sua povera moglie è ben approfondita, tanto da sensibilizzare la gente sulla condizione di quest'ultima, che non è così tanto rara nella realtà d'oggi. Le colonne sonore sono molto suggestive, ed in ogni caso sempre adatte al contesto nelle quali si trovano. Il gameplay è molto semplice, tuttavia la profondità della storia riesce ad intrattenere il videogiocatore allo schermo per tutta la durata (seppur breve) del gioco. Ebbene sì, il gioco, purtroppo, è poco longevo, ma tuttavia è un'esperienza consigliabile a tutti. Non fatevi ingannare dal prezzo basso, com'è successo a me, è un MUST HAVE in libreria.

												If you are a fan of the visual novel genre, or enjoy a game with a focus on narrative-driven storytelling, give 'To the Moon' a shot. It is a short game where you travel from flashbulb memory to flashbulb memory of a man who wants to go to the moon before his death - but to grant his wish, you must first unravel the mysteries of his past.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Beautiful, emotional storytelling. It's a story first, and a point and click game second. The game is simply the medium. It's funny, serious, dark and hopeful all at once. A simple concept experienced masterfully, games don't normally affect me but this one struck a chord. The soundtrack is only a couple of very basic tracks, but it is hauntingly beautiful, and deserving of the pickup. In many ways, this game is like a movie experience with the added benefit of your own input and interaction. Visually, it's retro look gives it charm, and it's impressive how much emotion can be conveyed with pixelated animation. You take the role of a pair of specialists who enter peoples memories, specifically dying people, to generate an experience from them that they express as a dying wish. In a style reminiscent of Inception they dive into the life of John, to fulfill his wish to go To The Moon. They have great chemistry, with fantastic pop culture references and lots of one liners. The story they discover is touched with meaning and emotion. I can't say what makes this game so great without revealing anything that happens, but it brought me to bittersweet tears.I bought this on a whim, a whim I now very greatful for. It's a truly enriching game, and it will make you cry.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												This is not a game. It's an interactive story where clicking is required to progress from scene to scene and from dialog to dialog.  The fact that from times to times some ridiculously easy puzzles have to be solved in order to progress doesn't exactly make it a game. There's nothing challenging about it.Anyway, its best part is the story. It's a complex story that treats matters of life and death in such way that it gets to be felt quite close and personal. I completely don't recommend this to depressive people. I was on the verge of busting into tears several times throughout its duration. The story is great, very touching and impactful. It's hard to speak about it without spoiling it, but I guess I could say it somehow reminds of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, the movie, but only in just a few aspects.Other than the story (but damn, what a story!...), there was nothing I liked about how "To the moon" presented itself to me. The soundtrack supports the story pretty well, it enhances the feelings that the story transmits, but it gets cheesy at points, near the end. Don't get me wrong, it's an awesome soundtrack that clearly shows the loads of work it required, but it's just not my type, I'm more into the Bastion-like soundtracks.Many people seem to have found the strength to tolerate the awful graphics, but I still can't ignore them. It's an "RPG Maker"-like, uber low budget kind of graphics that ruined for me the immersiveness of the "to the moon" experience at points. Since the clicking and controlling was also quite imprecise, I think I would've even prefered a slideshow of still images instead of some of the scenes where just moving around was pretty annoying and tedious. It also lacks basic settings like sound volume controls, full screen / window mode toggling, screen resolution settings, all the basic stuff. At least it comes with steam cloud support and a pretty neat, single "Steam achievement".Anyway, I don't regret the money spent on it and the 3 hours and a half that it took me to finish it. It's a great experience. It's also, indeed, worthy of still being considered the saddest game of all. I submit to this general opinion as well.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												To the Moon is a indie adventure game designed and built in RPG Maker, though it is not actually an RPG in the traditional  sense it looks as if it is, though there is no combat (Except as a joke in one spot) and very little actual gameplay outside of the usual adventure game mechanics of talking to everyone and finding things in the environment.In To the Moon you play as two doctors who are employed by the Sigmund Corporation under a new wish fulfillment service that people may use as they are dying, it lets the doctors alter memories to help someone believe they fulfilled their life long dream, and as such they are called to the house of Johnny Wyles who's dying wish is to go to the moon, but he does not know why, so as the two doctors you must go through Johnny's memories and figure out why while also building things up for Johnny to become an astronaut.Now... I am leaving out key parts to the story here because I do not wish to spoil it but suffice it to say To the Moon may have one of the best stories I have ever come into contact with in a video game, it is beautifully written to the point that I was in tears multiple times while playing it, despite how it looks graphically the writing shines through and delivers powerful emotions that tug at your heartstrings.Although it may seem a bit short, clocking in at about four to five hours long, less if you know exactly what to do, it is well worth it, an amazing experience from top to bottom, polished with very little flaws outside of repeating the same sliding puzzle every time you jump memories.And on a side note the soundtrack is totally worth it, the musical score is memorable to the point that after you finish the game, even just the music will bring back memories of the story, all in all a must play for anyone who cares about an amazing story in a video game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
A Paladin’s Steam Review: To The Moon. A Lot of Feels Story, not a Lot of Gameplay.Genre: Sci-Fi Adventure Comedy/Tragedy Story Driven Experience. Developed & Published by: Freebird GamesPlatform: Windows, Mac, Linux.Business Model: Base GameCopy Purchased by Myself Overall Story Thoughts & Gameplay MechanicsThe story is about two doctors who provide a service to people on their deathbeds. This service they perform is where they go into the person’s memories and change events in their head so that it concludes how they would prefer. The game is focused on one such patient and uncovering pieces of his past. There’s some interesting subjects brought up in the game, about life and death. About the moral and philosophical questions brought up about what these two are doing and the actions with regards to the patient. That being said, I feel like this is a game best experienced by yourself. It's not a story I really want to get into or dissect, as I feel that takes away from the experience. I won't deny that this is a bit of a cop-out but at the same time, that's why I don't usually cover titles like To the Moon all that often. I find them difficult to cover. The gameplay amounts to you finding certain important items on the level and advancing the story along. There’s not a lot that you, the player, can do when it comes to this game. A lot of the game expects to be watched and read, so there’s not much variance to the experience worth nothing. I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome. PC SettingsSettings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well. The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game. Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie. Final ThoughtsTo the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...Read the review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												To The Moon is simply one of the best story based games ive played in my entire life.A game that went under the radar for many people, developed by a small studio called Freebird Games, To The Moon is an incredible and heart breaking experience, as it will bring the manliest of men to there knees in tears.In short, its about 2 Doctors traveling through the memories of a dying man to fulfill his final wish, there isnt too much I can give away without ruining some part of the story, so hear this, play this game, buy it and play it, this game is simply incredible.This game was an emotional rollercoaster for me and many others who played this game, as you tie bits and pieces of the story together as you progress, you feel youself becoming weaker and more emotional as realisation sets in and you learn how sad the life of this old man really is.The game consists only of clicking around with your mouse, as there is no action, no fighting and no enemies to face, this may seem as a turn off for many, but in reality it is just a better way to immerse yourself in the game and its story, it simply couldnt be represented in a better way.From the outstanding soundtrack, spectacular story and the brilliant dialogue that this game delivers, its simply a masterpiece, and all that in around 3-4 hours of gameplay.9/10I can see why many people will and have enjoyed this game, but can also see why others may not.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
 To The Moon  is a truly beautiful game. It's very essence screams with emotion and you find yourself screaming with it. This game is the kind of game you sit down expecting to try for half an hour at 11:00 at night and find yourself still playing sometime the next morning. It's story proves engaging and litterally enthralls you as you become the game's minion. Entrusting you with simple tasks,  To The Moon  requires one to search in reverse chronological order small memories of a dying man in an attempt to convince a younger reflection of himself to follow a certain path in life, motivating him to fulfill his own death wish. As should be plain as daylight, untrained professionals such as us are provided with every opprotunity by Freebird Games to come in conact, learn about, and fall in love with the characters as we travel backwards through a man's most intimate and poignant moments of living. You spend hours caught up in this man's life, almost understanding him as well as he does himself, and that's where you find you've actually spent hours getting caught up in a magnificent and chancy trap: You slowly realize it as the story progresses, I will not reaveal it here, but you do inwardly question this dying man as you roam his thoughts. It even talks about a topic that is not quite well addressed in media and especially in games, and that is commendable in and of itself. Mental illnesses require the attention of close loved ones. This game explores the "whens" and "wheres" of unconditional love and just how significant it is in the lives of others. The entire time you are investing in a one-way friendship with this man, you are accompanied by a moving, extremely well crafted soundtrack he soundtrack is so fantastic it makes one wish they could either play, pick up again, or practice these songs on the piano. A mix between simplicity and complexity that complements the story line and the artstyle; everything comes together so thoroughly. If one were looking only for music, this game shines as brightly as any lighthouse. Now, in a sea of drama, the pair of scientists one guides through the memories provide comedic relief and this is where I could see where we lost a portion of the (at the time of writing) 440 out of 16010 people who did not recomend this game and that number could have been cut if there had been the following warning: the characters you play will bicker like siblings and they are present to cut tension. If they were not there, the story would be too heavy to handle. I enjoyed their presence and I laughed out loud a number of times as they allowed the developers over at Freebird to show their humor in a creative way. Actually, I find them reminiscent of certain characters Shakespeare would include in his works (i.e. the Porter in Macbeth) in order to plant some kind of restraint in an otherwise constant flow of deep and taxing storytelling. Please do not let yourself be unwilling to play this game because of them. My only personal complaint are the controls. I will say that this game is a point and click interactive story that one should use the arrow keys and enter/space bar for. I found the point and click clunky and not always accurate. I lost nothing in using the arrow keys, though, so it does work. Also, I found there to be too much delay in the memento puzzles for the amount of computing it should take. That did not detract much either as I was too busy figuring out moves anyway. That's it. The end of my complaints. "Use the arrow keys and I thought they could have cleaned up the programming for the puzzles. Otherwise, job well done. Fantastic story. Fantatstic sound track. Interesting art. 15571/16011 would play again." Thank you for your time.

I get that narrative-driven games are like this, but, it’s getting more and more tiresome. PC SettingsSettings for this game are extremely lacking. No resolution options (it runs in a 640x480 resolution), v-sync option is hidden away in the game properties menu which is only accessible by pressing F1 in-game (not something that’s made immediately clear I might add). Keybindings can be changed for both controller and mouse + keyboard though. There are separate volume sliders as well. The graphics are a 2D pixelated affair, with a top-down jRPG-like camera angle. Music is an instrumental affair with a lot of solo piano and strings. It works well to create a morose sort of weight to the game. Side note: the free DLC story that comes with To the Moon doesn't play on anything but Windows. It's ok, a nice little freebie. Final ThoughtsTo the Moon is pretty good. The story certainly has its feels and the game is laser focused on telling a tight story. I’ll give them credit that despite being a passive observer for the majority of it, they clearly knew what they wanted to tell. It’s not an entirely passive affair but the most you’ll end up doing is finding items to advance the plot along, moving around rooms and talking with people. There’s some interesting philosophical and ethical questions about death that are brought up as well. Other than that, what’s left to say...Read the review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]
