number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Yes, this is a sad but thoughtful game. After playing it, I don't even know whether I should be happy or not. Perhaps makers of this game want this reaction. When I entered the house and hear the song 'For River', I can feel the sad inside it. When I finished the first time leap in the old man's memory and meet the old man behind the house, I can even feel his loneliness. He just stand there watching the light tower and maybe he was thinking the old time he spent with his wife. Then every time I leap the memory, I come closer to the truth why the old man wants to go to the moon, and in the last memory, when the old man was a child and went to the festival with his mom and brother, when he went to that cliff far from the noisy party, saw the stars and moon and finally met River, my tears went out, just an accident changed the old man's life. Because that accident his mom lost her mind, he also lost his brother, and the most important thing, he forget the first time he met River and the promise he made with her. River had mental illness but she tried her best to let Johnny remember her. The rabbit, the moon, the light tower, even that toy and bag, every thing was shown to Johnny but he still didn't remember anything. Though at last two doctors finally achieve the old man's dream, but we all know this is just a fake. The past cannot be changed, the story of Johnny and River is still there and two doc can still remember that sad story. And of course as the player I can also still remember their hard and sad life. Two poor patients finally leave this world, but their story won't leave this world. Ehh, I seldom write a article but this game deserve a long article. I strongly recommend everyone play this game and listen to the song 'For River', which full of Johnny's love to River. And at last, just like River said, 'I'm happy now, that's enough.' I hope everyone can find their own happiness through their lives, no matter how hard life is, just don't give up, do what you most want to do, just like River and Johnny.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The story of a man named "John Wyles" and a woman named "River" and a dream...a dream to go to the moon. There are three story acts in 'To The Moon': Act 1 will leave an empty feeling in your heart, Act 2 will answer questions left unanswered and Act 3 will drown your hearts in feelings and emotions that you otherwise were containing as you played. I can't spoil anything besides what is told from presentation here. There has only been a few "games" (well, this is an 'interactive story') out there which could, despite its graphics (it was made on an RPGMaker - it wasn't meant to be innovative; it was meant to be story-rich) which could touch the hearts of people, including me. Although I was not able to sit through this particular gem in one sitting (I can't feel for a game if noises are around me all the time, and thus only play this when it's quiet enough in the middle of the night...it is 5:22 AM as we are writing this and I've finished it.). I have to say that everyone, and I mean everyone, should see this work of fiction for themselves at least once as a gamer (or even just a bystander).9.5/10My overall feelings towards 'To The Moon'...my words do not justify this work enough and encourage anyone reading this to take the trip as I have. If I could, I would have cried sentimental tears.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												For the better part of two years now I've frequently been exposed to opinions that go something like this:"oh em gee, To The Moon is the saddest thing evurrrrr :("Being a naturally trusting person I assumed these people knew what they're talking about. I was somewhat worried going in and expected some sort of shattering experience. By the second half of Act1 I already found myself waiting for a plot twist of sufficient calibre to come by and salvage my expectations of tearjerkiness, but it never did. I am kinda disappointed. Yes, it's an interesting premise and a touching, excellent story but that's it. Although I'm confident it would make one hell of a Hollywood blockbuster if adapted, I found the whole thing barely more emotional than, say... Dear Esther. It's still a great, worthwhile experience, just... don't have particular expectations. Hype is bad mkay.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												A short but heartwarming story.You play as two scientists who are tasked with fulfilling a dying man's wish by implanting him with artificial memories before he dies. He wishes to go to the moon, but he doesn't know why. You go back in time through his memories, from old man to young child, to find out why and to implant the new memory. Admittedly, the reason he wants to go to the moon is a bit ham-fisted, but the story surrounding his life is still quite touching and there are a few other interesting twists.The gameplay mostly consists of just walking around and interacting with people and objects, with a few easy puzzles in between (and an optional game of whack-a-mole for some reason). The gameplay is so minor that I'd honestly be fine if there were no interactivity at all, but it never gets in the way of the storytelling.If you like story-focused games (or even just these kinds of heart-tugging stories in general), l recommend To The Moon

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												I really enjoyed this one. It's more of an interactive story than a game, but it's kind of brilliant how that perfectly fits the story. It's about memories that have already happened and you're meant to observe with minor input. It's charming all around and when everything ties together you'll♥♥♥♥♥♥bricks... or maybe cry if that's a thing you do.Now to the complaints! The concept is bold and it's a great accomplishment that it mostly works as a video game. But while the dialog itself has personality, there are parts of it I really dislike. All of the characters (children and elderly) speak at an 18 year old age level. It's supposed to take place in the future, but they use lots of contemporary nerdy video game and anime references. I like how they try to mix jokes in with the sadness, but the out of character meta jokes feel lame and take me out of it.So I'd recommend it to people who already like games and are looking for something story oriented, heartfelt, and different. I'd like to recommend it to people who are less in to games (because they'd easily be able to cope with the limited gameplay), but I think the in-jokes would be too off-putting for them to take the rest of it seriously.TL;DR - Memento + Inception + The Notebook. There's a 1 hour demo, so give it a try!

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												There are certain games that leaves a horrific scar, be it for bad or for worse; and there are games which leaves an emotional scar, making the experience sweeter and satisfying. Do not let the RPG Maker tag deceive you -- To The Moon isn't an RPG: if anything, it's on the far-end of the spectrum, simply because the game has no combat mechanics of that sort. Instead, it relies on something triple-A games sorely lack and aspire to achieve: a player-invested story built upon multiple layers. And the game wears it like a proud dogtag. What should be the focal point is always the story. About two "doctors" that help a man relieve his dreams again, eventually finding out the entire cause of it, and granting his wish of making it To The Moon. The game straddles the line between hope and despairity; loss and gain; tragedy and happiness -- all in under five hours (counting the 2 minisodes which are absolutely must-plays). To The Moon is an all-round experience that leaves you wanting more, and hopes that after you've gone through all the sobbing tissues right by your side, that you still have a bottle of scotch waiting for you once the game ends. Because trust me: you'll need it. Brilliant story, brilliant soundtrack -- To The Moon is one of the best gaming experiences of all-time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												It's not so much as a game as it is an interactive storybook. One where  you flip the pages to the very end.The wording "To the Moon" is truthful in wording and truthful in where it leads. Physically and emotionally tolled, you will be affected as you take on the journey of an ideologically driven man - lying on his deathbed- to his dream of landing on the moon. He wishes it not only for his own sake, but for the women he loved so much as to let her die. His final action and wish is a gift of placation and apology for her sake. You control two scientists who enter dreams in an effort to change the memory of any ailing, near death patient in order to achieve their dreams mentally, but not physically. Their characters are often juxtaposed with the backdrop of the bitter, saddened clients they have, but it serves as a humanizing reminder of the need for human emotion in the times of desperation. They don't serve as the main character, but as (you) -> The person who journeys from the start and to the end of the story, not the creator.There isn't much of a game here to be had besides a few puzzles here and there, scattered as a movement of progression. Each puzzle serves as a pinpoint of interest in the client's life reminding the player of the human aspects of the person's mind they are investigating. May it be a simple baloon or some pickles, each pinpoint from the puzzle has its purpose of showing how human the character is.Verdict: This is a journey, a story of a man's unattained wish and you must complete it. I recommend it to the fullest to whoever enjoys games for their stories and not just for their gameplay. This is purely an interactive story.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
 This will hit you right in the feels....and you'll be glad it did. Don't be put off by the way this game starts, I was, and I beg you to learn from my mistake.After playing through the first 10 minutes or so i quickly declared the game to be "boring as hell" and "A magnificent waste of my time", but when I stumbled upon it in my library again late yesterday evening I gave it another shot....and played straight through the night just so I would get to finish it, hell I even played the minisodes while I was at it.I would highly recommend this game to anyone, it might not give you that adrenaline rush some people crave but it will sure as hell kick you right in the feels, and you'll thank it for doing so. During this game I laughed, I cried, and most of all I just had a ton of fun. The graphis aren't great, and yeah, sometimes the controls are a little wonky, but the AMAZING soundtrack won't leave you any time or need to worry about that. From some of the very first scenes to the very end, the music grabbed me and pulled me straight through the just as well written story. I would honestly tell everyone to buy this game, take a day off, and just play through it in one sitting. At the end, you'll almost be a different person. This game tells a wonderfull story, and does so in such a way that no matter what you wanted to happen, what you expected, what you hated, what you liked, you'll still love it, just the way it was.This game definitely got itself a place in my heart, and I hope it'll find it's way to your heart too.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												To the Moon is one of those works whose very nature places it at a disadvantage. Like a kicker on an American Football team, this genre (which is most satisfactorially described as an "interactive experience") is not comparable to its peers since it doesn't do the same thing they do. But in all fairness its peers likewise cannot match what it does, and you'd better believe it does plenty!The Negs --This title catches you off-guard, withholding the real meat of the gameplay until about 30 minutes in. And even then, that gameplay meat is lean-sliced turkey over a bagel at best. The "interactor" (rather than "player") functions to only move characters from one cutscene to the next. To the Moon could be outright categorized as a point-and-click game if it weren't for the RPG presentation it offers. The story mechanics are sometimes inconsistent, making the goals unclear, which is especially frustrating when all you want to do is get the characters to the next scene of dialogue. This frustration is not extensive though. There were some bugs in places, and sometimes the ground was just too cluttered with vague textures. Quite literally I continually thought the game was freezing on me simply because my character stopped walking when in reality a small flower, not so different in appearance from another small flower that I walk right over, was just blocking my way. The faults of the gameplay were highly bearable, however, mainly because the gameplay was a minor part of this experience.The Pos --Despite all the underwhelming gameplay aspects, this piece held my attention for 5 hours quite easily. The culprit: the characters. Not the main two doctors - I knew about them. What captivated me were the rest of the cast and their unanswered stories. The writing in this game is keen and well-paced, playing coy about the questions it introduces while not leaving the interactor lost for too long. The dialogue ventures into topics that are realistically gritty and gray. This whole experience works in the first place because the user is immersed enough to accept the story and characters at hand. This immersion is influenced by the detailed artwork, which avoided the half-hearted tiling of textures that RPGs are known for, and by the MIND-BLOWING SOUNDTRACK!!!!! I could not give the ost for this work any more laud than it has already received, but if my two cents count for a thing, the music in this game had me consciously framing each scene to its tone, particularly when the music changed mid-scene.The Verd --To the Moon is definitely one to sit down and just experience one day. It is certainly not the sort of thing that I would do any day to blow off some steam; there is a mood for it. So if you find yourself in the mood to watch The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind but in a form that requires you to read a little more, then pick up To the Moon (there are actually very similar tones between the two works, and the atmospheres line up pretty well too). As a video game it merits a [7 / 10], but as its own genre of entertainment it steals [10 / 10]. Touching on troubling topics and tearducts alike, To the Moon earned its place as a title that everyone should play once and discuss for a long time after.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												To the Moon is one of those works whose very nature places it at a disadvantage. Like a kicker on an American Football team, this genre (which is most satisfactorially described as an "interactive experience") is not comparable to its peers since it doesn't do the same thing they do. But in all fairness its peers likewise cannot match what it does, and you'd better believe it does plenty!The Negs --This title catches you off-guard, withholding the real meat of the gameplay until about 30 minutes in. And even then, that gameplay meat is lean-sliced turkey over a bagel at best. The "interactor" (rather than "player") functions to only move characters from one cutscene to the next. To the Moon could be outright categorized as a point-and-click game if it weren't for the RPG presentation it offers. The story mechanics are sometimes inconsistent, making the goals unclear, which is especially frustrating when all you want to do is get the characters to the next scene of dialogue. This frustration is not extensive though. There were some bugs in places, and sometimes the ground was just too cluttered with vague textures. Quite literally I continually thought the game was freezing on me simply because my character stopped walking when in reality a small flower, not so different in appearance from another small flower that I walk right over, was just blocking my way. The faults of the gameplay were highly bearable, however, mainly because the gameplay was a minor part of this experience.The Pos --Despite all the underwhelming gameplay aspects, this piece held my attention for 5 hours quite easily. The culprit: the characters. Not the main two doctors - I knew about them. What captivated me were the rest of the cast and their unanswered stories. The writing in this game is keen and well-paced, playing coy about the questions it introduces while not leaving the interactor lost for too long. The dialogue ventures into topics that are realistically gritty and gray. This whole experience works in the first place because the user is immersed enough to accept the story and characters at hand. This immersion is influenced by the detailed artwork, which avoided the half-hearted tiling of textures that RPGs are known for, and by the MIND-BLOWING SOUNDTRACK!!!!! I could not give the ost for this work any more laud than it has already received, but if my two cents count for a thing, the music in this game had me consciously framing each scene to its tone, particularly when the music changed mid-scene.The Verd --To the Moon is definitely one to sit down and just experience one day. It is certainly not the sort of thing that I would do any day to blow off some steam; there is a mood for it. So if you find yourself in the mood to watch The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind but in a form that requires you to read a little more, then pick up To the Moon (there are actually very similar tones between the two works, and the atmospheres line up pretty well too). As a video game it merits a [7 / 10], but as its own genre of entertainment it steals [10 / 10]. Touching on troubling topics and tearducts alike, To the Moon earned its place as a title that everyone should play once and discuss for a long time after.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												"In GameSpot's 2011 Game of the Year awards, To the Moon was given the "Best Story" award, which was won against Catherine, Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective, Portal 2, and Xenoblade Chronicles." Also, this game has Metascore rating of 81 which is pretty unusual for some indie pixel art.I've accidentally found this game in my collection, it was purchased in some bundle and became long forgotten. I decided to start it at least once to see what is it about and reduce number of unplayed games on my steam account.And it definitely wasn't a mistake. The game is a great story, presented in a clever way that keeps you interested for straight four hours. I won't lie - there isn't a lot of choice or freedom in this game, it is more of an interactive fiction that tells you about the entire lifetime of one person, so you could grant him a wish he couldn't get in his real life. You just sometimes press buttons to move to the next story point, but it is nicely told, gives you something to think about and with a plot twist. Everything we love about stories.And one more thing: there is no city, but there is a man. And there is a lighthouse.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2013
												A touching journey through the life of Johnny, a man on his deathbed, who has but one wish... to go the moon. Why the moon? That is explored by Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene via a memory device, reminiscent of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. In this case though, the doctors are able to not only view, but take part in the memories.The gameplay is by far the weakest aspect of To the Moon. It is a mixture of finding objects and completing dull puzzles. It's a means to an end, really. At no point would I say the gameplay was enjoyable, but I was compelled to continue by the beautiful story.The story is wonderfully told: it respects the players intelligence, allowing certain realisations to hit quite hard. I still find myself thinking about it, months on. Couple the story with an outstanding soundtrack (seriously, grab the soundtrack edition) and you have something very special.  +Heartfelt story+Great Soundtrack+The doctors have a nice dynamic-Game elements are boring/unnecessary-Movement can be a little awkwardTo the Moon would be better suited to another medium in my opinion. It's definitely not the first time it has been said, but it truly would make a better movie than a game. Even so, buy.

It's all in perspective. But I digress. Get this game. It's a no-brainer. This story is what I can only describe as: one of the few horses that you can't not ride. This, along with TellTales The Walking Dead, and a few others that I can't remember at this late hour, all fall into this stable of must-ride stallions (This joke will make sense once you buy the game). Overall, this game gets, and I can't believe I am saying this, a 10/10. Give FreeBird your money, and dont wait for a sale you cheapskape.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Heart-touching. I've never known a game that could describe such a beautiful story as To The Moon. The music, the atmosphere, the witty dialouge and the heart-melting story of Johnny and River is one that I will not forgot. The ending left me speechless as I was in tears. Never has that happend to me before from a game, nor a movie. The events have made me think about my own life what I should do with it. I found myself relating to Johnny's memories, wishing I had talken a different path. This game is augmented by a breathtaking soundtrack that sets the tone for scenes. The song "For River"/"To the Moon" will be one I listen to over and over while I contemplate my life as I am reminded of this game. This probably sounds very corny, however I speak the truth. Give this game a chance, play it alone and turn up the volume. It will grow on you and you will not forget the story of Johnny and River.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												To The Moon is one of those games you instantly fall in love with. With it's simple, but elegant design, incredible writing, and thrilling, heartfelt tale. Beauty is a perfect word to describe it. The storytelling is masterful, and complex, and charming. The characters are lovable. You play as the two scientists who assist the man in the pursuit of his dream, and often act as the comic relief for emotionally tense situations. Much of the gameplay is a variation between puzzles and "point and click", however, I advise you buy the game on sale, as its only a good solid 3-4 hours when playing normally without guides.To sum eveything up, To the moon is a game I highly reccommend for people who love a detailed and great storyline, while also having a complex and incredible experience of emotions.

This was the most touching story I've ever seen in a game and I would give any amount of money to wipe it from my memory so I could play it again for the first time. 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I've been meaning to get this game for a long time. Now I finally had a chance to actually play it, and I must say I regretted not getting it sooner. There was not a single thing I did not like about To The Moon. The story is well-written, the soundtrack is simply amazing, and the art is fitting. The mechanics could have been better but nothing that's stopping me from thoroughly enjoying the game.John's dying wish is to go to the moon, and the doctors, Eva and Niel, are contracted to fulfill it. To do it, they need to dive into John's memory to find out the cause of that desire. The story uncovers as you gradually dig deeper into John's past one stage at a time. This is a nice reminder that story progression doesn't necessarily means going forward.The puzzle pieces start to fit together as you go, and you get to know more about the characters, all of which are likeable in their own ways. Although, I find it funny that while the story is supposed to revolve around John, I feel like River is the most developed character throughout the story. I slowly started to understand why she acted the way she did, what she really wanted, how her mind worked, and I felt more sympathetic towards her than any other character. But while it's all dramatic and emotional, it is balanced by the constant comic relief mostly by the dialogue exchanges between Eva and Niel.The art isn't at all remarkable but it complements the atmosphere of the story very well and I probably won't have it any other way. Despite the rather low quality, they make up for it by using appropriate visual effects and color schemes. Even the subtle sprite movements, such as the eyes and arms, can show you what the characters are thinking or feeling during certain events. The soundtrack is, like I mentioned earlier, simply amazing. Even the simple piano piece that John wrote for River was very soothing and fun to listen to.Overall, I really enjoyed playing this game and I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a game with good story.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												It's interesting to look back on the days of time I've spent in big sandbox games and realize that-- in terms of experiential memory and fondness-- the five or so heartwrenching hours of To The Moon are still more memorable to me. It's a beautiful game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The story of a man named "John Wyles" and a woman named "River" and a dream...a dream to go to the moon. There are three story acts in 'To The Moon': Act 1 will leave an empty feeling in your heart, Act 2 will answer questions left unanswered and Act 3 will drown your hearts in feelings and emotions that you otherwise were containing as you played. I can't spoil anything besides what is told from presentation here. There has only been a few "games" (well, this is an 'interactive story') out there which could, despite its graphics (it was made on an RPGMaker - it wasn't meant to be innovative; it was meant to be story-rich) which could touch the hearts of people, including me. Although I was not able to sit through this particular gem in one sitting (I can't feel for a game if noises are around me all the time, and thus only play this when it's quiet enough in the middle of the night...it is 5:22 AM as we are writing this and I've finished it.). I have to say that everyone, and I mean everyone, should see this work of fiction for themselves at least once as a gamer (or even just a bystander).9.5/10My overall feelings towards 'To The Moon'...my words do not justify this work enough and encourage anyone reading this to take the trip as I have. If I could, I would have cried sentimental tears.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												For the better part of two years now I've frequently been exposed to opinions that go something like this:"oh em gee, To The Moon is the saddest thing evurrrrr :("Being a naturally trusting person I assumed these people knew what they're talking about. I was somewhat worried going in and expected some sort of shattering experience. By the second half of Act1 I already found myself waiting for a plot twist of sufficient calibre to come by and salvage my expectations of tearjerkiness, but it never did. I am kinda disappointed. Yes, it's an interesting premise and a touching, excellent story but that's it. Although I'm confident it would make one hell of a Hollywood blockbuster if adapted, I found the whole thing barely more emotional than, say... Dear Esther. It's still a great, worthwhile experience, just... don't have particular expectations. Hype is bad mkay.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												This game has been in my library for quite some time, only when a friend recommended this that I started playing it one bored afternoon. I'm quite open to games but nonetheless I honestly thought this game was going to be boring after browsing through the store page. But seeing that it was recommended to me and that it's also got great reviews, I decided to start it. I didn't know what to expect, the game starts off a bit confusing as it's premise was very new to me, and I'm sure it  will be as well for some of you. What caught my attention and....emotions was the characters, their decisions, motivations and story. It all got me curious and I continued on wanting to learn more as I also got attached to them, some scenes are very heartwarming and sweet and others are innocent and depressing. The way the story is laid out in terms of memory links creates a very interesting and strong medium that makes it very easy to relate and observe the characters from. The game was never frustrating and you'll definitely find yourself pausing occasionally, if you're like me that enjoys a good soundtrack whilst revering the scenes and characters.This is certaintly a great game, if you are looking for a great story, short game with a great soundtrack, I'll also highly recommend this to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												To the moon is a very nice 'visual novel' kind of game with a couple of puzzles, but with the main focus on the story.The story is about a dying man that has a final wish (yes, you guessed right, he wants to go to the moon). In this story there is a way to make this happen, but not in a 'story' kind of way, but as if you actually went to the moon.To make this happen two doctors travel backwards through the patients life to find his major 'triggers' that made his life happen the way it happened to ultimately change them to another path.I really enjoyed 'playing' through this game, because the writers not only wrote an excellent story, but also made sure it had emotion, humour and drama.For me this interactive kind of 'books' are a welcome addition to my library.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												To The Moon is a perfect mix of Memento and Inception. The game tells one of the best narratives in any game and although the gameplay is incredibly sparse, it manages to more than compensate with a story that has great depth. The game goes through the memories of the character John in mainly reverse chronological order, similarly to Memento, and as such it reveals more of the true story as the background is revealed and the subsequent events become more clear and meaningful. The soundtrack greatly adds to the experience as well, pulling you into the scene and helping create a greater emotional impact. Overall, it is definitely worth a buy and at around 3 hours for a playtrough, anyone can definitely finish.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Some of the negative reviews, or I should say most, are really petty and aggravating.  People complain about graphics, when graphics have nothing to do with a game at all.  If you get caught up on how many pixels are one the screen, you don't deserve to play a game like this anyway.  The story line is really addictive, the music is peaceful and relaxing, and the gameplay is smooth.  Not only did this game make me laugh on many occasions, it also mad me feel sad, angry, and delighted.  With a great story-line that keeps you wanting more, aesthetically pleasing scenes and artwork, and an ending that is all I can ask for in a game; I would have to say get this game.  Some other people said the $10 is not worth it, and I'll be honest, it might be too much for such a short game.  Though if you are willing to spend a little money on a great game, or can get it on sale, do it!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The following contains NO spoilers:A nicely told love story about an old man... a man... a teen... a boy and a girl... a teen... a woman... an old lady. The story follows two scientists that travel backwards through a man's memories while trying to find a way to input a new memory.I was surprised by the way the developers proved that telling the story backwards was the right way to do it. It's not only a thing of finding out how it all started but also understanding some bits of dialogue that although they didn't seem out of place, you couldn't truly understand at the time (even when you had no idea that they were important)I finished the game in about three hours and the lenght was spot on, it's well paced and frankly really good. Ps: I really think this could become a good short anime series (about 5 or 6 episodes long), I know it hardly has to do with the review, but it's just a thought that came to me.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This is the best story in a video game I have ever experienced.  The story made me feel so many emotions, whether it be laughter from the banter between the two scientists, sadness from the multiple depressing moments, or happiness from the ending.  The soundtrack is brilliant, fitting the scenes perfectly with virtually no lyrics except for the song "Everything's Alright" which appears near the end.  With subtle hints throughout the story, this game's story is just perfect.  The gameplay is weak, mostly just walking and clicking on things.  If you want a short game with an amazing story, buy "To The Moon".  If you want a game with lots of fun features and lots of variety in gameplay, this may not be what you are looking for.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												The music, which has been received very well as far as I've heard (pun!) since its release, alongside the storyline going along themes that people can relate to worldwide no matter the culture and age especially with the underlying themes of the game brings, for this reviewer, a connection or at least the prominent idea of the importance of many things everyone has in common in life--and the simplicity of experiencing existence, and memory.Personally, before playing this game amongst many other things, I felt cloistered and numb to most feelings (primarily due to depression), and coincidentally amongst many other things playing this (or at least listening to the music) helped quite a lot, and felt like breaking this 'shell' of being able to feel less, maybe because of the simplicity of its presentation or the humor [which may be different from person to person, as Dr. Watts can sometimes be a bit too silly], but all these add to the wholeness of detail in the game; lighthearted comic relief, and witty insight in turn. This game would be 'personal' too, on many levels with many people, as far as many reviews can note. Personally, I loved being able to feel--and personally, reflecting on the memory from all exposure within this game brought me to tears.Happy tears.Alongside touching experiences that are coming to society's eyes in recent note (Asperger's/Autism, etc), the game is also presents and showing its stuff rather than telling it all (given the dialogue and such) by letting you experience everything through the eyes of characters themselves, or at least those nearest to them to get their story.The Developers and their team are also very spirited and communicative folks! That's a major plus--including how they treat people, fan and otherwise alike.Would recommend this game fully--alongside recommending it for generations to come. The DLC (including the comic) are also worth the experience! (Wordless--picture only comic)E: My English may not be that good in writing this review! Apologies ahead!

content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												To The Moon is a perfect mix of Memento and Inception. The game tells one of the best narratives in any game and although the gameplay is incredibly sparse, it manages to more than compensate with a story that has great depth. The game goes through the memories of the character John in mainly reverse chronological order, similarly to Memento, and as such it reveals more of the true story as the background is revealed and the subsequent events become more clear and meaningful. The soundtrack greatly adds to the experience as well, pulling you into the scene and helping create a greater emotional impact. Overall, it is definitely worth a buy and at around 3 hours for a playtrough, anyone can definitely finish.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Oh meh god, where do I even start. This game... this game, is a needle in a haystack. What a unique game, I'm very foutunate to use my hard earn money to give this game a shot and what I got back was mixed emotions; as I laughed, cried, smiled, frowned, and all other possible humane facial expressions out there. All because of a typical RPG game running for 4-5 hours about John's or Joey's life. Joey.....Those types of scenes, I couldn't believe that any one espically an indie gaming company can come up with these occurances that can really hit you in the feels. Knowing that John would die at any moment + Eva and Neil doing their job and making sacrifices to fulfull John's last wish + John's childhood + The soundtrack (espically the piano instrumentals and Laura Shigihara's voice of an angel) + The reoccuring rude remarks of Neil + Eva having to deal with all that.... and +...River.... She was basically the icing of the cake in this game for her unique character... As she was limited by her autism, she really made her life complete in both reality and in John's visions. Their relationship is what made this game the most relatable, two different backgrounds and personalities; as they ended up living through the moments together through childhood to death and John's decision to change his memories before he leaves his life, really completed the couple.I cri everitim...Looking for a sequel as promised, Freebird Games... If not, replay levels are over 9000, speaking of over 9000+9000/10

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
To the Moon is a very nice game. Speaking about the genre, it is simple linear quest; speaking about the game itself it is wonderful, sometimes funny and sometimes very touching interactive story. Many people describe it as "visual novel", and I totally agree with that. This is the case when saying "you should play it by yourself" is the best recommendation you can give. Describing the story would ruin the experience; the gameplay mechanics are very simplistic, you can't really say anything about it. Click here, click there, read the dialogs, solve primitive puzzle, move on.What makes me recommend this game are the emotions it gives. Beautiful pixel-art, awesome and very atmospheric soundtrack, very exciting story, bringing tears to the eyes at some moments. You probably won't play that game twice, but the first walkthrough will be unforgettable.To be objective, here are some cons:- The game has no graphic options (or any options, actually) and it runs with fixed resolution and aspect ratio of 4x3 (as far as I can tell). So on a widescreen monitor you'll have big black areas on both sides. Considering its pixel-art style that's very minor issue though.- Some parts of the game seemed to me a little overextended and tedious. But they are rare, and taking into consideration that you can finish the whole game in 3 hours, it is fine.- Controls are not very responsive and sometimes feels a little bit inaccurate. That is actually the only part of the game that frustrated me a little. But again, it isn't huge problem - the game is short and as far as I know you can't lose, so that is minor complaint as well.- The game is a little bit pricey for its length and amount of content. I would recommend to buy it with at least 50% discount.- I've heard about not so great English texts and characters' style of speech. Can't say anything about it because I played the Russian version of the game. But I must say the Russian localization is acceptable at best. I've described my impressions on it in detail below for the Russian users. I'm sure the original version should not be worse than that. :-)I highly recommend this game, if you are searching for a touching story for one evening.------------------------------To the Moon - очень милая игра. По жанру это простенький линейный квест, а по сути - удивительная, очень интересная и местами забавная, местами невероятно трогательная интерактивная история. Многие называют её "визуальным романом", и с этим определением трудно поспорить. Это тот самый случай, когда фраза "в это надо играть" подходит лучше всего. Описывать сюжет - только портить впечатления, механика игры простейшая, по ней тоже сказать нечего. Кликаешь сюда, кликаешь туда, читаешь диалог, решаешь примитивный пазл, идёшь дальше.Что заставляет меня рекомендовать эту игру - так это эмоции, которые она дарит. Красивый пиксель-арт, очень красивая и атмосферная музыка, действительно захватывающий и порой вызывающий ком в горле сюжет. Такую игру вряд ли будешь перепроходить, но первое прохождение оставляет очень сильные впечатления.Чтобы быть объективным, перечислю минусы:- В игре нет графических настроек (как и вообще каких-либо настроек), и работает она при этом с фиксированным разрешением и в соотношении сторон 4х3 (насколько я понял). Следовательно, на широкоформатном экране вы получите большие чёрные области по бокам. Учитывая графический стиль (пиксель-арт), это мелочь.- Некоторые эпизоды игры мне показались немного затянутыми и скучноватыми. Таких моментов немного, а принимая во внимание, что игру можно пройти за 3 часа, это тоже простительно.- Управление не очень чёткое, временами какое-то неинформативное. Это единственная часть игры, которая меня действительно немного напрягала от начала и до самого конца. Но, опять же, игра короткая, и, насколько я знаю, в ней нельзя каким-то образом проиграть, поэтому это также несущественная проблема.- Принимая во внимание небольшое время прохождения и отсутствие реиграбельности, игра дороговата. Я бы советовал приобретать её как минимум с 50%-й (а лучше 75%-й) скидкой.- Русская локализация. Такое ощущение, что перевод, сделанный фанатом игры, был скачан с торрент-трекера. Куча жаргона, совершенно не к месту используемый мат (где-то закрытый сим$%#ами, где-то нет), регулярные ошибки, местами абсолютно не подходящий персонажам стиль речи... К тому же, как выяснилось, если включена русская версия, в конце игры не дают достижение за прохождение. Короче говоря, если английский текст вас не пугает, настоятельно советую поменять язык в настройках игры (в Steam) и играть в оригинал. Справедливости ради, я читал критику и в адрес английских текстов, но уверен, что они не будут хуже локализованных.Если вы ищете интересную историю на один вечер, To the Moon - отличный вариант.

So on a widescreen monitor you'll have big black areas on both sides. Considering its pixel-art style that's very minor issue though.- Some parts of the game seemed to me a little overextended and tedious. But they are rare, and taking into consideration that you can finish the whole game in 3 hours, it is fine.- Controls are not very responsive and sometimes feels a little bit inaccurate. That is actually the only part of the game that frustrated me a little. But again, it isn't huge problem - the game is short and as far as I know you can't lose, so that is minor complaint as well.- The game is a little bit pricey for its length and amount of content. I would recommend to buy it with at least 50% discount.- I've heard about not so great English texts and characters' style of speech. Can't say anything about it because I played the Russian version of the game. But I must say the Russian localization is acceptable at best. I've described my impressions on it in detail below for the Russian users. I'm sure the original version should not be worse than that. :-)I highly recommend this game, if you are searching for a touching story for one evening.------------------------------To the Moon - очень милая игра. По жанру это простенький линейный квест, а по сути - удивительная, очень интересная и местами забавная, местами невероятно трогательная интерактивная история. Многие называют её "визуальным романом", и с этим определением трудно поспорить. Это тот самый случай, когда фраза "в это надо играть" подходит лучше всего. Описывать сюжет - только портить впечатления, механика игры простейшая, по ней тоже сказать нечего. Кликаешь сюда, кликаешь туда, читаешь диалог, решаешь примитивный пазл, идёшь дальше.Что заставляет меня рекомендовать эту игру - так это эмоции, которые она дарит. Красивый пиксель-арт, очень красивая и атмосферная музыка, действительно захватывающий и порой вызывающий ком в горле сюжет. Такую игру вряд ли будешь перепроходить, но первое прохождение оставляет очень сильные впечатления.Чтобы быть объективным, перечислю минусы:- В игре нет графических настроек (как и вообще каких-либо настроек), и работает она при этом с фиксированным разрешением и в соотношении сторон 4х3 (насколько я понял). Следовательно, на широкоформатном экране вы получите большие чёрные области по бокам. Учитывая графический стиль (пиксель-арт), это мелочь.- Некоторые эпизоды игры мне показались немного затянутыми и скучноватыми. Таких моментов немного, а принимая во внимание, что игру можно пройти за 3 часа, это тоже простительно.- Управление не очень чёткое, временами какое-то неинформативное. Это единственная часть игры, которая меня действительно немного напрягала от начала и до самого конца. Но, опять же, игра короткая, и, насколько я знаю, в ней нельзя каким-то образом проиграть, поэтому это также несущественная проблема.- Принимая во внимание небольшое время прохождения и отсутствие реиграбельности, игра дороговата. Я бы советовал приобретать её как минимум с 50%-й (а лучше 75%-й) скидкой.- Русская локализация. Такое ощущение, что перевод, сделанный фанатом игры, был скачан с торрент-трекера. Куча жаргона, совершенно не к месту используемый мат (где-то закрытый сим$%#ами, где-то нет), регулярные ошибки, местами абсолютно не подходящий персонажам стиль речи... К тому же, как выяснилось, если включена русская версия, в конце игры не дают достижение за прохождение. Короче говоря, если английский текст вас не пугает, настоятельно советую поменять язык в настройках игры (в Steam) и играть в оригинал. Справедливости ради, я читал критику и в адрес английских текстов, но уверен, что они не будут хуже локализованных.Если вы ищете интересную историю на один вечер, To the Moon - отличный вариант.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I recommend this game whole-heartedly.  I feel like I should say that before stating that I don't think it's much of a game at all.  There are definitely occasional game elements - puzzles, plants and zombies (oh, I get it now), and I'm very proud of the 97% hit rate I got on whack-a-mole - but To the Moon isn't built around any of that.  To the Moon is simply a story: an intricate, emotionally honest, well-crafted story that is an utter amazement to experience.  The rest of this (non-spoiler) review is entirely about the story.First off: the construction.  I have one criticism here, and it's that the beginning felt like it stretched a bit too long before diving into the meat of the plot.  Other than that, the story is uniformly excellent.  Characters are relatable and flawed and real, and they are expressed organically through the story - shown rather than told.  The pacing of the plot is excellent, as is the rhythm of the frequent beats of humor against the somber moments.  And the overall arc is deftly woven: nothing happens in the end that isn't earned in the beginning, and it is rather amazing how recurring jokes such as the jar of pickled olives are transformed into something far more meaningful by game's end.Second: the content.  At its core To the Moon is a story about the faith required to have any sort of relationship with another human being.  This is not a point that is hammered in; instead it is subtly expressed in moments spread throughout the game.  Moments where a character is lonelier with someone he loves than by himself.  Where a debate is held over the notion that caring for another can also be selfishness.  Where two people with an asymmetric understanding of each other (and aren't all understandings between two people fundamentally asymmetric?) struggle forward into the future based on nothing more than. . . faith.I don't think I can go into any more detail without dipping my toe into spoiler territory, and To the Moon deserves better.  I will say that it feels like the story has changed me, colored my notions of the world in ways I can't quite define.  Any game that does that deserves to be played.I have developed an (unfortunate) habit of including a fairly inane story at the end of my reviews on Steam.  I'm going to pass that up in favor of - again - simply recommending that you enjoy the story of To the Moon.  Here's an attempt at a topical haiku instead!-----------------------------------------The moon is an eyeAlways watching from aboveNothing else sees all------------------------------------------Yeah, you do better.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												To great heights, some lows, and lukewarm destinations.RPGMaker, we meet again. As a foreword, I have a personal distaste for RPGMaker games, as a lot of the games developed with the engine tend to reuse a lot of stock assets, and To the Moon is no different in that regard. To its credit, it does use a lot of unique assets, but the overall vibe I get from the game is that it would be much better if it was developed on a different platform.The premise of To the Moon is a simple one. You are tasked with overseeing two doctors with a simple mission - to make a dying man's dream come true. Tragedy, romance, it's all there as you journey back through his memories to make his wish come true. The doctors are the facilitator of this, and they're more like dream technicians. And to be fair, they are the weakest part of the story. The two of them can be typecast as the straight (wo)man and the fool, which is my biggest complaint. Too often they interject their discourse into an intimate moment with no tact or subtlety whatsoever, which often ruins the mood. The rest of the game is incredibly well-written EXCEPT for the people you play as. The dying man's memories are way more interesting than listening to a neurotic's caffeine addiction or his complaints. I'm guessing it's written like so because it's "another hohum job" for them to do and that it's a simulation, but they come off as tactless. Outside of those two knuckleheads, the plot and story as a whole still manages to stay strong. There are also a couple of mini-episodes included with the game, but they're more fluff than anything, designed to give more of an insight to the background technology of the main story.As much as the visual medium of the game requires it, the RPGMaker graphics are servicable. There are some unique art pieces here and there, but it's acceptable for what it is. But once you've seen those trees and ground textures in one game, you'll see it everywhere else.Where the game really shines, however, is the soundtrack. The piano-heavy ballads and melodies have that right amount of melancholy and nostalgia to stick with you and make the scenes feel more impactful. When music is absent, the mood turns coarse and heavy. Where the graphics fail, the sound design helps to ease over the lackluster presentation into something more palpable.With all of those points in mind, the story is rather short and concise as most people can finish it through one sitting. As much as I was looking forward to playing this, I can't help but feel underwhelmed, and not of any fault to anything else but the mystique around it. The game is not perfect, far from it. It has its flaws and moments of heavy-handed writing. Even so, it's not a bad game. It tugs at the heartstrings at the right times and even made me well up at times.Ultimately, your mileage will vary. Some will cherish it far more than others, who might leave it as a cute story. For the price point it's at, you honestly can't go wrong.7/10.

Controls are awkward (don't even try playing it on controller, although it does work), and irritating...So, after all that, why do I recommend it...Because it has a beautiful and touching story... And interesting soundtrack... But story is, just fantastic, and it is a game that should really be played for it...To bad, it doesn't shine on graphical and UI fronts, because it could've been a masterpiece...

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Breathtakingly beautiful.I have just finished playing through To The Moon and I'm still shaken from the experience. I was in tears for a good 30 minutes. It's hard to describe why it affected me the way it did, just as it's hard to write a review/recommendation for this game.At it's core To The Moon is a very simplistic game. You walk around clicking the spacebar to find out about certain objects or to go through hours of dialogue that this game has to offer. That's it.However, this is some of the finest, best, most emotionally touching dialogue I've ever seen in any game, ever. The themes of death, love, loss, disease and inner battle are all addressed so well, it's actually quite surprising. It proves that video games stand on their own as a wonderful method of storytelling, because this story couldn't be told through another medium.As you can read on the Steam page it tells the story of two doctors trying to fulfill a dying man's wish. The pair travel backwards through his memories to see how they alter the future to make his dream come true... And that's all that can be said without spoilers.Unfortunately this means I'm going to have to leave this "recommendation" on a simple "trust me" basis.So, trust me, this is a game you want to experience.These are three hours of your time that will impact an touch you emotionally in a way you probably haven't experienced in a game before.And lastly, this game will really make you think about your life and your choices.There is no one I wouldn't recommend this game to. Even if I don't know you personally, I still want you to buy this game and let it affect you the way it affected me. Hope this convinced you to purchase and play through this brilliant story telling masterpiece.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												9.5/10I've always thought indie games were just the cheap way of making a game and after this game, I lost that view entirely. I bought this because it was on sale and I wanted to try something new and short. I did not expect this game to be as great as it was and only started it out of boredom. I'm so glad I did. **The reason my hours are shorter than most is because it was played on offline mode most of the time**The story is unique with many plot twists. The company doesn't put too much work into gameplay because it's the story you are supposed to focus on. If you expect it to be a full shooting and destroy everything game, you'll get a few puzzles for your enjoyment. You play as Johnny and has a very quiet wife, and although she doesn't say much she is one of the most loving characters in the game. The graphics are also quite nice in an indie way. You CANNOT play this game in long breaks, it's one you'd want to continue and even if you didn't, the ending is cute so go play to the end anyways. I've recommended this game to three people so far, and all three love and enjoyed it as much as I did. It's simplistic gameplay with a strong story makes one amazing game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Time spent: 4.6 hours from December 23 to 26 (at almost midnight!) This review however is done at around 12 am on Dec 27.To the Moon is a highly crafted and excellent art game. Its key points are its story and music, which are both well made and very engaging. Starting off with the art design, it feels like a retro RPG with pixel art and illustrations. These things are not terribly different from other games, but drives the point of the story very well. It can feel a bit bland and like a freeware RPG, but the art is for the most part stylized with the pixel art style and great art pieces with a good retro effect and being well connected to the story.Next up is the music. From the start in the title screen, the music is already carrying emotion to it, and the entire soundtrack is done very well. The music carries an instrumental feel with some more ambient or whimsical touches depending on the current mood. Laura Shigihara does have a track in this game, and it also has great emotion and musical quality to it. By carrying emotion and being well composed, the soundtrack of this game is very good and drives emotion in tandem with the story.Last is the critically acclaimed story. Like most people say and what I did, go into this game without reading any spoilers. The game does make you sad like others say, but also laugh, smile, and keep you on the edge of your seat. Without giving any potential spoilers, it is a well done story with many captavating moments for an excellent game. The gameplay is more like a visual novel rather than a pure RPG. Exploration is the bulk of the game, which is good to drive the story and keep you engaged. Now and then, some other gameplay is given like puzzles to break up the story flow a bit. Although the gameplay isn't much, the story is the game's main attraction that is worth the experience for.To the Moon has to be played to experience it in its glory without breaking it with spoilers. The music and story are strong in this game that they evoke many emotions from start to finish. It gives an amazing experience that people should really try out, for its story and music are well crafted in a kind of RPG visual novel.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Honestly before you read this review consider that I have been playing it for 4 hours straight because I got so caught up in the story.First of all the story, kudos to the guy who wrote it. Although it was confusing in the end it all made sense and it turned out to be a very nice story.Second of all the music, very well chosen and it's worth listening to. Even somewhere in the middle of the game I recall I heard a women singing a song and I really want to know what her name is so I can lookup more music from her.Next we have the main characters, the two mains were really the classic combo that this game could use. One of them is very serious and the sentimental type and the other one is the joker, although another side gets revealed later on in the game. At one moment I really felt that I want to scold the gamemakers for one of the decisions made by one of the main characters. But after completing it I felt different and felt like it was better that way.Unfortunately the movement was a bit wonky. Either decide between using point to click or moving with keys but don't use both in a game. Another small downside is that there are some repetitive mini games in the game itself. I found that annoying honestly.But if you want to play a game with a pretty good story with a twist I consider you to pick it up for the cheap price it is.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A little game that could, To The Moon proves that even with humble beginnings one can surpass the best in so many ways that really matter. It's not held back by its RPG Maker roots, short of iffy controls at times because of mouse implementation, and is one of the rare games made with it that actually show just how much can be done when motivated people take things seriously. There is little in terms of gameplay and the game handles like an on-rails adventure, but the story is what truly sells it. I think the highest praise I can actually sing about To The Moon's story is that it's one of very few games that, as far as I remember at least, actually made me take a deliberate break just to process everything. Subject at hand is handled masterfully and emotions overflow throughout the game as things fall into place - so much so that if it doesn't stir SOMETHING in you by the bitter and yet extremely satisfying ending, you've probably completely missed the point. Or you're not a human being.

												This game is so very touching. It's not realistic or logical (but it's not meant to be either).It plays like a dream. Imagine how dreams can be rather senseless and illogical, but have that special, mystical feeling to them? Well, that is how this game feels like.This is not to say that the story doesn't make sense, because it does (for the most part).So the story takes off with a patient (i.e. Johnny) at old age - on his deathbed - and wanting to fulfil his desire of going to the moon.But how on earth is a man of such age to achieve such a thing?Well, that's where a brilliant duo of doctors (aka Dr. Neil Watts & Eva Rosalene) come in.They specialize in the art of memory-alteration, through use of a sophisticated machine, which is then connected to a patient's head - via a helmet - so as to grant them access to their patients' memory and alter their memories (as needed).The game is played in a chronological, linear fashion (meaning, there's a certain routine to follow), which involves hopping from memory to memory, by interacting with mementos (i.e. items of sentimental value to the patient) which serve as a 'bridge' between one memory and the next & triggers the time-travelling process, within the patient's mind.It's interesting to note however, that time-travel occurs in a backwards fashion (meaning, as you play you get to see the patient at old age first, and then hop back in time to a younger version - again & again - till a certain age is reached).This is done for the purpose of creating a point of 'ignition' (in regard to Johnny's end-life desire of 'going to the moon'), meaning; the two doctors look for an ideal timeframe within Johnny's past to alter his memories, so as to encourage the fulfilment of his dream.Mementos (encountered within the patient's mind) have to be 'activated' in order for them to serve as a 'link' to a specific memory. This is achieved by touching them & going thru a process of solving a mini-puzzle.The puzzle is of the 'tile'-type (where tiles are flipped in a methodical way so as to have them form an image - this is always an image of whichever memento is being worked on at that moment).Also; these mementos are wrapped inside a protective bubble and have to be 'released' thru a certain mechanism, which is achieved thru the collection of so-called 'orbs' scattered across any area (i.e. school, home, yard, etc., ... ) that is up for exploration within the patient's mind.Whether or not Johnny's dream is eventually achieved is left for the player to find out at the end of the game (no awful cliffhanger there, phew!).The way the story ends, does make way for yet another episode (and hopefully this will be the case!).There was such clever use of sound, music and words that created a beautiful experience and atmosphere maintained throughout the whole game.Admittedly... it had me crying. The music, the story... the characters. Ahh... I love when a game has that effect on me - that's why I ultimately play - to have a good time. And I sure did!NB I played this game with a Steam buddy and that impacted my experience positively (it's one of those games that serves as a great way to bond and share the many 'feels' evoked by the story).UPDATE - NOMINATION:This game should be nominated because:- the plot in itself is very endearing (i.e. clever use of sound, music, scenarios)- the plot unfolds in a very original manner- it touches upon real-life issues with a fun sci-fi twist- gets you thinking about life, stimulates the mind & pulls quite a bit of heartstrings!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Like many others, I bought this game because so many of my friends insisted it was a masterpiece. At first, I thought I'd made a mistake: while it had an interesting beginning, it seemed to go downhill from there. Up until the end of Act 1, the gameplay was repetitive and, of course, the story didn't make sense at the time.Act 2 and beyond changed all that. Suddenly, the story made sense! The story and the meaning behind it pieced themselves together in such a beautiful manner and in a way that I had never expected. Initially, I thought that going through a story backward was gimmicky and would make the story incredibly convoluted, but it didn't. Going through the story in the way it's presented gives everything new shades of meaning. It essentially functions as foreshadowing in reverse and it's incredibly effective. You see the pieces of a man and a woman's life come together. It's so interesting because you know where they end up before you know all those tender or tense moments that led up to them coming together.By the time the story had ended and the game was over, my heart was officially touched. The characters I had thought a little boring at first grew as characters by the end. Every single character had personality, even the minor characters that the main story isn't about. To me, the ending was satisfying. It brought up ethical issues over what the doctors in the game were doing and those issues are brought to light even further in the holiday special. To some, it's probably a happy ending, but to others it's bound to be a concerning ending. It all depends on how you feel about the events as they unfold.I have zero regrets about purchasing this game. It's been over a week since I've played it, and even just thinking about the game fills me with happiness and reminds me of all the great moments the game had. The story, the music, the humor and charm behind the game -- all of it creates such a positive experience that I honestly don't feel words are enough for it.Sure, this game isn't for everyone, but even if it's not your cup of tea, you'll probably get something out of the experience. And, even if it turns you didn't like it in the end, it's obvious how much love Kan Gao and his staff put into this game. It's definitely a game worth getting.

												Where do I start... At first, I thought this game was just going to be some cheap indie that wasn't fully functional and had very little detail to the story... Boy was I wrong about everything.Synopsis: The game is based around Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts who are employees of a company that goes by the name Sigmund Corp, the whole idea behind the Sigmund Corp is Fulfilling the wish of those on their death bed using technology that is capable of constructing artificial memories, and their challenge of fulfilling Johnny's wish of going to the moon. Throughout the story, you meet some quite extravagant and lovable characters, such as River. As the story progresses, you can't help but feel distraught about the struggle that River and Johnny had gone through in their life. If you're a fan of Indie RPG's with a hint of Adventure, Mystery and Drama, I really recommend you try this game out :). The genres work well together which ultimately makes the ending of this game a work of art which I absolutely loved.9/10

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												To The Moon is beautiful. It is not about the visual itself that is beautiful but rather, how the story is presented. In this game, you play as two scientist/doctors who have have a very peculiar job, in which they give people another chance to live, all the way from the very beginning... but only in their patients' heads.In this game, they are tasked in fulfilling the dream of an elderly man, Johnny, who last wish is, obviously, to go to the moon. In order to grant these wishes that the duo needed to travel within Johnny's memory in order to rewrite it according to his wish, all the while learning on why he wanted that wish in the first place.The gameplay for this game is minimal at best. While using the 16-bit JRPG visual from RPG Maker, it is definitely not a RPG game. It strip down any reference to a RPG and can be more related to a Point-and-Click game, or a visual novel. They only gameplay it has is mostly memento finding and some puzzle solving and even then, it is simple.While it lacks in gameplay, it definitely make up in the story, which is told in reverse. It starts with Johnny on his deathbed, with more explained through his memories. As you learn more about your client, you will definitely feel more attached to him and starting to understand his feelings. Through this, various emotions such as joy and sadness can be felt by the players themselves, especially once they understand the whole story in the end. To put it in simpler words: The story is awesome.The game soundtrack is also very beautiful. Nothing can be said to the soundtrack besides the fact it fits the story very much. It does not only fits it but also enhance the experience of the game very much, making it very memorable.To The Moon is definitely not just a game. It is a storytelling medium in the form of a video game, and definitely one piece of evidence in showing that video game can be an art.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												English Review :"To The Moon is a briliant simple game"Previously, several game sites rate this game for its beautiful story. And the game won awards for an indie game category. Come with curiosity, I'll tried the game ... and ... To The Moon becomes one of the melancholy and emotional game I've ever played. There is laugh, there is love, there is sad and sacrifice. Sometimes the game make me smile, sometimes make me sad and cry. For a game, To The Moon becomes one of a tearjerker title that ever exist.This simple game had premise with a sci-fi element become complex & brilliant from the begining. There is a dying old man had a one last wish before he die, he want to go to the moon. So this is a job for Dr. Rosalene & Dr. Watts, they can enter the memory of the patient looking for memory fragment and manipulate it. From the present time to the past until his child era. Reverse driven-story like this, remind me of a french movie directed by Gaspar Noe entitled Irreversible. For the gameplay, this one made by RPG Maker engine but diffrent. This is not a Fantasy RPG like the other one. But becomes an adventure game with briliant soundtracks and story-driven plot. Characterization in this game is so powerful and can give an emotional impact to player. Maybe, if this one not a game. Plot of this game can be a novel. And I can predict, its become a best seller title. But, if this one become a movie. I can predict, its become a box office movie which won several award if made seriously.Rating : 10/10 - "A Perfect Game"Indonesian Review :"To The Moon adalah game sederhana dengan kemasan dan isi yang sangat brilian."Sebelumnya banyak yang mengatakan bahwa game ini memiliki cerita yang sangat bagus. Dan juga menang beberapa award untuk kategori game indie. Dengan rasa penasaran, sayapun mencobanya ... dan ... To The Moon, menjadi salah satu game paling melankolis dan sangat emosional yang pernah saya mainkan. Ada tawa, ada suka, ada duka, ada cinta maupun pengorbanan. Beberapa kali sempat tersenyum dengan plot jenaka, namun di adegan yang lain mampu membuat air mata menetes. Untuk kategori games, To The Moon mampu menjadi salah satu tearjerker yang pernah ada.Premis cerita game berbau Sci-Fi ini sangat sederhana namun eksekusinya menjadi sangat kompleks dan brilian. Seorang pasien lelaki tua yang sudah akan meninggal dunia memiliki permintaan terakhir dimana dia ingin pergi ke bulan. Dan ini merupakan pekerjaan dari Dr. Rosalene dan Dr. Watts dimana mereka bisa masuk ke dalam pikiran si pasien mencari kepingan memori dan memanipulasinya. Dari masa tua, sampai kembali ke masa lalu di masa anak-anak si pasien. Cerita yang berjalan mundur ini, mengingatkan saya pada film perancis yang pernah disutradari oleh Gaspar Noe yang berjudul Irreversible. Plot cerita di film itu berjalan terbalik.Untuk masalah gameplay, game ini dibuat dengan engine RPG Maker namun sangat berbeda. Ini sama sekali bukan game fantasy rpg, seperti yang ada kebanyakan. Namun menjadi game adventure yang dibumbui dengan soundtrack serta plot cerita yang brilian. Bukan hanya itu, karakterisasi tokoh yang cukup kuat mampu memberi impact yang kuat terhadap player secara emosional. Mungkin jika tidak menjadi game, plot cerita di game ini mampu diangkat menjadi sebuah Novel yang saya prediksi bisa menjadi Best Seller. Dan jika menjadi sebuah film mampu juga mendapatkan Box Office maupun Award jika digarap secara serius.Rating : 10/10 - "Game Sempurna"

Posted: July 26, 2014
												Most people think this is a "game." To the Moon is actually a project where psychologist and game developers collaborated and created a test to find out if an individual is a sociopath. Didn't feel like crying at the end? Didn't recommend the game? Found the game boring and lackluster? CONGRATULATIONS! You're a sociopath!Also some might say the game lacked "gameplay." These are just upset people who could not get 100% playing whack-a-mole. It's alright! Being a sociopath and bad at PC gaming isn't the end of the world. After all, you don't even have feelings. While this game…er…test can be boring, you can just quit and focus the extra time on acquiring things like empathy and remorse. Good luck!

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												To The Moon is beautiful. It is not about the visual itself that is beautiful but rather, how the story is presented. In this game, you play as two scientist/doctors who have have a very peculiar job, in which they give people another chance to live, all the way from the very beginning... but only in their patients' heads.In this game, they are tasked in fulfilling the dream of an elderly man, Johnny, who last wish is, obviously, to go to the moon. In order to grant these wishes that the duo needed to travel within Johnny's memory in order to rewrite it according to his wish, all the while learning on why he wanted that wish in the first place.The gameplay for this game is minimal at best. While using the 16-bit JRPG visual from RPG Maker, it is definitely not a RPG game. It strip down any reference to a RPG and can be more related to a Point-and-Click game, or a visual novel. They only gameplay it has is mostly memento finding and some puzzle solving and even then, it is simple.While it lacks in gameplay, it definitely make up in the story, which is told in reverse. It starts with Johnny on his deathbed, with more explained through his memories. As you learn more about your client, you will definitely feel more attached to him and starting to understand his feelings. Through this, various emotions such as joy and sadness can be felt by the players themselves, especially once they understand the whole story in the end. To put it in simpler words: The story is awesome.The game soundtrack is also very beautiful. Nothing can be said to the soundtrack besides the fact it fits the story very much. It does not only fits it but also enhance the experience of the game very much, making it very memorable.To The Moon is definitely not just a game. It is a storytelling medium in the form of a video game, and definitely one piece of evidence in showing that video game can be an art.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
Get on the Feel-Train!Normally I do not play those "little" (2D) games, but I thought that this game won't dissappoint me, when it is on sale - And I was right.(without spoiling) "To the Moon" is about the dying, old man John Wyles who has the last wish to fly to the moon. The two scientists Dr. Roselene und Dr. Watts have an equipment with which they are able to project a memory in John's mind - to fullfill his dream. And while the two doctors put together the puzzle pieces of John's life, they try to figure out why the old man just wants such a thing as a last wish.At the beginning the story is a little bit confusing but that disappears after some time - so don't get unmotivated!++ beautiful story++ very nice soundtrack (worth to buy)+ nice design+ funny elements+ unexpected changes+ feel-train+ worth the moneybad aspects:- really short (4-5 hours)- the humor is sometimes a bit exaggerated- first and maybe also the second hour is a bit "slow"- 1 achievement (will only unlock if you play the last part in english)To conclude:"To the Moon" is one of the best Indie-Games in my opinion! This game actually triggered something in me, what made me think about it. But not for a hour. No. I was so touched, that a week later, it still brought tears into my eyes. I would be really happy if somebody of YOU will buy this to share this nice experience. A game which is beautiful and sad at the same time deserves: 8,5/10

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I didnt think much of this when i first saw it in my library, thought it was just a plain rpg the same as all the other rpg's.But when i started playing it i was just blown away because the music is so thought through and is very considerate when it comes to the actual history of the game. I was totally blown away by the brilliant and delicate music and history of this great little rpg game.I have played through the story twice, and gonna go for my thierd time aswell. The emotions that builds up while playing this game, just forces you to shed some tears for especially one of the characters. The fine balance between too much and too little story-play is so fine tuned you rarely see such a good of a story in other games, both of this genre, and other.This recieves a good 10\10 from me, and 10\10 would definately play it over, and over, and over.Kudos to the developers of this game who truly knows how to make and tell a good story, and a big kudos to the music composer. This was truly a experience i would love to relive again not knowing what to expect.Warning: do not play through this in public, because you will shed some, if not many tears playing this game !

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												To the Moon will be a memorable game for me. I was brought to it by the soundtrack and recommendations of people that enjoyed it as well. First of all, it's a point and click game, which can make it a little boring at times, and the controls and resolution options can be a little wonky. The small amount of puzzles were quite simple. The whole game is easy, but i really don't think the difficulty is the point of this game; rather, its strength lies in its story and character. The story kept me going even when i got bored of it, and there is just the right amount of suspense and curiousity in it. Perfect amount of suspense, because in the end it all fit perfectly. I got rather attached to the characters and setting. I finished this game in about 5 hours, so i will tell you this game is definitely worth your time, short playthrough as it is. This game is worth the odds. :)
