content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												So, you're on the fence about buying "To the Moon." It's understandable, money doesn't just grow on trees. But, let's pretend you've got some money floatin' around, and you're looking for something good, something stimulating, but most importantly, something relatively cheap."To the Moon" is the game for you.Assuming the ending hasn't already been spoiled for you, this game will lead you through a (mostly) text-based adventure, wih plenty of twists that will more than likely cause you to finish it in one sitting. However, the brief nature of the game detracts nothing from the story - and believe me, the story is worth experiencing.If you're looking for something to think about, something to make you feel, or just something to immerse yourself in, "To the Moon" is a great game with plenty of suprises, incredible characters, and superb writing that will pull you inside it's world. This is one of the few games that I can truly say is worth playing and experiencing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												This game i would recommend to any gamer that likes a good story since this have exactly just that. The story is well written with a good OST. Many that played this game have gotten emotional after the ending or right out cry just like me.The story is about an old man on his deathbed and his wish is to as the title of the game implies to the moon. Your job is to fullfill that artificially, by doing that you have to dive into his memories to find the reason as to why. You start with his memories when he is a old man then as you progress you get to the memories of when he is in his 50s and then 40s and then 30s and so on. But the further back you go the more you learn about him but you also learnt something that will change the whole thing. Well i won't spoil it, you got to play it for yourselves in order to understand.Pros:- Really good story- Simple but interestingly smooth- Beautiful OST. You get the feels each time you hear the OST again just like Key Visual Art's game.Cons:- Not a game for anyone that doesn't play games for a good story.- Can take some time to get into.9.5/10 This game is a hidden gem. If it had a high budget or got a remake with a much better engine i believe this game would get a lot of attention.P.S this game is 3-4 hours long.

												Ahhh, To The Moon. The single best game I have ever had the great honour to have the privilege of playing. Such a short game, and yet so many hours I have spent replaying the masterpiece. To even call it a game is an insult to the perfection radiating from it. To anybody who understands this reference (The Fault In Our Stars), I understand how Hazel felt about the ending to An Imperial Affliction. I need to find out what happens; to Lily, to Neil and Eva, to the *platypus*. I cannot wait for Finding Paradise, despite it being a different patient, we still get Neil and Eva, and their story gets to continue. I can only hope that they get a happy ending as well.

content:
Posted: February 15
 To The Moon	 Pros:	+ Soundtrack: Loved the music to the game. It always seemed to fit the moment.+ Funny: I found myself being very amused by the game more than I thought I would be.+ A nice change from the violent games. + A story that will mess with your emotions.+ Comes with two free mini-stories. Cons:	- Wish there was more. Not a complaint, I was just sad when it ended and I wanted it to keep going. Review	     I was always hesitant to buy this game. It's hard for me to find a good story game that I can really get into, but this game is truly my favorite pure story game that I have ever played. If you have ever been in love then this game will probably make you emotional... It didn't help that I bought and played this on Valentine's day... This game has it's lighthearted moments and it's heart breaking moments. I highly suggest buying this game on sale and if you can't wait then buy it full price. If you are going to play this you should put on headphones and focus on the game so you can get into it. Trust me, this is worth your time and money. If you disliked the review leave comment and tell me why. Thank you for reading my review. content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												"To The Moon" is an indie story-telling game.  It wants you to experience the events through The Good+ Deep Story-telling experience using 2d RPG-style gameplay with cute nostalgic pixel art+ Soundtracks+ Characters were fun and sometimes can be relatable.The BadThe game really has no major problems since it is focused on story. So the following are probably minor issues that I think could've been improved for perfect game design.- The controls are not customizables and are configured weirdly. For one thing, you can move the character using the ARROW keys on keyboard. That feels awkward when you want to use the mouse as well (since the mouse can be used to highlight the items you can interact with).(UPDATE) There is a way to customize the keys by pressing F1 during playing.- Character movement on the level is stiff. When you press once on an ARROW key to move, the character will move precisely one tile for example. You can't stop in mid movement so sometimes it feels hard to take turns.- Gamepad uses analog only. Would have been a lot better with D-PAD option.Final VerdictI highly recommend this game if you are interested in story. It is not a long game and might take you 4-6 hours at most. So you could probably think of this game as an interactive pixel art movie. If you are looking for gameplay only, then I do not recommend you to get this game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												On the surface, To The Moon is a story about a spaceship that needs a crew. You, the player, alternate between two scientists on a quest to assemble a rag-tag team of ne'er-do-wells and get them into flight-ready form. To The Moon chooses for you which scientist you control at any given moment, but the distinction is arbitrary; there are no skills to use, or unique capabilities among them. This is not to say that each scientist is without personality, as one approaches the mission with callousness (albeit humorously), and the other assumes a more calculated, matriarchal role.Admittedly, most, if not all, of the story centers around Johnny. Johnny, a grown♥♥♥♥♥man with a child's name, is needed for the space mission, and can be viewed as the antagonist. Johnny approaches the critical NASA mission with a will-he-or-won't-he mindset, as he is but a man encumbered by a hard life, and  the demons that come with it.Though the game is relatively short (six-ish hours), it can be said that the game is exactly the length that it needs to be. For that, you are rewarded a rich experience, that will maybe culminate in the game's only achievement: Will Johnny get to the moon? Is Johnny capable of reconciling with an estranged wife? Can he unbind himself from the shackles that tether him to Earth? It's up to you to decide.

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, I really truly did.During the big sale I saw that To The Moon was only $2 and snatched it up right away because I'm cheap. For the years I've known about the game I've heard nothing but great things about it, and while my expectations weren't high, even things I didn't have standards for were disappointing.The gaming mechanics were terrible, within the first ten minutes I had to navigate my way to the house because I kept bumping into flowers. A flower blocked my path. And this continued for most of the game, small objects blocking my way and I couldn't tell what would block me and what wouldn't. Lining up to interact was also hard as most things were off-center.The pacing was entirely too fast, I get that it's a short game, but there was no time to take anything in. Most of the gameplay is walking around and interacting with things hoping to find orbs to break an orb to do a puzzle to get 2 minutes of "character development" (I use that VERY loosely) and you do it over again.  This lasts for 16 memories.  There's literally nothing else to do in this time.The humor and dialogue between the doctors is extremely weak. For 2011 omnomnom and weaboo jokes were probably the norm and funny, but in 2016 I'm just cringing. Neil is extremely unlikeable and it got to the point where I started skipping most if not all of his dialogue because I couldn't stand to listen to him anymore.The horse part with no explanation kept me trapped for a good five minutes,  as did the Zombievas. I didn't realize I could keep using the attacks and got trapped in a corner, incredibly frustrated. The way the game treated River was also pretty terrible.  She had autism yet they talked about her as if she were a bug. With her "condition" and if she would ever be "normal" and to tiptoe around her, I hated John for most of it because he refused to try and understand his wife. He was offered many opportunities to understand her autism and what it meant for her socially, but refused the help. All he wanted was a nice "normal" wife and you could see him get frustrated with River for a mental disability she couldn't control or help. I couldn't take their love story at all seriously because John was such a terrible husband to River. She's autistic, possibly high functioning, talk to her for once instead of hoping it'll just disappear. I just couldn't feel any emotion for anyone because of all these things. I'm disappointed that I didn't like the game as much I thought I would, however I'm glad I only paid $2 instead of the full $10, it's definitely NOT worth $10.However, the pros are: The music is wonderful and River was the only character with somewhat of a personality and she was the only character I could really feel for, despite John constantly bringing her down. If I'd replay this for any reason, it'd be to study River's character more.Update after playing the minisodes: Even more boring and a waste of time, none of the characters developed and the open ended ending  with the possibility of Eva dreaming it all  was extremely underwhelming because nothing was done with it. There's a million unanswered questions and there's never going to be answers to them. I played out of curiosity when I should've just left it alone.

number of helpful: 27 of 52 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												I really tried to like this game; I had heard nothing but praise towards this for years so finally this sale I decided it was time to get it but I really just did not like it at all. So here is why:First lets start with the surface level reasons, the stuff that hurts enjoyment but could be looked over by those who enjoy it:Controls: The controls are just plain bad, if you use the keyboard the map is designed in a grid (as in 1 press up goes one block) however the actual design of the area does not make this clear, causing keyboard controls to feel floaty, as if when you let go of the button the character will continue moving until they reach the next grid block. The mouse controls a little better with characters auto moving to where you click, but when switching surfaces or rooms they will randomly stop despite having more to move towards; overall it just controls poorly.Art Style: I know this one is just an opinion and I'm sure many will disagree but I just really don't like the art style; I can't really put a finger on why but it just rubs me the wrong way.So now for the more pressing reasons why I don't like this:Dialogue: This game isn't funny; the character's say cutesy jokes and puns so so often (especially Dr. Watts) but they just arent funny, I cringed through so much of it. Overtime these characters progress and make jokes less often but it just feels like a blatantly obvious way of showing chracter progression, take a bland character and make them say jokes then stop saying jokes and it will make it feel like they differed greatly.Emotion: All of the big emotional moments felt pointlessly manipulative; often having important bits of information or character motivation hidden simply for a twist later.Theme: I also disagree with the point the game tries to push about manipulating the past to be happy but I wont go into detail because spoilers.Ludonarrative Dissonance: The primary gameplay mechanic is finding these glowing orbs to go deeper into memories, but how does wandering around looking for glowing orbs relate to the themes of manipulating the past or memories what so ever? These things are completely arbitrary, if there aren't enough inspectable objects in the room to attach orbs to the game will literally just give you them for walking around.Overall I really disliked this game, I really wanted to like it, and I have heard nothing but positive regard from others but I just cannot see why. And it isn't just a matter of me not usually playing this sort of game, all of my favorite games are the artsy slow type that your 'average gamer' would hate (Her Story, Gone Home, Pathologic, etc) but this just did not click with me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												A recommendation isn't enough for this game, simply put, it's a masterpiece. It deals with the subjects of death, tragedy, buried memories and so much more and although some of the twists may be pretty easy to guess, the way in which the story is told ensures that this does not lower the quality of the game whatsoever. Easily the greatest element to this game though, is the way it creates emotion in the player. The humour is top notch, when something good happens for someone you are genuinely happy for them and most of all, this game is SAD. I have seen many different reactions about the ending, personally, I think it's tragic, but it works and it brings the game to a fantastic close.Presentation wise, the first thign you may notice is that the graphics are very similar to the style of the SNES (in my opinion, it is particularly reminiscent of Chrono Trigger). This works perfectly and after playing through the game, I can't imagine it with another art style. However, despite all this, the one thing I haven't mentioned yet is easily the games greatest asset, which is saying a lot considering everything else. The music in this game is just... stunning, probably my favourite soundtrack of all time, or at least in the last few years. A great mixture of instruments, mainly piano, adds to the games already fantastic environment, and each song sets the tone amazingly and is absolutely perfect for what is happening in the game. Should you buy it? If you're a fan of heavily story based games, then yes and if not, give it a go anyway. 10/10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Initially, I didn't think that I would like To the Moon. But I soon found myself being enthralled by this short story.To give a quick summary: In the world of To the Moon, the Sigmund Corporation has created a device to alter the memories of patients. You follow Dr. Rosalena and Dr. Watts as they try to fulfill a dying old man's wish to go to the moon.While the plot can be a bit sappy and predictable at times, it was a nice blend of melancholy and comedy throughout the 3 hours it took to play through. I also found that Johnny's story was incredibly relatable. But what kept me hooked the most was the writing and devlopment of Rosalena and Watts. To the Moon is an excellent short game that can leave an impact on you. It makes you realize that life is just a giant collection of memories, and it's so easy to miss out on a lot of the small details.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												This game tugs at the heart strings; who would have thought that a pixel game reminscent of Dragon Quest and other point-and-click games can? The witty banter between our scientist duo Eva and Neil makes for more personal characters as well as the curious wish of Johnny. With nods to various pop culture references and puns, the script as well as plot is what keeps you interested.The music is lovely, definitely recommend buying the game + OST bundle. My own negative was the lag but then again, could be my laptop. Otherwise, please check this game out!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												What do Roadkill, a dying man and zombies have in common? Nothing! And yet To The Moon crafts these elements together to form such a seamless and beautiful experience that will remain with you long after the credits roll.To the Moon follows the story of two scientists whose role is to visit the dying, and alter their memories of their life so that they can die fulfilled. In this instance, they visit a comatose old man, "Johnny", whose final wish is to visit the moon - the only issue is that he has no idea why he wants to do so. Admittedly this may sound depressing, but the dialogue between the two scientists is refreshingly full of humour to keep things perky.To The Moon is an absolute masterpiece of a game - the soundtrack is unique and accompanies the story perfectly, and although the graphics are in 16 bit style and the actual 'gaming' aspect of it is more point-and-click than anything, none of this detracts in the slightest from the genius and depth of the whole experience. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - worth every last penny. You owe it to yourself to play this.

												Love, loss and memories sum up the core ideas in To the Moon.  Styled as an SNES-era, sprite-based RPG, the game takes players on an adventure of the mind, similar to Inception.  Will you help put a dying man's wish in place or will you discover much more about his true desires?  Recommended for adventure fans and sprite-based games fans alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												One of the ever rising problems with modern games is their simplicity. They're short, utterly simple, and rarely worth finishing. What makes a game worth it? Is it complexity? Pretty graphics? Reward-factors? Difficulty? Absolutely not, because To the Moon is a short, utterly simple game... and it's definitely worth it.To The Moon is much less a game than it is an experience. Although simple in design, the depths of what it achieves is hard to surpass and simply cannot be passed up. You owe it to yourself to play it.Despite being made in RPG Maker XP, I can't say anything more than that it's simply what's used to pass on the story to the player. It's there, but never really makes the player feel like it's an RPG... it's more of a visual novel, with RPG Maker visuals instead of pictures. Is this a bad thing? Maybe, but what if there's something inside this game so powerful that it'll let one overlook anything iffy about its design? What if it's possible to lose yourself in a different aspect of the game? If it's the story, wouldn't it be like getting lost in a really good book? Yes, yes it would.The game's story is easily its most prominent aspect. There is some side-dialogue you might miss out on, but nothing else is going to sneak by. The story in To the Moon is amazing, sure, but are there any problems with it? Possibly. You see, To the Moon, if it suffers from anything, is its simple dialogue. Sentences are often short and consice. There isn't the same amount of detail you'd get in a novel. However, the pacing of the story, the characters, the plot twists, and everything that comes flying at you like a shuttle makes this one possible issue forgivable, if there really is an issue at all. Because in all of its greatness, I have to find something wrong with it. Honestly, it's a struggle...In addition to its great story, To the Moon has an absolutely amazing OST. Again, like the story, it's also simple. I could delve into detail about this like in the above paragraph, but I'll just stop and tell you that it fits perfectly. Every track only adds to the scene. There is absolutely nothing wrong with its simplicity. I'm done talking about that. Its best to hear the music while playing the game. The music and writing combine to deliver something fascinating, so revel in the simple beauty of the arts.And that's exactly what makes To the Moon an amazing game. Its simplicity. It's a short, to-the-point, and beautifully written story. At the end of it all, yes, I cried.In this world full of AAA games that suffer in some regard from being too simple, is To the Moon a game that stands out among the rest? Yes.Should you play it? If you value what makes video games worthwhile, then yes, you should.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												What 'To the Moon' isn't: an action game, a role-playing game, an adventure game.What 'To the Moon' is: a beautiful interactive novel that tells a poignant, human story.Using wonderfully retro pixel art (reminicient of the SNES), To the Moon tells the story of a man's life in reverse, spinning a tale that is equal parts melancholy and uplifting.  The gameplay interacions are absolutely minimal - there are some light hidden object mechanics, and a realitive easy recurring puzzle..... but that's not really the point of the game.  To the Moon is a schmultzy (in a good way) story set against a lovingly-crafted canvas and set to some utterly captivating piano scores.  The game looks and sounds amazing, and if you don't get misty eyed at least a few times then I don't know what's wrong with you.If you loved 'Gone Home', or other recent pieces of interactive fiction, then you should nsap this gem up right away.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												“To the Moon” is a simple but remarkable around four hour story-first game. That is somewhat limited on actual gameplay. Yet, makes-up for this fact with its extremely well-written and emotionally driven storyline. This game will tug at your heart strings one moment and make your side split with laughter by making fun of itself on the next. Each of the main characters are wonderfully written, even though they are a bit simple and stereotypical at times. I highly recommend this game to anyone who does not mind a little reading and enjoys a good story in their games.The gameplay is realistically only a few steps above a traditional visual novel. As you spend a lot of time reading its plotline and/or exploring the various locations to find triggers to advance the story. As a means to break-up the large amount of reading there are puzzles thrown in, which are relatively limited in difficulty. With some mini-games latter on comparable to virtual dodge ball and classic tag. Music-wise this game tends to repeats its few pieces over and over again. But what songs it does use are of high quality and really add to the emotional storyline. Particularly, the game loves playing its main theme: a wonderful piano piece throughout the course of the game during its various emotional scenes. Although, the limited selection is kind of to be expect to a certain point, since this is an indie game and was most likely developed on an extremely small budget; if any.Graphics-wise the game is retro Super Nintendo/Sega Genesis (16bit) era JRPG style. The artistry used is truly top-notch and would have been considered AAA quality in the heyday of 2D sprites. Which of course will strike a nostalgic vibe with older gamers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												An amazing, touching story for anyone, including non-gamers, to play. While the "gameplay" isn't the its best feature, the story and music are the shining treasures of this game. The story will definitely touch you in some way. Don't watch the ending first. This is one of those games where you just have to watch it from the beginning as everything has meaning to it. Watch a Let's Play if you have to, but I recommend supporting FreeBird Games by purchasing it yourself. Especially since one of the artists for the game is currently hospitalized. The music is one of my favorite parts of the game. I've learned most of the songs from this game on the piano. Definitely get the soundtrack with it. It hits the right mix between calm yet emotional. Just play the game before you listen to the soundtrack. It will make the music more memorable. All in all, definitely get this game for the story. If you like Mother 3 or sad stories, this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												To be clear, only the first couple hours at most have anything resembling 'gameplay', with a 'search the level for things' puzzle and 'flip tiles' puzzle coming up every 5 to 10 minutes. After those first two hours, the remainder of the experience is all one long 16-bit era RPG-like cutscene.That said, I still enjoyed the story that unfolded. It touched on a few issues I hadn't seen handled in a video game before and the central premise (as described in the flavor text on the store) is an interesting concept that I could really imagine being turned either into a series of stories or a movie someday. But probably the most compelling aspect is how the narrative explores what a profound difference one moment in time can make on the trajectory our lives take. This is always interesting food for thought to contemplate for ourselves, so being reminded of that via this game was nice.The soundtrack is soothing and fits the game perfectly.The controls are the only thing that had me grimacing from time to time. There are a lot of path blockers that serve no actual purpose and make navigating around them a bit tedious either by keyboard or mouse controls. This wasn't a major detraction, but was mildly annoying from time to time.Overall, quality experience, took about 3.5'ish hours. If you enjoy '90% story/10% game' style games as I do, you should appreciate this one.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I'm not used to do that kind of things and actually it's the first time that i do a true evaluation for a game but, on this one, clearly it deserve it.To let you know, i'm not that you can say a "big fan" of retro or pixel games but, clearly developpers and game designers have done an amazing job, graphics are really well done. I often say that "pixel games are hurting my eyes" but this one has been made a sort that my eyes were perfectly fine with it and i can ensure you that it is something pretty difficult to do.Now, the soundtrack... I'm a guy that love when there is some good soundtrack on a game and actually, even tho it could have been repetitiv, it fit well with the game + actually there is some others songs, like the one at the end when they're with "river's case" (to not spoil) is just wonderfull ! Clearly sound designers have done a great job too.Now, the best part : the story. Clearly on this one, people can't argue, it has been well made too. Main story is interesting with every important settings needed for a good story. Main characters are interesting and quite appealing, there is also some background that is nice, even tho i'm pretty sure we could have like some more but on the actual state it's quite nice and probably enough.  There is comedy, some drama, some suspens, etc... i would say that's a complete story with every good components that we like (and yeah, i had a tear at the edge of my right eye at some moment while laughing at other ones).I'd like to congratz the "french traduction team" because it has been majestic, even some "triple-A" games has worse trad that you have.Like, seriously, we can feel that every person that worked on this masterpiece has put into the game their soul and not takings shortcuts. To do a great game, that's what you need to do.Actually, i can't only be positiv or it wouldn't be a real evaluation... I only have one issue with this game, is about the "gaming" itself. I don't know if it's because of the 2.5D but some textures have bad hitbox and so characters have often some difficulties to use some specific objetcs when you directly click on the item to let them go and use it, you have to manually put them right in front + even worst, sometimes even if you're in front of it, the characters can't use it, because some part of the "hitbox" is not working...But don't worry, it is not that much of a problem because the rest of the game really make this small cloud something that don't stay in mind ; but yeah, because of that i can't say that i gave a 10 to this game, but clearly i give it a 9.5/10.To everyone that wonder if it's a good game, yep it is ! Clearly it's worth to buy it but not buying it when there is some huge discount on him, it's probably criminal (i'm joking, but yeah, i don't like to do some "free advertizing" but this game really deserve at least your attention).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												To the moon, is an indie game that will take you on an emotional roller coaster. This game with it's story, and execution will make the biggest of gaming men choke up with this beautifully story. Are you ready to ride this roller coaster of feels?Game play: 5While this game is a very story driven, it kinda of lacks in any real game play. You run around as one of the two main characters either in the dying old man johnny's memorys or around his house and outside of it.While inside the his memorys you are task to find key pieces to his memorys after each scene that plays out to unlock earlier memorys. Pretty simple, you look for the “shines” that shows up. After each memory chapter you are given a small puzzle of flipping tiles of a picuture to complete the memory. Overall the game play isn't the main focus here.Story 10The story takes place with an the old man named, johnny, who is on his death bed with only one wish. To go to the moon.  The two main characters you follow are, Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts who are from the Sigmund Corp. who has technology that altar the memory’s of people. They usely use the technology on people who are dying to grant them one last wish. It is the job of Rosalene, and Watts to altar johnny's memory to send him to the moon. While digging deep into the memory’s of Johnny you find out about his wife who passed away years ago. Who has had mental problems who befriends a light house.  You also find out more about his pass on why he wants to go the moon even though he doesn't know himself. You'll end up meeting other characters from his, from his childhood to his aduit life who plays a big role in his life. With some dark twist.This game proves that sometimes isn't not always about having the best game play or graphics to have a compelling story to get you immersed in whats going on.Graphics: 9This game goes with a 16-bit graphic style, with mostly bright and colorful graphics mix with some dark looking graphics to set up each scene nicely. Ir's like playing a classic Super Nintendo game. They paid attention to details to make sure they where fitting for the story thats unfolding in front of your eyes.Music: 9The music is well placed and helps to set the mood for each scene. The music goes hand and hand with the story. They did a great job in matching the music to how they wanted you to feel at that current moment. They also did a great job on the music overall. Having a great story and music can mean all the difference on how well a game like this could do, over all the music mixes well with the story and adds a unique experience that you wont find in many other games. Final Though:I found this game one of the best story driven indie games that I have ever played. The story gets really deep and it will touch most peoples hearts, While giving you a lot of overwhelming feelings that you though you didn't have. The story is a sad story, and can make almost anyone cry or at least choke up. I can safely say that I can compare this to the aeris death scene in final fantasy VII when it comes to emotional feelings.As soon as I started playing. I was immersed in the story with in the first 15 minutes or so. I didn't even want to get up for anything. I only got up one time to use the bathroom, even then I was holding it in for at least an hour before hand. I beat this game in one sitting from start to end. I won't lie to you. I was crying by the end. I remember walking out of my room and my roommates asking why are my eyes so red and I said back to them “im just really tired I didn't get much sleep last night”.If you are wanting a heavy story driven game, then this game WILL be for you. There isn't any real amazing game play here but the story makes up for it ten fold. So for the people who are more about action style games, don't bother in picking up this game you'll most likely find it boring and not to your liking. This game is just overall amazing plain and simple! It's a MUST buy for any story driven game fans out there.Final Score: 10For more reviews and other fun stuff check out my tumblr. www.rogue32807.tumblr.com

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												"Because one day.... I'm going to befriend one of them"To The Moon is honestly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The story is among the best in any form of entertainment and will simultaneously break your heart and move it. With its amazing 16-bit graphical art style, To The Moon is a beautiful story about love and grief, reminding us how easy it is to overlook the simple, yet beautiful moments in our lives.Also the music is phenomenal and stands among the best in video games! Just starting up the game and drowning yourself in To The Moon's main theme is an experience in itself. The piano piece "To the Moon/For River" is arguably one of the most beautiful, albeit repetitive, songs I have ever listened to.In terms of gameplay, there isn't much to do. You can tell the doctors where to go and what to interact with (kinda like a point and click adventure game) but besides that, gameplay is fairly lacking. However, your main reason to play this amazing gem should be because of its poignant story, not its gameplay. To The Moon is easily one of my favourite games and is hard not to recommend it to anyone who appreciates a good story. I applaud Kan “Reives” Gao for writing such a beautiful story, for composing an elegant score, and for creating such an emotional, touching experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I can safely say there are very few games that have touched me so deeply. I'm proud to say this is one of them. The game made me laugh, cry (both from joy/relief as well as from sadness), and panic. It also made me ponder the meaning of life and the inherent fallibilty of the human brain, as well as the long-lasting effects that everyday choices can make.Granted, this isn't really as much of a game as it is a visual novel, one of which has little to no branching paths therein, but I digress.I truly enjoyed the game's narrative and characters. The chemistry between the two main characters is infectious, and there was more than one time I'd burst out laughing from the banter between them. The references (for the most part) are relevant, recognizable, and genuinely funny. The plot was riveting, and had several startling and brilliant twists. I can honestly say I NEVER would have seen the Joey/Johnny twist coming (and I'll leave it at that, so as not to spoil it for prospective players), and I'm VERY good at predicting plot twists.There are some flaws in this game, as there always are. Nothing's perfect. The list of my gripes follows:1. I wish a lot of the items I picked up served any real purpose through the game. Maybe leading to a secret ending or something? I had that origami rabbit in my inventory the whole game. Not once was it utilized.2. As far as I know, the memento puzzles are nothing but busywork and your amount of moves doesn't affect the game in the slightest.3. The health monitor for your client is apparently just there for window dressing, as I never saw it change unless the plot demanded it, and even then, the effects in the memory, as well as what other NPCs say, tells you of his change in condition, leaving the health monitor to be rather superfluous.4. The game essentially boils down to "hover your mouse over things until you find something to click on". Granted, sometimes you find things that are merely there to set the scene, and that's a good thing, but I'd prefer some indicator on things I can click on.5. Targeting for the mouse seems really wonky at times. In the whack-a-mole minigame, the highlighted box that shows where the hammer is supposedly going to impact seems remarkably imprecise and highly unpredictable. Also, if, on the memento flip puzzles, you click another row before the first one finishes flipping, the next row to flip will be whatever row your cursor is over at the moment the first flipping finishes, and it often isn't one you wanted clicked.6. The animorphs puzzle is wrong. Then again, it's a really minor thing that (as far as I can tell) bears no real effect on the story, so that's a minor gripe.7. They never go into how or why River died. They mention how there's an operation that can be performed, and that it's expensive, but they never really go any further into detail.8. They made River's disorder rather ambiguous. Granted, it was kind of obvious to me, seeing as Human psychology has always fascinated me, but they never mention the disorder by name. I was playing the game alongside a friend, and had to explain to him what River's disorder was, because he thought she was just awkward. Many people probably had to google the author of the book River's doctor gives to Johnny, just to know who Tony Attwood even is.Despite these shortcomings, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who's willing to take the time to get invested in the story and characters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												When I read about this game, I thought it would be some kind of anime story with some memory exploring. Oh boy was I in for a surprise, I had never expected how much this game would affect me.There aren't enough words to describe how amazing this game is. The story is excellently weaved together. The characters all have very distinct personalities, even the two scientists have such distinct personalities you can clearly tell how they would react in situations. (The male one being the sillier and quirky) Exploring the old mans past makes you relate to him as if he was a person you knew in your real life. It's so easy to like him, but also relate to all of his struggles. There are many moments of sadness where my heart aches for him.The most striking character for me is potrayed with a disability in the autism spectrum. Usually when you see these kind of characters, they are either stereotypically good at math (autism) or they are self-absorbed ragers (aspberger). As I have high functioning autism myself (basically between autism and asperger), there are so many ways I could relate to this character and her perception of what love and friendship is. People in the game are also portrayed in the way they view her, because she really stands out as strange and emotionally distant. But the main character, Johnny, just likes her so much he won't let the things get in the way. He spends enough time with her to understand how she works, instead of others that look at her and think she just refuses to be civilized. Excellent portrayal of this disability.The soundtrack is fantastic. Especially "Moonwhisher". I have spent hours and hours crying to this lovely track. It's so incredibly touching. There are few wordless tracks which moves me in the way this one does. It really sets the mood when you are watching a sad scene in the game. Many of the other musical pieces are also great. One of them, "For River", even has a background story in the game as to why the musical piece is so simple at the beginning with just two notes. So when you follow the story to the end, then hear the musical piece in the various adaptions, it really fills my eyes with tears. I liked the graphic of the game. The old school pixels were all very well done and the areas portrayed all feels like they spent a good time to make sure it wouldn't be repeatetive. Nowhere do I remember feeling myself lost. Each area has their own uniqueness, so it is easy to find your way.I love the way the story is told. It literally starts you near the end, then you tread your way back slowly until you reach the start of Johnnys life, then it is like climbing back up again to find parts that were skipped over during the transition there. It doesn't just end there though, the game offers a final piece to the puzzle with a great plot twist. The game starts out by making it seem the issue is easily solved, then it builds up and you realize there is so much more to the game.The only possible complaint I could make about the game is a mini-game you play each time you transistion in a memory. I just thought it was distracting and not fun. It's over quite fast though.This is a game I would recommend to everyone to play at least once. Especially if you enjoy deep, emotional stories that truly explores the personalities and life of the characters.

												Man, this game...I very rarely write reviews for anything, let alone Steam games. If I wrote a review for every steam game I owned, I'd be here a long time.I originally fired up this game because it has steam cards. I don't even remember how I ended up with a copy. Probably from a Humble Bundle. Regardless, the steam cards enticed me to open it up. With every game I've ever opened for steam cards, I gave it a spin, and I am happy I did.Initial thoughts were ho hum as it took a little bit to get into the game. It was also very focused on trying to get me to use the mouse. Let me say right now to anyone thinking of playing this game, only use the mouse to try and identify items to click on. Move around with the keyboard, it'll make things much easier on you.Initial thoughts aside, I trudged on as I watched my steam inventory tick up on the cards collected. However, as I got deeper and deeper into the game, I found myself fascinated as story events started to reveal. There was quirky humor, shocking reveals, and sad moments. However, the story wraps itself up well and I found myself amazed as I looked back, picking up on small things that happened with no reasoning until things revealed through the ending.The story flows together well. The soundtrack fits in perfectly. The characters have enough depth to keep them interesting, without being overbearing. Overall, this game is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone. I'm not normally an artsy fartsy story telling game kinda guy, but this one was fantastic. Just get ready for tears, because holy crap that reveal.Now if you excuse me, I need to go play 12 hours of Street Fighter to make up for the emotional carnage this game has played on me. :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												This game's greatest strengths are its moving narrative, and a soundtrack that enhances the mood perfectly. At its heart, the story is a bittersweet romance; generous doses of quirky nerd-culture references and make-you-think mystery make it well-rounded and distinctive. Much of the comic relief comes from the banter between Drs. Rosalene and Watts. At first I found their sarcasm and silliness grating, but eventually as they come to care about their patient, Johnny, their wisecracks are put into balance and cease to detract from Johnny's story.The puzzle- and hidden-object-based game mechanics are simple, but that's a good thing, because it was supposed to be subordinate to the story. That said, the gameplay does have some flaws. The mouse controls sometimes lagged, and I found some of the maps to be cluttery and hard to navigate. But overall, the game mechanics did their job of getting me to notice the little details that contribute to the story.I completed To the Moon in just under 5 hours, mostly in a few long sessions, because I didn't want to put it down. It made me feel all the feelings. <3

This game is very short and you can easily finish it in 1 or 2 sittings (3 to 4 hours). And there's only a couple of minutes of actual gameplay in total, the rest is mostly text and some exploration elements. This game would have been fine as just a visual novel or a point and click game but despite all this, the game makes up for it with a deep and touching story. The story really emphasizes how it's not about the destination, but rather the journey. Paired up with an amazing soundtrack, this game creates a beautiful experience that makes it all worthwhile.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												"Because one day.... I'm going to befriend one of them"To The Moon is honestly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The story is among the best in any form of entertainment and will simultaneously break your heart and move it. With its amazing 16-bit graphical art style, To The Moon is a beautiful story about love and grief, reminding us how easy it is to overlook the simple, yet beautiful moments in our lives.Also the music is phenomenal and stands among the best in video games! Just starting up the game and drowning yourself in To The Moon's main theme is an experience in itself. The piano piece "To the Moon/For River" is arguably one of the most beautiful, albeit repetitive, songs I have ever listened to.In terms of gameplay, there isn't much to do. You can tell the doctors where to go and what to interact with (kinda like a point and click adventure game) but besides that, gameplay is fairly lacking. However, your main reason to play this amazing gem should be because of its poignant story, not its gameplay. To The Moon is easily one of my favourite games and is hard not to recommend it to anyone who appreciates a good story. I applaud Kan “Reives” Gao for writing such a beautiful story, for composing an elegant score, and for creating such an emotional, touching experience.

												"To The Moon" is very much a game that is a greater than the sum of its parts. Individually I don't think they are uniquely powerful in anyway. But as a whole this game is brilliant. Its a well put together experience with the narrative and music really capturing you and taking you on an adventure as you go through the world and story in the game. This is a game I really can't reccomend enough and I assure you that you will have some kind of emotional response. My response from the game, was that I actually had to stop the game maybe a third of the way through and call my mother. I just felt compelled to do it, and I'm pretty sure anyone who plays the game is going to get a similarly strong reaction to the game.If you want to read a longer review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/09/to-moon.html.

Posted: September 1, 2015
												I loved this deeply emotional and philosophical game. The themes are very accessible in terms of the common human experience they explore, yet they are presented with very interesting nuance and complexity. The Memento-like mechanic of moving backwards through time in vignettes works really well to create a solid narrative suspense.The minisodes are not as good. They explore the social implications of the technology that is at the base of the game as well as some mystery about the main characters, which is interesting, but the gameplay is weak, involving a lot of back and forth between screens.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												To the Moon is a beautiful short story. I must say, however, that after hearing so many good things about the game, I found it rather disappointing... but that isn't the game's fault, so I still recommend it. Just don't expect to cry your eyes out and be traumatized forever, as some people on the internet would have you think. It's a nice and clever story, there's not much to do as long as gameplay goes, but as it usually happens in this kind of games, this should be considered more as an alternative way to tell a story than a proper game. An interactive story, you could say. The writing is funny, the OST is extremely well done and catchy, and since I also like olives and platypuses, I definitely recommend To the Moon. If playing a localised version (thank you devs for having the game translated!) be aware that you'll have to change the language to English and play again through the last scene in order to get the achievement. Oh, and don't forget to play the two free DLC (a.k.a mini-sodes). They're a nice free addition, though I really hate cliffhangers and every single ending has one. And the mini-sodes should have been included somehow directly in the menu of the main game. The way they are currently implemented is quite sloppy and I believe this wouldn't be that hard to fix.  Despite all this, To the Moon is a nice story worthy of a playthrough... a great story, yes, but still not quite what I would call a game. As long as you are okay with this, I'm sure you'll enjoy it :)

												One of my favorite stories I've ever read/played. The plot is well developed and thoroughly enjoyable. This game is a steal at its current sale price!Art is simplistic but amazing in its own style. The characters have nice designs and I love the level design. It's such a beautiful game -- nothing I'd expect out of a game I'd never heard of before its sale.As for controls, the movement with clicking can be a bit annoying, but it's really no big deal. The puzzles are easier than I thought they'd be. I don't think going for the "ideal" amount of moves on all the puzzles does anything significant, so no need to be stubborn like I was and keep trying to find the ideal move order. The soundtrack for this game is amazing. After launching the game for the first time, I was awed by the main menu track and knew it'd be well worth my time even if it were just for the music. Throughout the game, the soundtrack worked well to produce an appropriate atmosphere, as the soundtracks were very nice and fitting.TLDR: I can't recommend this game enough. The story is fascinating and the soundtrack is worth the price of the entire game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												What is worth anything in the end, are fake memories better than real ones? What would you want to remember from your life when it’s nearing it’s conclusion if you had the possibility to choose? Does it even matter if the memories are real if they make you happy? Such questions together with one of the saddest relationships in gaming history makes ”To the Moon” one of my absolute favorite experiences ever in the gaming medium. It’s also not everyday the word neurotypical is used in a game narrative. If you have any connection at all in your life with high functioning autism this is probably one of the only games that discusses the topic in a relatable, albeit heartbreakingly sad way. I can’t say much about the game itself as everything is overshadowed by the tale told. It has some beautiful music and vintage graphics but also the clunky gameplay style of an old school JRPG. Some of the dialogue is rather retro as well, but the storytelling is excellent to a point where anyone even slightly interested should experience it.A huge experience in a very small, limited package it's hugely recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I was never into visual novels, but after experiencing this one - I think I might have missed on many memorable games from the genre. To the Moon is certainly one of them.Don't judge the book by its cover. Being made in RPG Maker shouldn't be a reason to avoid this game. To the Moon involves some simple mechanics to keep you engaged and let's you take an active part in the whole story. Pixelart is beautiful, every sprite is very detailed and locations are unique. Music is one of the strongest points of the game - sets the mood perfectly everytime.Throughout the game I experienced whole spectrum of feelings. It made me jump from sadness to the joy and back to the sorrow again in a blink. It also makes you curious, makes you think about current events and doesn't stop until the very end. Your main characters add humorous aspect without breaking the overall tone of the story and are easy to get along with.You won't find hardcore gameplay here, but mature story about fulifilling one's dreams.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												This game will make you cry!! Seriously tho, it was good enough that I felt like I should write a review for it (which is a big deal for me lol). My first bit of praise for this game is its beautiful music. Music can make or break a game for me, and suffice to say, To the Moon's OST is one of my favorites. Secondly, the story is supurb. The plot has perfect pacing, moderate origionality, and fantastic character design, not to mention you will definatley shead a few manly tears (I know I did T^T). The way the story is set up (moving back through a character's memories) you are always discovering the product of the character's actions before you know what is going on, which kept me intrested and invested in the story all the way through. The game is short though, I finished it in about 3.5hr (.2 was idling), but it doesnt have to be any longer. The length of the game is perfect, it allows enough time to tell the story, without becoming boring. If your looking for a tear-jerking feel's trip, that leaves you feeling oddly philosophical, with great music and character design, the give To the Moon a try, you'll love it. Can't recommend this game more! 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I heard this game from a friend's recommendation. He said that this game has an awesome (and heartwarming, if not tear-jerking) story. When I checked a couple details of the game from the store page, I thought that it was quite attractive. A US$10 game with RPGMaker-like graphical art, awesome story, and beautiful musics. That looks like a deal to me! Moreover, it was Summer Steam Sale at the time, which made it even better. Oh well, enough with the intro.Story:The story itself is pretty short. You can complete it in under 4 hours straight. It is indeed short in terms of length, but it's superb in terms of quality. You can drowned inside the emotional story if you really pay attention. While it didn't make me cry like some other players, I agree that it is truly beautiful.Gameplay:The gameplay is pretty simple, it's just point and click until you clear the objectives. There are some puzzles to solve too. While it's not really hard unlike other puzzle game, it's quite challenging.Graphic Art:I can't say a lot about the graphic. After all, this game is about its emotional story. All I can say is this game has a RPGMaker-like graphics. If you don't mind that kind of graphics, then you'll have no problem. If you do though, I recommend you hold out until you can grasp the idea of the story. Trust me, the story is much much more interesting than you think.Musics:This is another favourite part of mine in this game. Almost all the musics here fit perfectly with each scenes it paired with. Especially that one "repetitive piano play" music. It's lovely.Characters:While the story has so much emotion in it, not every characters also bring more sappy elements into it. For example our two doctors. Or exclusively that one person who always trying to crack jokes with his partner. It balanced the atmosphere nicely.In conclusion, this game really deserves the "Great Story" and "Story Rich" tags. Play it at least once until you understand the main story, then I assure that it will leave a special impression for you. If you think that US$10 is too expensive, wait until the next Steam Sale. I bought this for US$3 during Summer Sale, and it was worth every cent of it. And also if you're feeling generous, buy the Soundtrack bundle too. There are some musics that worth to collect inside.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												To the moon. This game. This fricken game is amazing. I must start off by saying this isnt much of a game, its more of an interactive storytelling with tangents for extra information, nonetheless this game is amazing. To the moon is a 2d top down sprite game that tells the story of 2 young doctors whos job is to recreate a patients wish using a machine that recreates it in thier memory. Now thats done, lets get down to it. To the moons story. one - the writer is a genius he created each interactable character with a deep and relatable storyline. This is also the first game I have ever felt so tear-jerked. It was beautiful. The story was told so well from beginning to middle to end, each with impressive plot twists that are hard to see coming. I think that was the art to this story, it was incredibly hard to predict. Now music. One - the soundtrack was beautiful with large amounts of subtle orchestra music playing to create constant ambience at the right moments. There was also some very heavy songs amoung to create unease and funnily enough they sound like they are out of a horror game. two. I bought the OST the minute I finished the game. The graphics - like I said before 2d but this works perfectly, This game is so engrossing you will soon create faces for the characters yourself imagining the perfect emotions for the characters when its really needed. Gameplay. Now the gameplay was a bit weird, the game characters handled a bit like any click to move game, you collect "momentos" to move onto new memorys generally finding a final one to move back to another memory. There were also mountains of media refrences throughout the game. I will leave you with my favourite quote. "Not cool Eva. You Never cockblock someone in the middle of a kamehameha."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												To The Moon......Gah, where do I start?TL;DRI guess fair warning to anyone deciding whether or not to buy this game:The storyline is great, and the soundtrack equally good, but if you're looking for amazing graphics, this is not the game for you.There are a few picture perfect moments, but other than that the graphics are that of a 1st Gen Pokemon game.Pros+Great StorylineThe storyline has be taken aback a bit.I've just completed the game and I'm having a bit of trouble finding the words.I went into this game not having the slightest idea of what I was going to experience, and oh boy, this game was an experience alright.+Great SoundtrackI would also recommend buying the soundtrack, as it's 33 (Ish) tracks, and 50% of that money goes to charity. The soundtrack has a more classical theme, with piano being present in every track if i remember correctly.+Cheap GameWell worth the 10 dollars (12 if you get the soundtrack), and even more of a steal when this game is on sale.+Steam CardsYou can't really profit off of the steam cards with this game, but steam cards are always a plus to a game.+Relatable CharactersAll the characters had a very real personality added to them, I could draw connections to some of the people in game.+HUGE plot twistYou will have to play and find outCons-The graphics Better graphics would've made the story just a tad bit better, and made the game more immersive, but this was not a large problem due to the great storyline.-Gameplay MechanicsCollecting memories seemed a bit odd, and it takes a while to get into the flow of how this works.-Low replay valueThe story is really great, but now that I know how the story goes, I may not play it again until I've forgotten every detail of the game. RatingOverall I give this game a solid 9 out of 10.The only (again, minor) thing would be the graphics, but this studio has a great story to tell and I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2012
												A strange combination of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Citizen Kane," and a push puzzle game. Which might sound terrible, but the results are pretty awesome. Although there are mini-puzzles to solve, it's really more an "interactive story" than a game, per se, but the "story" elements are top notch and even kind of revolutionary, considering that this was made in RPG Maker. It's rare that any piece of storytelling uses its medium to the fullest to achieve its ends so well.It is heavy on the sentimentality at times, but usually it's smart enough to pull back with a bit of humor, or a non-sequitor, or just a genuinely well observed piece of writing before things venture into "maudlin" territory. Over all, though, it is very well written.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												You know that feeling you sometimes get when you're close to beating an amazing game, and you're just in awe as the story reaches it's conclusion? To The Moon did that for me too, but it hit me a lot harder than any game I have played before, and it did it before the ending was even in sight.Not much of a game in the tradtional sense, it is a stupidly good interactive movie. Before playing To The Moon I would say that The Walking Dead is my favorite game in this genre, it too is an amazingly gripping interactive character drama. However, as powerful and tear-jerking The Walking Dead was for me, it only really had me in tears at moments where the characters' lives were threatened. It evoked emotions over a feeling of hopelessness in the face of death. To The Moon, however, is a much more complicated story. I was in tears throughout it's duration, and for several different reasons. It was an emotional rollercoaster that only got stronger as it reached it's conclusion.And it's story is something so good I feel everyone should experience it. I would reccomend playing through it in one sitting. It's only about 4 hours long, so that's doable, but it will be an experience you will never forget. At least for me it was.To put it bluntly, this game changed my life.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A profoundly beautiful experience that features some of the most poignant story-telling and one of the finest musical compositions I can recall in recent memory. So emotionally draining that it's capable of reducing grown men to tears with ease. It handles themes such as love, death, regret, and fulfillment while hitting all the right notes at just the right times. Excellent pacing, never really a dull moment where the story seems to drag. Every scene and every line of dialogue has a meaning and purpose to it and it results in a tight narrative that's both engaging and captivating. My one real issue is the way some gameplay elements seem to be shoehorned in (especially in one of the final scenes), as if the developer feared not including any gameplay at all. It feels tacked on and unnecessary and the experience would be no less powerful had they been left out entirely.To The Moon serves as a testament to how important good story-telling and writing can be in the world of videogames. In this case, they lift the game up into the realm of greatness. A true masterpiece.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												To the Moon is a fantastic game. It's a story about two people named Dr. Rosaline and Dr. Watts and they give people a last chance to live out their final wish through their memories and make them think they actually did it. The patient they are currently working on is a man named Johnny whose final wish is to go to the moon. He doesn't remember why, but that's all he wants to do.Simple right? No, his story goes far back to his childhood and you must travel through the years of his life, find out why he wants to go to the moon, and give it to him.The story is fantastic, the soundtrack is great too, and characters are likable and memorable. It is also a game that will tug at your heart strings as you journey along. It is a very emotional game, and I bet you will be tearing up at the end at how good it is.Pick it up now and play through a fantastic experience. Also get the soundtrack too because it too is also great.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2012
												A strange combination of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Citizen Kane," and a push puzzle game. Which might sound terrible, but the results are pretty awesome. Although there are mini-puzzles to solve, it's really more an "interactive story" than a game, per se, but the "story" elements are top notch and even kind of revolutionary, considering that this was made in RPG Maker. It's rare that any piece of storytelling uses its medium to the fullest to achieve its ends so well.It is heavy on the sentimentality at times, but usually it's smart enough to pull back with a bit of humor, or a non-sequitor, or just a genuinely well observed piece of writing before things venture into "maudlin" territory. Over all, though, it is very well written.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												This is a FANTASTIC game. You play as one of two scientists who go to dying people and allow then to "relive" their lives, with modifications to their memories. You are able to grant a deathbed wish.You follow the life of a man and his love by tapping into his memories by using the same machine that you are using to alter his memories. You are but a ghost, observing the unfolding story and history of the man's life though his memories. You gain great insight and develop an emotional connection to the characters in the game to your own benefit to connect with them and really feel their stories, their happiness, and their sadness.There are YouTube Let's Plays of this game. Someone made a compilation "Players react to To The Moon" - specifically the ending. Even some of the most famous and comedic Let's Play broadcasters have been brought to a serious, quiet, somber demeanor as the game unfolds, and brought to tears at the end.Don't look at any reviews (well, except this one, it's too late!), don't watch the reaction video until you've beaten the game, don't listen to the music until you've completed the game. Just play it. It will take you in and immerse you. It will be one of those games you categorize in your mind as the most memorable and emotional stories in a video game ever.All this from sprites in a Final Fantasy esque presentation (but no random encounters!). It shows you don't need high definition, state of the art graphics to have a powerful game play experience. The music however is real, no midi synth or FruityLoops. Everything from a real simple piano piece (which you will find yourself YouTubing to listen to for years after playing it, if you don't outright buy the OST) to fully scored songs, one with (great) vocalization.Buy it. If you love a game for it's story over mindlessly running around killing things for XP, you will love To The Moon.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
To The Moon is a game that I didn't expect much of, but ended up being quite possibly my favorite game. This game is absolutely worth full priceI could say some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here about how "To The Moon tells a masterfully orchestrated tale of humanity: Remembering who you are and what you mean to those who love you" and, to be fair, it does. The problem is that there's just nothing I can really say to make you play this game other than this: Trust me. It's short, it's sweet, and maybe a little salty from all the tears, and it should be at the very top of the "To Play:" list for anyone that enjoys a good story. Hell, for anyone because it tells a story that's relevant to all of us. The StoryThis game doesn't have a story. it is a story, but that's what makes it so great. The story focuses on a man named Johnny, and his final wish: to go to the moon. Now, that's all the detail I'm going to tell you, because [insert ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about experiencing the story here]. I mean, yeah, that's what makes a good story, a great story. It's also probably why I liked this game so much to be honest, because I went into it fully blind. I picked it up in a hmble bundle, like, years ago, and just played it. I have to say, it was not what I was expecting. I was originally gonna put this in that last paragraph, but went on a tanget that I just dont want to take the time to move it somewhere else. ANYWAY, let's move on. This story is one of humanity and unconditional love. Well, kinda. At least on the unconditional love part. It is most definitely a story about humanity. One that teaches that you need to remember who you are and what you mean to those who love you (which, conviniently, is the same fluffy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that I said I wasn't gonna put in here. So I'm a liar. Sue me.). Something that I know that a lot of people need to hear.And it's just ♥♥♥♥ing good.The GameplayIt's not much. RPG Maker isometric perspective. It doesn't need much though. It's a story. A good one. (see above)I don't even know why I added this sectionThe MusicYes.In all seriousness, the soundtrack is great. One of the best things about this game. You can get it on steam  or on Bandcamp[freebirdgames.bandcamp.com]My personal reccomendations are Everything's Alright and any version of For RiverRantI. ♥♥♥♥ING. Love. This game. That is all.Hey, and if you like this there are other games from Freebird on steam. You can get Bird Story here  or, next summer, you can get Finding Paradise here.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												After almost two years, I finally got around to playing "To the Moon". It's billed as an adventure game, but is really just a wonderful story told through JRPG mechanics.  Great pixel art, good scripting and a wonderful soundtrack all make the experience enjoyable and very touching.  It's a bit of a slow burn, at first, but once you get past the story setup, you'll be hard pressed to stop playing until the end."To the Moon" will tug at your heart in surprising ways.  What are we and what is life, but the sum total of our memories and experience?  And, at the end of your life, if you could change something from that experience, would you?  And at what cost?It's really thought-provoking stuff, and is told in a way that will make you smile, make you reflect on your life...and break your heart.  Start to finish is only about three hours and, at the end, you'll get that same bittersweet feeling as when you finish a wonderful novel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												In a nutshell, "To the Moon" is the story of two doctors looking to fulfill the wish of a dying man named Johnny. His wish is to go, you guessed it, to the moon. The problem with that is he doesn't know why and it's up to the two doctors to find out and they do this by going into his memories. I won't spoil any of the plot for you but the journey is one well worth taking. I wouldn't exactly call "To the Moon" a game per se. You basically look around the level for fragments of a memory which trigger a memento that helps you reach the next memory. After you trigger the memento, you have to do some light puzzle solving. Sometimes, you will have to do other things but this is the definiton of a casual game. There's no time limits, no right or wrong way to do things and you WILL eventually fulfill Johnny's wish to get to the moon. That's why I'd call this more of a visual novel than a game. The story is really what sucks you in. It's almost a nuisance to go through the gameplay because you just want to find out what happens. And I will say, this game about 80% in throws you a massive curveball I didn't see coming. Like System Shock 2 - SHODAN type curveball. Overall I'd recommend "To the Moon" for it's wonderful story of love and loss and the superb soundtrack. Yes, you can loosely call this a "game" but it's definitely worth a playthrough if you enjoy good stories. 7.5/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												Words can't be enough to describe how brilliant this is.Even though the gameplay is quite thin, focusing on collecting mementos and solving fairly easy puzzles, we're not here for that.It's the fantastic story, the brilliant musical score and the clever dialogue that steals the show immediately.The story tells about technology, which makes it possible for doctors to connect into patients' minds, see their memories and change them as they match their dreams.This corrupts though the "real" memories, so these have to be done when they're on their deathbed. I'm not getting the story any further, as you have to experience it on your own.The music is absolutely terrific, it fits to the mood of the story and enhances it at the same time.And the dialogue is both hilarious and thoughtful, it balances the game for not being too depressing or too jesting. The playful chit-chatting of doctors, the sad thoughts of Johnny (the "main" patient) and shy statements of his now-deceased autistic wife River.Now for hardcore gamers, this isn't one of your "action thrills" of the year, nor the longest games you've ever played (took me 5 hours to complete it).To The Moon is more like an interactive story than a game, but it doesn't hurt the in-game content.There are also sometimes a bit inconsistent pacing, turning suddenly from puzzling to throwing pot plants at zombies (Plants vs. Zombies?)Asides of these problems, it's hard to forget this game. It was completely different experience, and it deserves more attention than it currently has. It's one of those games that keeps reminding of what is truly important in life. From the beginning's lighthouse to the touching conclusion, it really is worth your money.
