number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												This is probably the best-written game (or really, anything) that I've ever experienced..Buy it. Buy it now. Don't have another thought until you purchase this game. I bought it for $10, but it's easily worth at least 15.Usually, my guideline of the worth of a game is a dollar payed for every hour I've played. It's not the best guideline, and there are many exceptions to it. Of all the exceptions, this game is the strongest. It far exceeded my expectations. And after reading the reviews, my expectations were pretty freaking high.Let me explain:I have cried at video games, shows, movies, and probably even a book or two. But none of those have ever made me feel like this game has. It made me cry, laugh, smile, wonder, worry, and love.Love is there because I'm in love with this game and the craftsmanship of its creators.Listen, I rarely write reviews. For ANYTHING. Just do yourself a favor and don't debate buying this game. You wont regret it. One thing you WILL regret, though? Not buying the soundtrack along with it.Buy it. Now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												You know that feeling you sometimes get when you're close to beating an amazing game, and you're just in awe as the story reaches it's conclusion? To The Moon did that for me too, but it hit me a lot harder than any game I have played before, and it did it before the ending was even in sight.Not much of a game in the tradtional sense, it is a stupidly good interactive movie. Before playing To The Moon I would say that The Walking Dead is my favorite game in this genre, it too is an amazingly gripping interactive character drama. However, as powerful and tear-jerking The Walking Dead was for me, it only really had me in tears at moments where the characters' lives were threatened. It evoked emotions over a feeling of hopelessness in the face of death. To The Moon, however, is a much more complicated story. I was in tears throughout it's duration, and for several different reasons. It was an emotional rollercoaster that only got stronger as it reached it's conclusion.And it's story is something so good I feel everyone should experience it. I would reccomend playing through it in one sitting. It's only about 4 hours long, so that's doable, but it will be an experience you will never forget. At least for me it was.To put it bluntly, this game changed my life.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A profoundly beautiful experience that features some of the most poignant story-telling and one of the finest musical compositions I can recall in recent memory. So emotionally draining that it's capable of reducing grown men to tears with ease. It handles themes such as love, death, regret, and fulfillment while hitting all the right notes at just the right times. Excellent pacing, never really a dull moment where the story seems to drag. Every scene and every line of dialogue has a meaning and purpose to it and it results in a tight narrative that's both engaging and captivating. My one real issue is the way some gameplay elements seem to be shoehorned in (especially in one of the final scenes), as if the developer feared not including any gameplay at all. It feels tacked on and unnecessary and the experience would be no less powerful had they been left out entirely.To The Moon serves as a testament to how important good story-telling and writing can be in the world of videogames. In this case, they lift the game up into the realm of greatness. A true masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2013
												To the Moon is an incredibly depressing game, and I loved every second of it. As a bit of a disclaimer, if you are sensitive, have at least 5 tissue boxes with you. Trust me, you will need them. Anyways, this game is about a dying man named Johnny, who has hired people to into his memories and fulfill one wish, which will be the last thing the patient remembers. Johnny's wish: to go to the moon. This is an unforgettable experience and is worth $10, the game will make you laugh with many pop culture references and its general sense of humour, and make you cry with its sad story and ending. Anyone longing for a good story NEEDS to play through this game... I promise you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												The good with the bad. In the end, an excellent experience.Good: Fantastic story and concept. The music is wonderful. The graphics are full of life. The early levels are detailed and magnificent to explore.Bad: Some terrible, occasionally dreadful writing. Most of the characters are written the exact same all the way through the game. There's little differenciation between the different eras of the story. Lots of incidental "internet" humor and references to pop culture that should have been deleted after the first draft. Many eras' memory links are reused from previous levels and the game starts giving up on the memory link structure about halfway. This all adds up to a scattershot and amateur tone that any editor worth his/her salt could have corrected in an hour.Do I like the game? Definitely. Is the end result effective? Sure. But I hope chapter two is better.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												To the Moon will always hold a place close to my heart as one of the most touching narratives a video game has ever delivered. If you're looking for complicated gameplay and combat galore, you won't find it here. Instead, you'll find a roughly three-hour story of memory, friendship, and loyalty. Skip movie night and use the money to pick up this game--you'll find a story more heartfelt than Hollywood can deliver that will haunt you for days after.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Wow, this game is brillaintFirstly, don't be put off by the graphics. It looks like an RPG, but plays like an adventure game.While there are puzzles, which are somewhat basic, they aren't the focus in this game. This game is all about story.You take on the role of two people basically performing Inception on a client; jumping back through his memories to make him think he went to the moon. It's strange seeing the events play out backwards, but it's fun piecing it all together. There were a few moments where they game had thrown me off completely about the context of some events, making it all the better when they were revealed later in the plot. It's apparently also part of an episodic game so I want as many people to play it so we can get the rest sooner.Only bad thing to say about it; DAVID'S MAIN MORPH IS A LION.

												I got this game pretty cheap for like 1 dollar. i thought this game would be another indie short game that's just cheap and made for making people to buy this game as much as possible. Yet this game is magnificent.it's a really short game, i can tell you that but you'll wish that this game would last longer. From the moment the game really starts you're pratically hooked. I highly recommend that you play this game in one go.This game can bring up more emotions than any AAA game out there! From the funny moments when you're laughing due the hilarious dialogues all the way to the very sad moments in the story (believe me there are A LOT of them, so be prepared!).This game alos has one of the best soundtracks ever that can emotionally touch you very deeply and also the artwork is magnificent if you consider their very small budget they had to work with. People who liked the chrono trigger artwork will definitely fall in love with this game.recommended: play this game in one go and don't forget to bring a box filled with tissues because there will be tears that shall be shed! #demFeelzfor the bonus level i recommend you read the guide here:

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												One of the ever rising problems with modern games is their simplicity. They're short, utterly simple, and rarely worth finishing. What makes a game worth it? Is it complexity? Pretty graphics? Reward-factors? Difficulty? Absolutely not, because To the Moon is a short, utterly simple game... and it's definitely worth it.To The Moon is much less a game than it is an experience. Although simple in design, the depths of what it achieves is hard to surpass and simply cannot be passed up. You owe it to yourself to play it.Despite being made in RPG Maker XP, I can't say anything more than that it's simply what's used to pass on the story to the player. It's there, but never really makes the player feel like it's an RPG... it's more of a visual novel, with RPG Maker visuals instead of pictures. Is this a bad thing? Maybe, but what if there's something inside this game so powerful that it'll let one overlook anything iffy about its design? What if it's possible to lose yourself in a different aspect of the game? If it's the story, wouldn't it be like getting lost in a really good book? Yes, yes it would.The game's story is easily its most prominent aspect. There is some side-dialogue you might miss out on, but nothing else is going to sneak by. The story in To the Moon is amazing, sure, but are there any problems with it? Possibly. You see, To the Moon, if it suffers from anything, is its simple dialogue. Sentences are often short and consice. There isn't the same amount of detail you'd get in a novel. However, the pacing of the story, the characters, the plot twists, and everything that comes flying at you like a shuttle makes this one possible issue forgivable, if there really is an issue at all. Because in all of its greatness, I have to find something wrong with it. Honestly, it's a struggle...In addition to its great story, To the Moon has an absolutely amazing OST. Again, like the story, it's also simple. I could delve into detail about this like in the above paragraph, but I'll just stop and tell you that it fits perfectly. Every track only adds to the scene. There is absolutely nothing wrong with its simplicity. I'm done talking about that. Its best to hear the music while playing the game. The music and writing combine to deliver something fascinating, so revel in the simple beauty of the arts.And that's exactly what makes To the Moon an amazing game. Its simplicity. It's a short, to-the-point, and beautifully written story. At the end of it all, yes, I cried.In this world full of AAA games that suffer in some regard from being too simple, is To the Moon a game that stands out among the rest? Yes.Should you play it? If you value what makes video games worthwhile, then yes, you should.

To the Moon is not a good game. The gameplay is trivial (even for a point-and-click adventure game), it's very short and let's not even mention the graphics. But that's not important at all, because a game is not the foremost category that To the Moon belongs to. It's a great story that just happens to be told in a form of a video game, and as such, it's definitely worth experiencing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Please, do not judge a book by its cover or even the screenshots provided. I only played this game because it was a rainy day and I got it in the Humble Bundle for a dollar along with other games. Once I started to play it, I could not stop. I was hooked. I played and finished it within a day, and that was the best day of my life. This story has such a big impact on me for such personal reasons but it can give anyone else the same feeling. The graphics, gameplay, and many other things made me go "ehh" at the idea of playing it, and I hate myself for thinking that way. The story will swallow you alive, the soundtrack will coze you into a daze, and the ending will mentally strain your feelings. People who played this game from start to finish were put in such a frenzy, Freebird Games had to make a short little freebie on their website to calm everyone's nerves, as a salute to the game. It's called "To The Moon: Holdiday Special" Go download it, it's free! It will fill the holes in your heart, at least for the time being.11/10 Would play for a third time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												To the moon. This game. This fricken game is amazing. I must start off by saying this isnt much of a game, its more of an interactive storytelling with tangents for extra information, nonetheless this game is amazing. To the moon is a 2d top down sprite game that tells the story of 2 young doctors whos job is to recreate a patients wish using a machine that recreates it in thier memory. Now thats done, lets get down to it. To the moons story. one - the writer is a genius he created each interactable character with a deep and relatable storyline. This is also the first game I have ever felt so tear-jerked. It was beautiful. The story was told so well from beginning to middle to end, each with impressive plot twists that are hard to see coming. I think that was the art to this story, it was incredibly hard to predict. Now music. One - the soundtrack was beautiful with large amounts of subtle orchestra music playing to create constant ambience at the right moments. There was also some very heavy songs amoung to create unease and funnily enough they sound like they are out of a horror game. two. I bought the OST the minute I finished the game. The graphics - like I said before 2d but this works perfectly, This game is so engrossing you will soon create faces for the characters yourself imagining the perfect emotions for the characters when its really needed. Gameplay. Now the gameplay was a bit weird, the game characters handled a bit like any click to move game, you collect "momentos" to move onto new memorys generally finding a final one to move back to another memory. There were also mountains of media refrences throughout the game. I will leave you with my favourite quote. "Not cool Eva. You Never cockblock someone in the middle of a kamehameha."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Someone once said (I think) that the meaning of tragedy in narrative is to let us channel our sadness, sorrow, into something far greater: an escape or an elevation. To consume a tragedy and shed tears because of it is to see our own shortcomings and faults, to understand the human condition and, while feeling sorrow for it, to overcome the mere sadness of unpleasant and unwanted things. The goal is to understand that while we are "only" human, each and every life story in the context of humanity is an epic in itself. Sounds grandiose, doesn't it?Well, I think that if we agree with what I said before, To the Moon is one of the great tragedies of modern gaming. It is a story monumental by itself: it is mostly the story of a single man and his love and memories, but in its execution it brings us to the shore of nostalgia, fondness, appreciation and - most of all - empathy for our fellow man. This is one of the greatest stories I have experienced. I recommend it for everyone.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												It is very infrequent that I play a game that I consider truly beautiful, and nothing less than genuinely lovely. To the Moon is entirely story based, and the only gameplay to be found is in the form of tile puzzles and a later (apalling) action sequence. Yet the story involved is so heart-wrenchingly engaging that I found myself playing through the 4/5 hour process in merely a few hours. Along with a few intelligent twists, this story reaches a satisfying conclusion. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with To the Moon, despite the terrible controls, and would recommend it to anybody with a heart.

												I loved it. Technologically the game was kind of mediocre (noticeable screen tearing, fixed 640x480 resolution, etc.) and the gameplay got pretty tedious at times, but the actual art - graphics, music and story are all absolutely amazing.As an autistic person I found the girl's part of the storyline kind of.. cliche, I guess? number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												While I can't say this is a game I cried over, To The Moon is a game that will probably linger in my mind throughout the rest of my life. The story is impactful, light-hearted, and most importantly, interesting enough to keep playing through to the end.What To The Moon shows without spoiling much is that life can bring about very unfortunate circumstances, but even under them, people are determined to find happiness, and will use any means to have it. We don't live for what brings us down, but for what keeps us up and fighting to our last breath. Where it shows best is its unbelievable narration and character dialogue. You will remember the happy and humorous parts as much as you would the sad and depressing parts, but neither of the parts affect each other no matter how close they are together in the story.The music? While some may call it repetitive, I find it far from it. It fits many of the situations in the story, and uses the piano as a distinct theming tool. And let me not forget that wonderful piece by Laura Shigihara. I haven't heard a lot from her, being one song from Plants vs. Zombies. But this song is simply stunning, and even moreso in where it plays.Its gameplay can be somewhat excused considering the engine it's built off of, RPG Maker XP. So yes it does look and feel like an old JRPG, but that's not what the game's about anyway. The puzzles were intuitive, but a little too easy (maybe it was intentional so it could be enjoyed in 4 hours?). The mouse controls are convenient especially during sections where it's difficult to find pieces for mementos (which for me almost turned into a pixel-hunt without them).To conclude the review, To The Moon is a game that takes life's meaning and puts it in the hands of the player. Where it takes you is your decision alone.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												First of all, to nitpick/nerd rage for a moment, David's main morph was most certainly NOT a cobra, it was a lion. I'm not even sure he morphed a cobra, I think Marco morphed it in #20 while trying to get the Escafil Device from his room. Sorry, bit of Animorphs freakiness. That said, the game, as many have pointed out, is a bit simplistic, which is why its more novel than game, the actual gaming part amounts to a few search missions and a cute little puzzle game. I'd probably have felt cheated if I'd paid the full $10 instead of being on sale for $2.50. However, to be fair:1) I'm only halfway through as of writing this (the Animorphs thing made me nerd rage so I just HAD to point it out, see above) and most reviews say the ending is quite worth it2) As someone who's used RPG Maker to make games, this thing is impressively done. It's obviously not professional, but it's the HIGHEST level of amateur, and the love/work put into it does shine through. 3) I actually got all the pop culture references, so it made me smile a lot. :) I was actually kinda excited by the Animorphs and Hitchhiker's Guide stuff.

Posted: May 5, 2014
												I initially got hooked after watching a video playthrough of it on Youtube. After actually experiencing the game myself I became even more attached to the story as it progressed. The story itself is amazing and incredible with an ending so sad it would make almost anyone cry (I know I did and still do every time I go through it, haha). The game is short, but the story is definitely worth it. Don't let the game's graphics fool you, there's a lot more to 'To the Moon' than you might initially think. If you do not yet own this game, I recommend you buy it, do whatever you can to get your hands on this game. You won't regret the beautiful story this game takes you through. :)

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												This is a nice, short game.I followed the advice of other gamers and I played "To The Moon" in one sitting.The game is only 4 hours long so it's definitely doable, but I must say that I found it a bit tiring, as the experience to me wasn't as gripping as other reviewers made it out to be.While I found the plot interesting, at certain points the game struggled a bit to hold my attention. These "low" points were more than made up by the emotional scenes towards the end: after a particular scene (first meeting between River and Johnny) everything comes together, all the questions find an answer, and together with a sense of realization I also felt very moved.So yeah if you wanna bawl your eyes out go ahead and play this, it's a good game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												I can safely say there are very few games that have touched me so deeply. I'm proud to say this is one of them. The game made me laugh, cry (both from joy/relief as well as from sadness), and panic. It also made me ponder the meaning of life and the inherent fallibilty of the human brain, as well as the long-lasting effects that everyday choices can make.Granted, this isn't really as much of a game as it is a visual novel, one of which has little to no branching paths therein, but I digress.I truly enjoyed the game's narrative and characters. The chemistry between the two main characters is infectious, and there was more than one time I'd burst out laughing from the banter between them. The references (for the most part) are relevant, recognizable, and genuinely funny. The plot was riveting, and had several startling and brilliant twists. I can honestly say I NEVER would have seen the Joey/Johnny twist coming (and I'll leave it at that, so as not to spoil it for prospective players), and I'm VERY good at predicting plot twists.There are some flaws in this game, as there always are. Nothing's perfect. The list of my gripes follows:1. I wish a lot of the items I picked up served any real purpose through the game. Maybe leading to a secret ending or something? I had that origami rabbit in my inventory the whole game. Not once was it utilized.2. As far as I know, the memento puzzles are nothing but busywork and your amount of moves doesn't affect the game in the slightest.3. The health monitor for your client is apparently just there for window dressing, as I never saw it change unless the plot demanded it, and even then, the effects in the memory, as well as what other NPCs say, tells you of his change in condition, leaving the health monitor to be rather superfluous.4. The game essentially boils down to "hover your mouse over things until you find something to click on". Granted, sometimes you find things that are merely there to set the scene, and that's a good thing, but I'd prefer some indicator on things I can click on.5. Targeting for the mouse seems really wonky at times. In the whack-a-mole minigame, the highlighted box that shows where the hammer is supposedly going to impact seems remarkably imprecise and highly unpredictable. Also, if, on the memento flip puzzles, you click another row before the first one finishes flipping, the next row to flip will be whatever row your cursor is over at the moment the first flipping finishes, and it often isn't one you wanted clicked.6. The animorphs puzzle is wrong. Then again, it's a really minor thing that (as far as I can tell) bears no real effect on the story, so that's a minor gripe.7. They never go into how or why River died. They mention how there's an operation that can be performed, and that it's expensive, but they never really go any further into detail.8. They made River's disorder rather ambiguous. Granted, it was kind of obvious to me, seeing as Human psychology has always fascinated me, but they never mention the disorder by name. I was playing the game alongside a friend, and had to explain to him what River's disorder was, because he thought she was just awkward. Many people probably had to google the author of the book River's doctor gives to Johnny, just to know who Tony Attwood even is.Despite these shortcomings, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who's willing to take the time to get invested in the story and characters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												When I read about this game, I thought it would be some kind of anime story with some memory exploring. Oh boy was I in for a surprise, I had never expected how much this game would affect me.There aren't enough words to describe how amazing this game is. The story is excellently weaved together. The characters all have very distinct personalities, even the two scientists have such distinct personalities you can clearly tell how they would react in situations. (The male one being the sillier and quirky) Exploring the old mans past makes you relate to him as if he was a person you knew in your real life. It's so easy to like him, but also relate to all of his struggles. There are many moments of sadness where my heart aches for him.The most striking character for me is potrayed with a disability in the autism spectrum. Usually when you see these kind of characters, they are either stereotypically good at math (autism) or they are self-absorbed ragers (aspberger). As I have high functioning autism myself (basically between autism and asperger), there are so many ways I could relate to this character and her perception of what love and friendship is. People in the game are also portrayed in the way they view her, because she really stands out as strange and emotionally distant. But the main character, Johnny, just likes her so much he won't let the things get in the way. He spends enough time with her to understand how she works, instead of others that look at her and think she just refuses to be civilized. Excellent portrayal of this disability.The soundtrack is fantastic. Especially "Moonwhisher". I have spent hours and hours crying to this lovely track. It's so incredibly touching. There are few wordless tracks which moves me in the way this one does. It really sets the mood when you are watching a sad scene in the game. Many of the other musical pieces are also great. One of them, "For River", even has a background story in the game as to why the musical piece is so simple at the beginning with just two notes. So when you follow the story to the end, then hear the musical piece in the various adaptions, it really fills my eyes with tears. I liked the graphic of the game. The old school pixels were all very well done and the areas portrayed all feels like they spent a good time to make sure it wouldn't be repeatetive. Nowhere do I remember feeling myself lost. Each area has their own uniqueness, so it is easy to find your way.I love the way the story is told. It literally starts you near the end, then you tread your way back slowly until you reach the start of Johnnys life, then it is like climbing back up again to find parts that were skipped over during the transition there. It doesn't just end there though, the game offers a final piece to the puzzle with a great plot twist. The game starts out by making it seem the issue is easily solved, then it builds up and you realize there is so much more to the game.The only possible complaint I could make about the game is a mini-game you play each time you transistion in a memory. I just thought it was distracting and not fun. It's over quite fast though.This is a game I would recommend to everyone to play at least once. Especially if you enjoy deep, emotional stories that truly explores the personalities and life of the characters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Man, this game...I very rarely write reviews for anything, let alone Steam games. If I wrote a review for every steam game I owned, I'd be here a long time.I originally fired up this game because it has steam cards. I don't even remember how I ended up with a copy. Probably from a Humble Bundle. Regardless, the steam cards enticed me to open it up. With every game I've ever opened for steam cards, I gave it a spin, and I am happy I did.Initial thoughts were ho hum as it took a little bit to get into the game. It was also very focused on trying to get me to use the mouse. Let me say right now to anyone thinking of playing this game, only use the mouse to try and identify items to click on. Move around with the keyboard, it'll make things much easier on you.Initial thoughts aside, I trudged on as I watched my steam inventory tick up on the cards collected. However, as I got deeper and deeper into the game, I found myself fascinated as story events started to reveal. There was quirky humor, shocking reveals, and sad moments. However, the story wraps itself up well and I found myself amazed as I looked back, picking up on small things that happened with no reasoning until things revealed through the ending.The story flows together well. The soundtrack fits in perfectly. The characters have enough depth to keep them interesting, without being overbearing. Overall, this game is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone. I'm not normally an artsy fartsy story telling game kinda guy, but this one was fantastic. Just get ready for tears, because holy crap that reveal.Now if you excuse me, I need to go play 12 hours of Street Fighter to make up for the emotional carnage this game has played on me. :D

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												"To The Moon" is very much a game that is a greater than the sum of its parts. Individually I don't think they are uniquely powerful in anyway. But as a whole this game is brilliant. Its a well put together experience with the narrative and music really capturing you and taking you on an adventure as you go through the world and story in the game. This is a game I really can't reccomend enough and I assure you that you will have some kind of emotional response. My response from the game, was that I actually had to stop the game maybe a third of the way through and call my mother. I just felt compelled to do it, and I'm pretty sure anyone who plays the game is going to get a similarly strong reaction to the game.If you want to read a longer review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/09/to-moon.html.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												I loved this deeply emotional and philosophical game. The themes are very accessible in terms of the common human experience they explore, yet they are presented with very interesting nuance and complexity. The Memento-like mechanic of moving backwards through time in vignettes works really well to create a solid narrative suspense.The minisodes are not as good. They explore the social implications of the technology that is at the base of the game as well as some mystery about the main characters, which is interesting, but the gameplay is weak, involving a lot of back and forth between screens.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												"He's more of a cat person""Why does the world have to be so complicated"So right off the bat you know this game gets nuance.  But all kitten aside, my opinion of the game is  the same as all the other 19 thousand reviews; that this is just a truly great story with a great OST that grabs hold of you from the very first note.  The story did not spin itself into a ball of cliched melodrama mashed with elements that just wouldn't have worked. Kan Gao orchestrated every scene and mustered every creative element he could, piecing them together into a perfectly striking well told story.  It was hilariously funny at just the right points, then deeply moving for all the right reasons.  In two notes, it captures an entire lifetime in melody. With 16-bits, it takes you all the way to the moon.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												To the moon, is an indie game that will take you on an emotional roller coaster. This game with it's story, and execution will make the biggest of gaming men choke up with this beautifully story. Are you ready to ride this roller coaster of feels?Game play: 5While this game is a very story driven, it kinda of lacks in any real game play. You run around as one of the two main characters either in the dying old man johnny's memorys or around his house and outside of it.While inside the his memorys you are task to find key pieces to his memorys after each scene that plays out to unlock earlier memorys. Pretty simple, you look for the “shines” that shows up. After each memory chapter you are given a small puzzle of flipping tiles of a picuture to complete the memory. Overall the game play isn't the main focus here.Story 10The story takes place with an the old man named, johnny, who is on his death bed with only one wish. To go to the moon.  The two main characters you follow are, Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts who are from the Sigmund Corp. who has technology that altar the memory’s of people. They usely use the technology on people who are dying to grant them one last wish. It is the job of Rosalene, and Watts to altar johnny's memory to send him to the moon. While digging deep into the memory’s of Johnny you find out about his wife who passed away years ago. Who has had mental problems who befriends a light house.  You also find out more about his pass on why he wants to go the moon even though he doesn't know himself. You'll end up meeting other characters from his, from his childhood to his aduit life who plays a big role in his life. With some dark twist.This game proves that sometimes isn't not always about having the best game play or graphics to have a compelling story to get you immersed in whats going on.Graphics: 9This game goes with a 16-bit graphic style, with mostly bright and colorful graphics mix with some dark looking graphics to set up each scene nicely. Ir's like playing a classic Super Nintendo game. They paid attention to details to make sure they where fitting for the story thats unfolding in front of your eyes.Music: 9The music is well placed and helps to set the mood for each scene. The music goes hand and hand with the story. They did a great job in matching the music to how they wanted you to feel at that current moment. They also did a great job on the music overall. Having a great story and music can mean all the difference on how well a game like this could do, over all the music mixes well with the story and adds a unique experience that you wont find in many other games. Final Though:I found this game one of the best story driven indie games that I have ever played. The story gets really deep and it will touch most peoples hearts, While giving you a lot of overwhelming feelings that you though you didn't have. The story is a sad story, and can make almost anyone cry or at least choke up. I can safely say that I can compare this to the aeris death scene in final fantasy VII when it comes to emotional feelings.As soon as I started playing. I was immersed in the story with in the first 15 minutes or so. I didn't even want to get up for anything. I only got up one time to use the bathroom, even then I was holding it in for at least an hour before hand. I beat this game in one sitting from start to end. I won't lie to you. I was crying by the end. I remember walking out of my room and my roommates asking why are my eyes so red and I said back to them “im just really tired I didn't get much sleep last night”.If you are wanting a heavy story driven game, then this game WILL be for you. There isn't any real amazing game play here but the story makes up for it ten fold. So for the people who are more about action style games, don't bother in picking up this game you'll most likely find it boring and not to your liking. This game is just overall amazing plain and simple! It's a MUST buy for any story driven game fans out there.Final Score: 10For more reviews and other fun stuff check out my tumblr. www.rogue32807.tumblr.com

												This is quite possibly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played story and graphics wise. The few puzzles in this are relatively simple but fun to figure out.  Fair warning that playing this produced quite a few tears, especially around the midpoint of the game. (And the music is so hauntingly beautiful, moreso after that point that I almost always had tears welling for the rest of the game.)Also, I definitely recommend playing through the whole thing in one sitting. It's short enough that it is entirely worth it, and while I found quite a few places that could make decent stopping points, I was so invested in the story that I wanted to find out what was next. I'm also definitely going to play through the story again just to find out what I'll see differently now that I know the end.And I haven't even started the two minisodes that are dlc, but I've got some high expectations based on the quality of the main story!

Posted: June 28, 2014
												How could I possibly put into words anything that would even remotely come close to an accurate representation of my thoughts on this?This is simply one of the greatest experiences I have ever had in my 22(at the time) years. Trying to pinpoint specific things that made it such would be difficult. Just a wonderful experience. The music, oh lord the music. The combined talents of Laura Shigihara and Kan Gao make this one of the most, alright i'll say it, beautiful soundtrack in a game that is based entirely on its narrative story. The fitting music is comforting when it needs to be as well as dark and unsettling in times where you truly feel worried. However then you have moments like Laura Shigihara's "Everythings Alright" that just bring all the emotion, struggle, hope and everything you've been obsorbing the whole time and lets it all out with you.The simplistic yet perfect medium.Using what could arguably be a simple medium for the presentation of this game, the story and music brings it to the player in a way that far surpasses some more elaborate and higher budget projects. Its just simple, raw, true storytelling. When finishing you can't help but wonder what these writing talents could do given the support of some AAA titles. However at the same time I think a lot of the magic would be lost. Which brings me to my belief that the current method works just fine.The story keeps you going.The biggest drawback people might face is the gameplay. This is where you notice the time focused more on story/music rather than gameplay elements. It is point and click at its finest. More of an interactive story than an adventure. But don't that make you think its so easy *cough* horseback riding memory *cough*. There are things that require thought. Which are kind of speed bumps on your way but provide a good way of pacing the story.Onward and upward.This is not all Kan Gao and Freebird Games have done. They have other projects worth looking into which can be found on their site. There is also an extra holiday episode that fills a gap between To the Moon and the upcoming Bird Story. All of which I highly reccomend looking into.Must do's.Others can feel free to edit in their own thoughts here, but how you play this game is a very important deal in my opinion. I should start by explaining how I came across this game. I came home from work to log into Steam and do my daily "what are my friends up to?" check. I see just one friend in game. An unfamiliar title to which I instantly message him asking what it was. I got no reply so I simply shrugged and went about my evening until about 3 hours later I finally heard the all too familiar ping of Steam messaging. Now this friend is one i've known and grown with for years. We are very alike. His reply was simply "get this game." Luckily I had money and before I even replied it was downloading.I jokingly asked something to the effect of "what the hell did I just buy." He basically told me to shut my door, disable Steam overlay, put my phone away and just play the game. So I did. Roughly 3.5 hours later I emerged after the wonderful thing I just sat through. So in playing this, I HIGHLY reccomend do it in one sitting and far from the distractions of the world. In short, this is one of the greatest things I have ever seen. All who wish for an amazing story pick this up. You can ask any of my Steam friends, I think i've bought it for almost all of them

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												If you like retro styled games that are based fully on the story, this is for you. While playing this game it felt like I was reading a book, a book that takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions. My emotions changed from being sad, happy, and to creeped out just from a single scene change. I recommend playing this game when no one will disturb you, it helps you get into the game.Now however, while this game's story was good, the gameplay was lacking. The minigames seemed to serve no purpose other than to exist. They were short, and didn't give much entertainment if any. I would have either not include them, or implement them in a way that fits the story better, instead of having them get you to the next part of it. ( Another thing, did how well you did on the minigames even affect anything? From what I have seen they don't do anything.)Besided this, the game had a good soundtrack, had no bugs/glitches (atleast for me), and it presented it story well, you never knew what was going to happen. I would rate this game at a 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I had some monumental expectations for "To the Moon". Seeing all of the reviewers claiming they cried, had me hope for a story that would keep me enthralled and emotionally invested the entire time.While the story is emotional, dealing with a husband's struggles in living with a wife with a mental condition, there was one thing  with the writing that kept bothering me...the doctors.They pulled me out of the story almost every time they interacted. From snarky banter, to pop culture references, to pointless "mini-games" involving  zombies??! . I think they weren't written with the same serious tone as the rest of the story.There is a major twist towards the end that I suppose is there to pull your heart strings, but there was no real build up to it and was in a completely different direction then where I thought the story was going.  I thought Anya was going to be a lost child, which would have suited the build up more and been a great cataclyst for River's change in condition. I must say that you should complete this in one playthrough to get the impact of the story. I can see someone missing the emotion if they left the game and came back later to finish it.I recommend people play this as it is a decent story. For a little more then the cost of a movie ticket and time to devote to it (it's 4 hrs long), it's something to experience, but I wish the writers had made the script hold up as maturely as the material.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												A simply incredible story told through a special medium. This isn't your standard RPG, where you have a health bar and mana. There are no lives to lose other than the ones destined to before the game finished downloading. It's not a movie or a book but something that must be told through a game. Think of it like those scenes in your favorite RPG where your in some area like a town or party where you talk to everyone to see what they say, even though it's not required. Granted, it's required in this game but it's not monotonous. It's not like you're in the intro of Paper Mario (N64) and you make a goal for your self to talk to EVERYONE in the Peach's castle. It's like the ending of a game where you sit through some story, then talk people at leisure, then back to story. RPG Maker seems like an odd choice for a story book "engine", but the RPG cutscene feel is the perfect medium for a story like this. A plain-text book with some illustrations or an HD movie just doesn't cut it. Even watching someone on youtube play this isn't the same. A small bit of interactivity is perfect for this story. To think that RPG cutscenes are the proper way to tell such a story is simply amazing and no other medium would do as well. And I haven't even covered the game itself yet, just the medium! I'm going to not go too much into the story, other than that it has some nice turns, and it feels nice to pick up on them before the characters realize what's going on. If you don't notice; don't worry. It's still a slight shock when you find out eventually. There's no major twists, but lots of things laid out that you don't put together right away, and neither do the characters. Eventually things go together, and the game can jerk some tears at some points. Happy, or sad? I won't tell you. Maybe both? Maybe not. In the first 5 minutes, you witness something that feels like it should be sad, but it's not too terrible. It's the little things that get you worked up. It gives the feeling of one of those games where "it was all a dream!" but instead of that being the twist ending you knew it all along. That's not the case with this game though. Just an analogy for how you set yourself up for the inevitable.In short, it's $10 for a 4 hour, intense, RPG cutscene. Scratch that; two things wrong with that: 1. It's not $10, it's $12.49 because you're definitely going to buy the soundtrack. 2. It's not intense as in action-packed, but intense on the head. Brain, tear-ducts, and ears. You'll be thinking of this game days after you play it. Not because it has a great replay-ability or some thick puzzles, but because it has a memorable soundtrack and an emotional plot

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Initially, I didn't think that I would like To the Moon. But I soon found myself being enthralled by this short story.To give a quick summary: In the world of To the Moon, the Sigmund Corporation has created a device to alter the memories of patients. You follow Dr. Rosalena and Dr. Watts as they try to fulfill a dying old man's wish to go to the moon.While the plot can be a bit sappy and predictable at times, it was a nice blend of melancholy and comedy throughout the 3 hours it took to play through. I also found that Johnny's story was incredibly relatable. But what kept me hooked the most was the writing and devlopment of Rosalena and Watts. To the Moon is an excellent short game that can leave an impact on you. It makes you realize that life is just a giant collection of memories, and it's so easy to miss out on a lot of the small details.

												I have to say this game pulled at my emotions more than any other I have played.  I was so grasped by the mystery of the game that I was terrified how the story would be revealed, fearing there were too many loose threads that they would be impossible to tie together, but the story blended beautifully.  I really am not exaggerating when I say this is simply one of the best video game stories of all time.  If I was to nitpick, the doctors retrieving the memories were a little silly.  I would rather have had the old man tell his story, or perhaps the characters figure it out by exploring the house and having him explain it with each object in question they find.  Also, there were some frustrating times where a click was not registered because of poor pathing, or my character wasn't positioned well enough to interact with an object.  But those were mild annoyances at worst, and even if they were horrid, I would still give this game a thumbs up.  The story - the story.  IT IS SO GOOD!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Please, do not judge a book by its cover or even the screenshots provided. I only played this game because it was a rainy day and I got it in the Humble Bundle for a dollar along with other games. Once I started to play it, I could not stop. I was hooked. I played and finished it within a day, and that was the best day of my life. This story has such a big impact on me for such personal reasons but it can give anyone else the same feeling. The graphics, gameplay, and many other things made me go "ehh" at the idea of playing it, and I hate myself for thinking that way. The story will swallow you alive, the soundtrack will coze you into a daze, and the ending will mentally strain your feelings. People who played this game from start to finish were put in such a frenzy, Freebird Games had to make a short little freebie on their website to calm everyone's nerves, as a salute to the game. It's called "To The Moon: Holdiday Special" Go download it, it's free! It will fill the holes in your heart, at least for the time being.11/10 Would play for a third time.

												This is probably the best-written game (or really, anything) that I've ever experienced..Buy it. Buy it now. Don't have another thought until you purchase this game. It's not the best guideline, and there are many exceptions to it. Of all the exceptions, this game is the strongest. It far exceeded my expectations. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I bought this game on a sheer whim, looking for something new to add to my library and hoping to have some fun. I never expected to fall in love with it. From the first 20 minutes in, I was hooked. As implausible as the plotline sounds on paper, the game developers and writers have done an immaculate job of sucking you into this world where it's not only totally possible, it's commonplace.  It's cleverly written, intelligent, and the characters feel like real people.  There are so many gems in the dialogue that made me laugh out loud -- especially a particular TV show reference early on. And I can't say enough good things about the soundtrack. It is so, so lovely.While the gameplay itself is very simplistic and easy, the story is what will keep you rooted to your seat. The pacing is perfect -- moments of sadness, elation, and well-timed comedic relief are placed very well throughout the whole story. And that ending...well, I wouldn't dream of spoiling it, but just hang onto yer butts, kids. And bring the tissues.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												To the Moon is a visual novel rather than a game. I've heard the term RPG used to describe it but that would be incorrect as there are no unique mechanics, form of progression or indeed any aspect of your characters to progress. What might be considered puzzles or game play is nothing more than the game stubbornly folding its arms and barring you from the next chapter until you have collected all five macguffins in each tiny area and a breif bullet hell section at the very end. However, in spite of what I just said, I am recommending To the Moon because it tells an amazing story that kept me interested form beginning to end. As a game designed soley to tell a story it does so in spades with an intrigueing plot, relatable characters, and an ending I didn't see comming. I'm looking foreword to A Bird Story.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												This game not only looks and sounds incredible, but the story is engaging and well-written. While short and not big on the replayability, its worth it to go through even just once. Personally, I will be playing this game many times in the future, but even just once grips you and keeps you all the way to the end. It's heartbreaking but really intriguing. The characters are wonderful and absolutely hilarious, the art is amazing, and the soundtrack is out of this world. Even the two extra DLC about the two workers are really interesting, and deep within its own small stories. I'd say try to go into playing this game completely blind. I had no expectations going into it other than being told it was sad, and not knowing why it was sad made it all the more impactful. Had I known, I bet I wouldn't have cried nearly as hard. So if you want to experience all the raw emotion when you first play it, try your best to avoid spoilers. One of my favorite games, definitely. 10/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												To the Moon is a great story with limited game elements. Maybe it's because I have a soft spot for 16-bit games due to growing up on the SNES, but this game made me care about the characters like few modern games can. Think of it like Chrono Trigger or Mother 3 without the grinding RPG elements. I'd play both of those games just for their stories and as long as you would too, then this game is for you even if you don't typically like interactive stories. I don't compare games to CT or M3 lightly, as I consider them to be two of greatest games ever made, so I'll let that be the highest praise that I can offer this wonderful game.*Obligatory Steam Awared Update*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												To the Moon is a game released by Freebird Game. Previously, To the Moon was sold on Freebirds Games' website before made its way to Steam. The game is designed by using RPG Maker XP which is responsible for its "retro" looks and simple gameplay. What Is the Game About When we are talking about playing video game in general, we are expecting stuff that would engage us to play the game. Generally, gameplay is the one that keeps us to play the game and that what makes video game fun. To the Moon, however, does not offer any gameplay; you spend most of the game walking and reading, and that's all. Therefore It's safe to say that To the Moon offers only cinematic experience than an actual engaging gameplay. Fortunately, the story and the soundtrack of To the Moon are really well crafted that it makes up for the lack of the gameplay. What I LikeThe StoryTo the Moon tells a story of two employees of Sigmund Corp, Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts, that offers a service where people can create artificial memories to achieve their unfulfilled dream in their death bed. The patient handled by Eva and Neil is Johnny who has a dream to go the moon. He is not really sure why he suddenly has an urge to go to the moon, but he still wants to go there anyway and he uses Sigmund Corp's service to fulfill his dream. By using a piece of hardware that enables Eva and Neil to see and interact with Johnny's memories, they are going in a venture where they uncover a story of loss and regrets. By reading the synopsis of the story, it is clear that we would expect something that's resembling a story of  Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind as there are manipulating and exploring memories elements in the story. However, To the Moon manages to stay fresh by using witty dialogues and the way the story unfolds the mystery of Johnny's past keeps me engaged with the game. What I really love from the story is how it delivers its humorous dialogues even in some serious scenes without destroying the atmosphere of the scene. However, even with its witty dialogues and light-hearted characters, the story is still able to deliver a strong punch to the gut with its twist near the end of the game. The MusicOf course without the music that's well composed by Kan Gao and Laura Shigihara, the game could not achieve the atmosphere that it tries to construct from the beginning of the game to the end. From a comedic scene to melancholy one, the music is able to match the tone of the atmosphere and it creates a great experience for me. The main theme of the game, For River, is a simple and monotonous, yet beautiful, song that would greet you as you start the game. However, because it is that monotonous that it ables to grow in me and becomes a memento that would resonate through the playthrough.The Mixed FeelingThe Lack of GameplayWell, the lack of gameplay could be a bummer for some people. There are some simple puzzles in each sequence of the memory and that's all. You will play most of the game walking and reading dialogues and it's just fine for me, even though I hope there are stuff that would make exploring and interacting with the world more enjoyable.ConclusionTo the Moon as a game may not offer an incredible gameplay experience. However, it compensates the lack of gameplay with a wonderful journey of unraveling the repressed emotions and desires of a dying person that would leave you captivated even after you finish the game.Additional InformationFinished the game in three hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												To the moon – ♫ Fly me to the moon♫ To the moon was released in 2011. I first acquired the game as part of a humble bundle and paid it no mind! Man was that a mistake!!The game is listed as an Adventure RPG. But i would call it an interactive short story told backwards. Its not so much a game as it is a great story in a game. It will make you laugh, it might make you cry, but it will certainly show you how a great story can be told through a game. Mostly To the Moon is a treasure hunt, the goal is to find clues to unlock the next stage. With even a few mini games thrown in for good old fun. The story can be hard to follow at times, so make sure you read all the clues at the start. It will not make sense at first but they soon will. This game does have high repeatable play value, because of the complexity of the story.As to the game itself, well it has the feel of an 8-16 bit JRPG.  With simple point and click movement  throughout most of the game play. There is no real combat,  unlike most RPG’s.  And you play as one of two characters, both being doctors. Your goal is to replace a dying mans last wish. It is hard to go into further detail without giving out spoilers.    I would give this game a top rating due to it is an ingenious way to tell a great story while drawing the reader in for more. You cannot beat the price, and it is a no contest debate, whether or not I will buy the next short story game from FreeBird games. I just hope you enjoy this game, err story, um ah game as much as I did.  -TheBad300

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Feel free to read this, I won't include any spoilers, if you're thinking of getting the game. This game is beyond amazing, I picked up simply cause I heard nothing but good things about it, so I gave it a shot. Where to begin... I didn't think much of it at first, kind of expected the ordinary, but it was beyond my expectations.- 8/10 Graphics: For it being an Indie game, I enjoy the sprite animations, since it's limited to what can occur throughout the game.- 10/10 Music: It does get a bit repetitive at some points, but it doesn't lose it's values within the sentimental emotions in the scenario. There is a lot of memorable soothing songs the game lives up to express.- 7/10 Characters: As much as I enjoy watching Dr. Watts having his moments and Dr. Rosalina correcting him, even if he's right, I felt like Johnny could have been displayed differently to "understand" him more, personality and characteristic wise.- 8/10 Gameplay: This is a game where you want to play in a single run-through to grab a bigger feel of what's going on as you put the pieces together. I didn't enjoy finding items that "stick out" to progress, but it was pretty straight-forward anyway even if you're a casual gamer.- 10/10 Story-Line: This game is all story-line based, and was creatively done. It's completely original and met it's expectations. This game will make you feel every single emotion, I kid you not. Happiness, Anger, Sadness, Confusion, Regret... in fact, this game makes you think about your life as well. It expresses that any small thing you say or do can be the difference between you and your future.= 10/10 Cost: Is the game worth the money? For me, it was, and I'd even consider re-playing, even if I know what to expect, it's just one of those games where you might find something new and put reason to it.4.5/5 Overall: I loved this game and it's really inspiring. If you've played Ib, Witch's House, or Mad Father type of games, this should be very similar gameplay. I recommend it, just be sharp with every little detail, it'll help understand the characters' feelings it truly conveys.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												LIK DIS IF YOU CRY EVERTIM. No, but really. I actually cried at the end of this game. In a good way.The gameplay and controlling isn't what makes this game good. It's also lacking a menu, which is really annoying (especially since the volume is quite high). Graphics and animations are retro and quite allright. It's also quite simple to solve all the puzzles, and you never have a big "map" to get lost in. The soundtrack is also very soothing. What this game really perfects, is the story, how it's told and the character-development. The story is told in a clever way and has depth, even though some parts of the playthrough gets somewhat repetitive. When you start to dig into the lives of Johnny and River Wyles and get to know how they met and how their lives unfolded, it's heartbreaking, fun and interesting at the same time.It's a quite short game, being as I completed it in under 4 hours, but I'd still recommend it to players who enjoy a good story-based game. Really, really enjoyable.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Highly Recommended.This is the best game of this genre I have ever played. Not because there's so much action or so many choices but because the story is just so beautiful. I found myself relating to some of the characters very well and understanding why they did what they did throughout the story. It's an extremely emotional game, if you pay attention to the story (Which is a must, if you wish to enjoy the game). While it is a rather sad story, the game doesn't leave you alone and sad as the two characters that discover the story are very close and understand each other. They often bicker and it ends up as a perfect mix between story, emotion and humor. I found it extremely enjoyable.The soundtrack is also brilliant! It gets a little repetitive if you spend to much time in one area but other than that, the detail in the audio of the game (Including sounds) is of a high quality.My recommendation: If you haven't got this game yet, make sure to add it to your "To-Play" list. It really is a story worth hearing.

												I'm generally not a fan of these types of games. When I first discovered this, I debated about getting this game for a few months, And only decided to when the game went onsale over the Steam Summer Sale.The game itself is very nice, I was intially intrigued by the idea of the game, I only further came to like the plot by having the perspective from the two doctors. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I know it's already been said over and over again, but I'll say it again: To The Moon is a fantastic achievement in storytelling that weaves an intricate and fully engrossing tale through the medium of games. The pixel graphics are charming and suit the game well. The music is beautiful and perfectly timed, tugging at the player's emotions at just the right moments. While there are a few kinks here and there, the story is so entrancing that these can be easily overlooked.Actual gameplay is pretty minimal, with players simply exploring areas to progress the story and solving some easy puzzles, but it's an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and despite having a linear story, the game never feels too confined. I very quickly became invested in the plot and wanted to delve deeper and discover the answers to all the questions each new progression raised. To The Moon is a story that deals with a great range of emotions and takes the player along for the ride to experience the ups and downs of life. If you're the sensitive type, be prepared for tears. I cried like a baby.In short: I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who can appreciate a good story, regardless of what your actual taste in video-games is. You might be surprised.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This isn't a game, but it is a touching story told in reverse which still makes for a worthwhile experience. As the player you control the speed at which the story unravels but not much else and at times it all gets a bit repetive. Thankfully the 'experience' is short otherwise it could have ended up becoming tedious.Perhaps acknowledging that people will be expecting some sort of gameplay there's a single repeating image puzzle element, but it's so easy and without any risk that it doesn't qualify. It's arguable that the developer should have had the courage to stick with their vision and omit the puzzles, they add nothing to the story and feel out of place.So, this is a story, I should be reviewing that then. Well I don't want to give anything away about the ending, or should I say beginning since it's told in reverse? It's a slight love story, one of small coincidence, endurance through hardship and personal tragedy. It's not life changing or all that original, but if you have a shred of empathy and compassion then you will probably enjoy it. It's unclear whether the player has any control over the outcome, but I saw no point at which this was likely so there is no replay value.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Warning: mysterious fluids might start coming out of your eyes after finishing this game.I'll start by getting the cons out of the way first. This game is very short and you can easily finish it in 1 or 2 sittings (3 to 4 hours). And there's only a couple of minutes of actual gameplay in total, the rest is mostly text and some exploration elements. This game would have been fine as just a visual novel or a point and click game but despite all this, the game makes up for it with a deep and touching story. The story really emphasizes how it's not about the destination, but rather the journey. Paired up with an amazing soundtrack, this game creates a beautiful experience that makes it all worthwhile.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I got this game as part of an indie bundle a few months ago. I didn't think much of it until last week, when my wife mentioned that she'd heard of it and wanted to check it out. I must admit I was a little bored with the graphics and snarky tone for the first 45 minutes or so. I almost fell asleep, if I'm being honest. But I'm so, so glad I didn't. This turned out to be one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. The pacing is perfect, the music is beautiful, and the storytelling is just superb. This is a game that will touch you deeply if you give it a chance and will probably stick with you for weeks after you've finished it. Certainly a work of art.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												My friend had been bugging me to get this game for ages, so last Christmas I got it in the sale. I didn't play it for ages (though they continued to bug me) until one weekend I thought I'd give it a try. I finished it in one sitting.This isn't a game for someone who wants to have an effect on the world they're playing in, to customise their character and explore freely. The gameplay is very simple, mostly just walking around and talking to people in order to progress to the next cutscene; although there were a few quirkier moments and they really did a good job of stopping the gameplay feeling monotonous. This is a story that is beautifully told and really draws you in. The characters are all full of personality and as you delve through memories you really get invested in finding out the meaning behind certain events. The atmosphere is wonderfully maintained by the soundtrack, which at points is woven into the narrative (I nearly cried when I heard a certain piece towards the end of the game). The art style too is lovely, simple with repeating themes to help you recognise things throughout the timeline but still lovely to look at. Honestly, I teared up at a few points as To the Moon is such a beautiful game - though if you like a lot of input into your games then this probably isn't for you. I would definitely recommend giving it a go though, particularly if it's on sale as it is only ~4 hours to play all the way through (though it feels longer!).

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												After playing To The Moon, it's hard to believe the large percentage of people that would give this a perfect score, but, I can easily see their standpoint. The detractors that dislike this game are those that I feel were downplaying just how much a story can carry the game's experience. Throughout your playthrough, this game will lack all the action that a shooter would give, and it does not deliver any interesting gameplay aspects besides some scattered puzzles. You essentially "play" a movie-like story. I have to say though, that the story just flat out hauls this game to emotionals highpoints. Its premise is very unique and the execution of it is filled with dialogue. It has many funny parts to break the monotomy of all that dialogue, and just delivers an amazing experience. That's exactly what I've felt after playing this game twice. It was an experience. An experience unlike much else that I've ever played.Ultimately, I had a wonderful time playing this game. Introducing this game to friends has been a blast. I can only dream of going through the first-time experience of "To The Moon" again.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Wow. This game is good. At the end I had to grab a turtle and cry in to it.Gameplay:Basically, the gameplay is going around looking for important items (I think they are called memory links) then, after finding all 5 in a level, go to a very special item to the person (Johnny in this case) and use that to get to the next memory. Obviously, your just trying to find out why Johnny wants to go to the moon, then you need to alter his memories so then he can go to the moon. Well, technically he isn't going to the moon... they just alter his memories like Total Recall, But whatever. Also includes a mediocre wack a mole game, but its only used once, and a part where you shoot zombies with potted plants. Yeah... Potted plants.Story:It starts with you killing a squirrel. No, seriously. This game has a pretty humorous storyline as you can probably tell. But its also really sad and tragic, especially torwards the end where it is revealed the squirrel had a family. Just kidding thats a future dlc. Maybe.If I were to compare it to games I've played in this genre, I'd say its story is about equal in quality to ghost trick, which means better than Phoenix wright (in my opinion... I have played the games) but not as good as 999 (Play it after this one, its way more tragic than if this had a baby with ghost trick and then the baby died). Basicallly, it has a very impressive storyline.I would really reccomend this to anyone, even those who don't like sad stories because its not just a sad, sappy story. It actually does some pretty smart things, including connecting timelines even after the fork (whether or not Johnny goes to the moon) and doing callbacks to other parts in the timeline.In short, its a really good game and I would highly reccomend it to everyone looking for a nice, short story that doesn't tell you everything up front.Also, GG squirrel. U got rekt m8.

												This game not only looks and sounds incredible, but the story is engaging and well-written. While short and not big on the replayability, its worth it to go through even just once. Personally, I will be playing this game many times in the future, but even just once grips you and keeps you all the way to the end. It's heartbreaking but really intriguing. The characters are wonderful and absolutely hilarious, the art is amazing, and the soundtrack is out of this world. Even the two extra DLC about the two workers are really interesting, and deep within its own small stories. I'd say try to go into playing this game completely blind. I had no expectations going into it other than being told it was sad, and not knowing why it was sad made it all the more impactful. Had I known, I bet I wouldn't have cried nearly as hard. So if you want to experience all the raw emotion when you first play it, try your best to avoid spoilers. One of my favorite games, definitely. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												What can I say about this game?Well, it's not really a game, for starters. It's more of a story-driven point-and-click adventure, though at points the player may use keyboard keys. To the Moon is an emotional rollercoaster, with highs, lows, and the occasional derailing, lovingly packed with just enough humor to make me grin past the manly tears rolling down my cheeks.The soundtrack alone makes it worth the price tag. If you play this game with music disabled, you're doing it wrong. Each individual track perfectly fits the situation that it is tied to, and each rates a five-star rating from me. I'm not going to spoil anything about the story. I enjoyed the story, and although it may not have been the happiest, I cannot think of a single way to improve it. I went into this experience without knowing a single thing about To The Moon, and I do not regret my purchase in the slightest. It took me eight and a half hours to complete. As of the time I'm writing this recommendation, it's 70% off, at just $2.99. Buy it. Play it. Love it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												To The Moon is the only game that I have ever played that has made me so emotionally attached to a cast of characters and to a plotline that I started to cry, and I am not ashamed to admit that. To the Moon isn't a whole lot of game, as it is a story-based experience that you have your hand in. Just to keep this review short, the story is the best I have ever experienced in a game and while the visual style of pixel art may put some off, that combined with the absolutely perfect soundtrack complements a game that will capture anyone looking for a new experience. This game is a must-own and I would not be surprised if a movie adaptation comes down the line. Please, spend a day and play this game.

content:
Posted: January 1
												One of my favorite stories I've ever read/played. The plot is well developed and thoroughly enjoyable. This game is a steal at its current sale price!Art is simplistic but amazing in its own style. The characters have nice designs and I love the level design. It's such a beautiful game -- nothing I'd expect out of a game I'd never heard of before its sale.As for controls, the movement with clicking can be a bit annoying, but it's really no big deal. The puzzles are easier than I thought they'd be. I don't think going for the "ideal" amount of moves on all the puzzles does anything significant, so no need to be stubborn like I was and keep trying to find the ideal move order. The soundtrack for this game is amazing. After launching the game for the first time, I was awed by the main menu track and knew it'd be well worth my time even if it were just for the music. Throughout the game, the soundtrack worked well to produce an appropriate atmosphere, as the soundtracks were very nice and fitting.TLDR: I can't recommend this game enough. The story is fascinating and the soundtrack is worth the price of the entire game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I literally just finished the game less than a minute ago, and my first thought was to write my first review.  I'm a sucker for games that have an impressive story.  For example, Bioshock Infinite had plenty of action and a killer ending to go along, and I loved it.  Same with The Last of Us.  But this game, To The Moon, is the first that made me cry.  I'm not ashamed to admit it because this game is truely a gift.To those of you wondering whether it's a worthy investment, it is.  If you are fine with tons of dialogue and a bit of puzzle solving, then by all means, purchase as soon as possible.  This is by far the best game I've played in my life story-wise.  And the music...I don't think the game would have been nearly as good if the music was different.Overall, amazing and perfect game.  I will probably replay it just to try and experience it again, but there is nothing like the first time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Ok, here's the thing : To the Moon is not a typical 'game'; There's no leveling, there's no monster fighting/killing, and no HP or MP. In fact, it's kinda like a highly interactive visual novel where the characters get to walk around and perform certain actions to enable the story to move forward. While the 'gameplay' might not be everyone's cup of tea, I highy suggest this game for its great soundtrack and story.Con : Not a fan of the game's point-and-click controls; Requires 2 clicks at times to get the characters to move to the require spot or walk through a door/next screen (not that big an issue but a mild annoyance nonetheless)Pros : Where do I start??1. AWESOME soundtrack (I immediately bought the Game + Soundtrack bundle after the trailer finished playing)2. Great storyline3. Nostalgic graphicsTo the Moon is a great example of an extremely well done game. There's no need for flashy graphics or high requirements; All that is needed is a great storyline and soundtrack.  Now excuse me while I go hunt down the damned ninjas who were cutting onions in my room.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												This game.... became one of my favorites in the course of about an hour and a half. Now, I've heard a lot against it, but people really like to miss the point. This game isn't about gameplay, it's about story. In fact, it's much more story than game. The actual "gameplay" elements are there, but barely at all. I'd call it more an interactive novel.Anyhow, pick it up if you're a story type. The dialogue can be a little clumsy and the controls a little wonky at times, but this is still a very good game with an extremely engrossing story.And the music's great, too.
