number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This isn't a game, but it is a touching story told in reverse which still makes for a worthwhile experience. As the player you control the speed at which the story unravels but not much else and at times it all gets a bit repetive. Thankfully the 'experience' is short otherwise it could have ended up becoming tedious.Perhaps acknowledging that people will be expecting some sort of gameplay there's a single repeating image puzzle element, but it's so easy and without any risk that it doesn't qualify. It's arguable that the developer should have had the courage to stick with their vision and omit the puzzles, they add nothing to the story and feel out of place.So, this is a story, I should be reviewing that then. Well I don't want to give anything away about the ending, or should I say beginning since it's told in reverse? It's a slight love story, one of small coincidence, endurance through hardship and personal tragedy. It's not life changing or all that original, but if you have a shred of empathy and compassion then you will probably enjoy it. It's unclear whether the player has any control over the outcome, but I saw no point at which this was likely so there is no replay value.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I know it's already been said over and over again, but I'll say it again: To The Moon is a fantastic achievement in storytelling that weaves an intricate and fully engrossing tale through the medium of games. The pixel graphics are charming and suit the game well. The music is beautiful and perfectly timed, tugging at the player's emotions at just the right moments. While there are a few kinks here and there, the story is so entrancing that these can be easily overlooked.Actual gameplay is pretty minimal, with players simply exploring areas to progress the story and solving some easy puzzles, but it's an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and despite having a linear story, the game never feels too confined. I very quickly became invested in the plot and wanted to delve deeper and discover the answers to all the questions each new progression raised. To The Moon is a story that deals with a great range of emotions and takes the player along for the ride to experience the ups and downs of life. If you're the sensitive type, be prepared for tears. I cried like a baby.In short: I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who can appreciate a good story, regardless of what your actual taste in video-games is. You might be surprised.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												This game is hard to review because it has so many faults and yet I still recommend it. The controls are beyond awful, the "puzzle" and "action" sequences are worse than amateur attempts you'd find on Newgrounds and in fact detract from the game itself, and worst of all: the "humor" that is non-stop present in the game is so idiotic and childish that it undermines the rest of the experience. The "humor" is essentially the dumbest smartass comments I've ever heard spewed so nonstop I felt like I couldn't go a minute without it being displayed. I laughed maybe once and I don't believe humor in a story based game that is about something so deep and serious is necessarily a bad thing, just done very poorly in this case. Also as a composer, I feel the music is very tacky "pop art" and poorly composed, as well as repeated nonstop (but I suppose that goes well with the theme of the game) and overall it also undermines the story for me.However, I feel that this game still has a very deep and interesting story that brought about a lot of emotions in me and I feel the overall writing was superb. It's cheesy in all of the right ways...by actually delving into serious real life issues and being bitterwsweet about it the entire time. And on top of that, it personally struck home with me both because of the story and because of the surrealistic aspect of the entire game. I consider all video games as art but for the sake of categorization, I would call this an "art game" in the sense that it clearly tries to be more than simple mindless entertainment.I recommend it to anybody but it should probably be played in short stints to avoid frustration at the issues mentioned.
